PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Greenwood, Mississippi. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1977 Code and ordinances subsequently adopted by the City Council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1977 Code and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been provided catchlines to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
RELATED LAWS RL:1 SPECIAL ACTS SA:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1 SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Daniel Walker, Code Attorney, and Kim Ryder, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Thomas Gregory, Chief Administrative Officer of the City of Greenwood for his cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that his efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Greenwood, Mississippi," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1977, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to codify ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-15. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and interpretation. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council: 
    City. The terms "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Greenwood, Mississippi" followed it. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits, city limits. Whenever the terms "corporate limits," "corporation limits," or "city limits" are used they mean the legal boundary of the City of Greenwood, Mississippi. 
    Council. The terms "council" and "council of the city" mean the governing body of Greenwood, Mississippi. 
    County. Whenever the terms "the county" or "this county" are used they mean the County of Leflore, Mississippi. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring or authorizing the head of a department or agency of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it shall be construed as authorizing the head of the department or agency to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act or make the inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper, proprietor. Whenever the term "keeper" or "proprietor" is used it means persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Law. The term "law," when used in any ordinance, includes any provision of the Constitution of the United States, or the State of Mississippi, and any statute of the United States or the State of Mississippi, and any ordinance, resolution or order of the Council of the City of Greenwood, Mississippi. 
    MAC. This term refers to the Mississippi Administrative Code. 
    MCA 1972. This term refers to the Mississippi Code Annotated, 1972, as amended. 
    Month. Whenever the term "month" is used it means a calendar month. 
    Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Greenwood" followed it. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. Words used in the singular number only, as descriptive of either persons or things, shall extend to and embrace the plural number; and words used in the plural number shall extend to and embrace the singular number. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes the term "affirmation" in all cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Offense. The term "offense" means any violation of an ordinance liable to punishment by criminal prosecution. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. Whenever the term "owner" is applied to a building or land, it includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. Whenever the term "person" is used it includes, means and may be applied to any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, or to a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court or in any other manner. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes goods, chattels, effects, evidences of rights of action, and all written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation or any right, title or interest in any real or personal estate shall be created, acknowledged, transferred, incurred, defeated, discharged or diminished. 
    Preceding, following. Whenever the terms "preceding" and "following" are used they mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Premises. Whenever the term "premises" is used it means place or places. 
    Property. The term "property" includes personal property as defined herein and also every estate, interest or right in lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes every estate, interest or right, in lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Residence. Whenever the term "residence" is used it means the place adopted by a person as said person's place of habitation, and to which, whenever the person is absent, said person has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed the residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the term "seal" is used it means the city or corporate seal. 
    Sidewalk. Whenever the term "sidewalk" is used it means any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. Whenever the terms "the state" or "this state" are used they mean the State of Mississippi. 
    Street. Whenever the term "street" is used it means any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, viaduct or other public highway in the city. 
    Swear or sworn. The term "swear" or "sworn" includes the term "affirm" or "affirmed," in all cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Tenant, occupant. Whenever the term "tenant" or "occupant" is applied to a building or land, it includes any person holding a written or oral lease on, or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. Whenever the term "week" is used it means seven days. 
    Written, in writing may include printing, engraving, lithographing or any other representation of words, letters or figures; except that in all cases where the signature of any person is required, it shall always be the proper handwriting or mark of such person. 
    Year. Whenever the term "year" is used it means a calendar year. 
(Code 1977, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definition of terms used in statutes, MCA 1972, § 1-3-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-4 hereof. 
(Code 1977, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)	Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not less than $100.00, nor exceeding $1,000.00, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, and the cost of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the municipal judge. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	In addition to the penalties hereinabove provided in subsection (a) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the city, as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Maximum penalty, MCA 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 1-5. - Working city prisoners; credit against fine. 
(a)	Persons imprisoned for the violation of city ordinances may be required to work upon the streets of the city. 
(b)	Where such prisoner is engaged in working out a fine assessed against him, the prisoner shall receive a credit against said fine at the rate of the highest current federal minimum wage. 
(c)	The officer in charge of the prisoners shall file a report with the jailer of each prisoner working out a fine, and the latter shall credit the result of such labor to the fine assessed against such prisoner as the same appears upon the jail docket. 
(Code 1977, § 1-5; Ord. of 12-15-1987, § 1) 
State Law reference- Authority, MCA 1972, § 47-1-39; credit against fine, MCA 1972, § 47-1-47. 
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code-Effect. 
    All additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the council to make the same a part hereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that reference to the "Code of Ordinances, City of Greenwood, Mississippi," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(Code 1977, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Same-Manner. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. 
(Code 1977, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - Same-Language. 
    Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Greenwood, Mississippi, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." (Set out new provisions in full.) 
(Code 1977, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Style of ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-7. 
Sec. 1-9. - Same-New material. 
(a)	In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Greenwood, Mississippi, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article, chapter or other designation as the case may be), to be numbered ____________ , which reads as follows:...." (Set out new provisions in full.) 
(b)	In lieu of subsection (a) of this section, when the council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the Code, which the council desires to incorporate into the Code, a provision in substantially the following language may be made part of such ordinance: "It is the intention of the council and it is hereby ordained, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Code of Ordinances, City of Greenwood, Mississippi, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(Code 1977, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - Same-Repeal. 
    All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1977, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-11. - Same-Subject to general penalty. 
    In case of the amendment by the council of any section of this Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 1-4 shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
(Code 1977, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1977, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-13. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)	The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)	The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1977, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-14. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 1-14) 
Sec. 1-15. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    The ordinance adopting this Code shall not affect any valid ordinance in effect at the time of adoption of this Code which is: 
(1)	Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by city; 
(2)	Containing any administrative provisions of the city council not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; 
(3)	Granting any right or franchise and establishing any rates therefor; 
(4)	Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(5)	Making any appropriation; 
(6)	Levying or imposing taxes not inconsistent with this Code; 
(7)	Establishing or prescribing grades in the city; 
(8)	Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)	Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(10)	Adopting, extending or contracting the boundaries of the city, and incidental acts pertinent to annexations; 
(11)	Prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(12)	Prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets, or portions thereof, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(13)	Pertaining to rezoning of specific property; 
(14)	Any other ordinance, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; and 
all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set forth in this Code, until revised or repealed after adoption of this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Municipalities generally, MCA 1972, § 21-1-1 et seq.; general municipal powers, MCA 1972, § 21-17-1 et seq.; appointive officers, MCA 1972, § 21-3-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Form of government. 
    The city shall be governed by the "mayor-council" form of government as provided for in MCA 1972, title 21, chapter 8. The city council shall be composed of seven city councilmembers. One councilmember shall be elected from each of the seven wards in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 2-1; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Ward boundaries. 
    The city shall be divided into seven wards, each being described as follows: 
(1)	Ward 1 Precinct. All area within the existing boundaries of the City of Greenwood bounded on the North by the corporate limits and the Tallahatchie River; bounded on the East by Grand Boulevard from the Tallahatchie River to President Street; bounded on the South by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Grand Boulevard and President Street; West on President Street to Dionyse Street, North on Dionyse Street to West Adams Street, West on Adams Street to Monroe Avenue; West on Monroe Avenue to its intersection with Montgomery Street; South on Montgomery Street to Claiborne Avenue; West on Claiborne Avenue to U.S. Highway 82 to the Yazoo River; West along the Yazoo River and the corporate limits to its intersection with the west corporate limits of the City of Greenwood; bounded on the West by the corporate limits. 
(2)	Ward 2 Precinct. All area within the existing boundaries of the City of Greenwood bounded on the North by the corporate limits and the Tallahatchie River; bounded on the East by the current corporate limits from its intersection with the Tallahatchie River to its intersection with the Yazoo River; bounded on the South by the Yazoo River to the historic Keesler Bridge; bounded on the West by Grand Boulevard from the historic Keesler Bridge to the Tallahatchie River. 
(3)	Ward 3 Precinct. All area within the existing boundaries of the City of Greenwood bounded on the North by a line described as beginning at the intersection of President Street and Grand Boulevard; then West on President Street to Dionyse Street; thence North on Dionyse Street to its intersection with Adams Street; thence West on Adams Street to its intersection with Monroe Avenue; thence West on Monroe Avenue to its intersection with Montgomery Street; bounded on the West by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Monroe Avenue and Montgomery Street; thence South on Montgomery Street to Claiborne Avenue; thence West on Claiborne Avenue to U.S. Highway 82; thence South on U.S. Highway 82 to the corporate limits of the City of Greenwood, thence West along the corporate limits to its intersection with the western corporate limit line. Bounded on the west by a line described as beginning at the West corporate limit line and the Yazoo River; South to the intersection of Sections 16, 17, 20, and 21 (less and except an area bound on the North by Mann Street on the East by Buckeye Road; on the South by Scruggs Street; and on the West by Beale Street); bounded on the South by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Sections 16, 17, 20, and 21; thence East along the Section line to its intersection with Cypress Road Extended; thence North on Cypress Road Extended and Cypress Road to its intersection with U.S. Highway 82; thence East on U.S. Highway 82 to its intersection with Whittington Park Drive; bounded on the East by a line described as beginning at the intersection of U.S. Highway 82 and Whittington Park Drive, thence North on Whittington Park Drive to its intersection with Henry Street, thence East on Henry Street to its intersection with Parkway, thence North on Parkway to its intersection with Johnson Street; thence East on Johnson Street to its intersection with Main Street; thence North on Main Street to its intersection with Front Street; thence West on Front Street to Fulton Street and the historic Keesler Bridge; thence North across the historic Keesler bridge to Grand Boulevard to its intersection with President Street. 
(4)	Ward 4 Precinct. All area within the existing boundaries of the City of Greenwood bounded on the North by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Sections 16, 17, 20, and 21; thence East along the sectional line to its intersection with Cypress Road Extended; thence North on Cypress Road Extended to its intersection with U.S. Highway 82; thence West on U.S. Highway 82 to its intersection with Whittington Park Drive; thence North on Whittington Park Drive to its intersection with Henry Street; thence West on Henry Street to its intersection with Parkway; thence North on Parkway to its intersection with Johnson Street; thence West on Johnson Street to its intersection with Fulton Street; bounded on the East by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Johnson Street and Fulton Street, South on Fulton Street to Palace Street; thence West on Palace Street to its intersection with Henderson Street; thence South on Henderson Street to its intersection with the property line between Crestview Homes and Earnestine McNease Apartments; thence East on the property line to Cotton Street; thence East on Cotton Street to its intersection with the Canadian National Railroad tracks and the corporate limits of the City of Greenwood; South on the corporate limits to its southernmost point; bounded on the South by the existing corporate limits and bounded on the West by the existing corporate limits. 
(5)	Ward 5 Precinct. All area within the existing boundary of the City of Greenwood bounded on the North by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Main Street Extended and the Yazoo River, thence East along the Yazoo River to its intersection with the corporate limits; thence East on the corporate limits to its intersection with the Canadian National Railroad tracks, thence South on the Canadian National Railroad tracks to its intersection with McNeill Street; East on McNeill Street to Pelican Avenue; South on Pelican Avenue to Carrollton Avenue; East on Carrollton Avenue to Barrentine Street; bounded on the East by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Carrollton Avenue and Barrentine Street; South along Barrentine Street to Ash Street; West along Ash Street to Flowers Street; South along Flowers Street to McLaurin Street; West on McLaurin Street to its intersection with Avenue I; South on Avenue I to its intersection with Broad Street; bounded on the South by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Avenue I and Broad Street; thence West on Broad Street to its intersection with Avenue H; North on Avenue H to its intersection with Scott Street, West on Scott Street to its intersection with the Canadian National railroad tracks; thence North on the Canadian National railroad tracks to its intersection with Main Street; thence North on Main Street to its intersection with Jackson Street; thence West on Jackson Street to its intersection with Fulton Street; bounded on the West by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Jackson Street and Fulton Street; thence North on Fulton Street to its intersection with Johnson Street; thence East on Johnson Street to its intersection with Main Street; thence North on Main Street Extended to its intersection with the Yazoo River. 
(6)	Ward 6 Precinct. All area within the existing area of the City of Greenwood bounded on the West by a line described as beginning at the intersection of U.S. Highway 49 East with Craig Canal; North along U.S. Highway 49 East to its intersection with Canadian National Railroad tracks; North along the Canadian National Railroad tracks to its intersection with Cotton Street, West on Cotton Street to its intersection with the boundary line between Crestview Homes and Earnestine McNease Apartments, West on the property line to its intersection with Henderson Street; North on Henderson Street to its intersection with Palace Street; bounded on the North by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Henderson Street and Palace Street, thence East on Palace Street to its intersection with Fulton Street; South on Fulton Street to its intersection with Jackson Street; East on Jackson Street to its intersection with Main Street; South on Main Street to its intersection with Canadian National Railroad tracks; thence South on the Canadian National Railroad tracks to its intersection with Scott Street; thence East on Scott Street to its intersection with Avenue H; thence South on Avenue H to its intersection with Broad Street; East on Broad Street to its intersection with Miller Avenue; North on Miller Avenue to its intersection with Jordan Street; East on Jordan Street to Bowie Lane; bounded on the East by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Bowie Lane and Jordan Street, South on Bowie Lane to its intersection with Booker Avenue and the existing city limits line; and bounded on the South by the existing city limits line from the intersection of Bowie Lane and Booker Avenue to the intersection of U.S. Highway 49 East and the Craig Canal. 
(7)	Ward 7 Precinct. All area within the existing boundaries of the City of Greenwood bounded on the West by Canadian National Railroad North from its intersection with McNeill Street Extended to the intersection of the existing city limits line; bounded on the North by a line described as the corporate limits from the Canadian National Railroad South to Pelucia Creek (Bayou); East along Pelucia Creek (Bayou), being also the corporate limits of the City of Greenwood; bounded on the East by a line described as the corporate limits of the City of Greenwood South from its intersection with Pelucia Creek (Bayou) (Big Sand Creek); and bounded on the South by a line described as the current corporate limits, East to its intersection with Bowie Lane, thence North on Bowie Lane to Jordan Street; West along Jordan Street to Miller Avenue; South along Miller Avenue to Broad Street; West along Broad Street to Avenue I, bounded on the East by a line described as beginning at the intersection of Avenue I and Broad Street, thence North along Avenue I to McLaurin Street; thence East on McLaurin Street to its intersection with Flowers Street; North along Flowers Street to its intersection with Ash Street; East on Ash until its intersection with Barrentine Street; thence North on Barrentine to its intersection with Carrollton Avenue; thence West on Carrollton Avenue to its intersection with Pelican Street; thence North on Pelican Street to its intersection with McNeill Street; thence West on McNeill to the Canadian National Railroad. 
(Code 1977, § 2-2; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 12-20-1988, § 1; Ord. of 2-25-1992; Ord. of 9-4-2001, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 01-16, § 1, 11-8-2001; Ord. of 3-22-2005, § 2; Ord. of 4-5-2005, § 2; Ord. of 8-7-2012, § I) 
Editor's note- Section II of an ordinance adopted August 7, 2012, states that the map describing the boundaries wards listed in the above subsections are on file in the office of the city clerk. This map shall be in aid of the descriptions set forth above. 
Sec. 2-3. - Providing registration and poll books. 
    The registrar of the city is hereby authorized and directed and empowered to cause proper poll books to be prepared in accordance with the provisions of law and shall provide means for facilitating the registration of the qualified electors by having registration and poll books at said precincts at proper and convenient times after due notice. 
(Code 1977, § 2-3; Ord. of 5-1-1951, § 2) 
Sec. 2-4. - Compensation for members of the city's election commission. 
    Municipal election commissioners shall be entitled to receive a per diem in the amount to be established from time to time, to be paid from the municipal general fund for every day or period of no less than two hours accumulated over two days, not to exceed 50 such days or period per year, when actually employed in the performance of their duties in the conduct of an election or actually employed in the performance of their duties for the necessary time spent in the revision of registration books and poll books necessary for conducting of municipal elections. 
(Code 1977, § 2-26.5; Ord. of 11-19-2002) 
Secs. 2-5-2-8. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATIVE STRUCTURE AND OFFICIALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-9. - Exercise of executive and administrative power. 
    The executive and administrative power and duties of the municipality shall be exercised by the mayor. 
(Code 1977, § 2-9; Ord. of 3-2-1965, §§ 3, 4; Ord. of 7-2-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 2-10. - Chief administrative officer. 
    A chief administrative officer shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council; such chief administrative officer shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor, shall be answerable solely to the mayor in the performance of functions of the office, and shall be subject to dismissal at the pleasure of the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall coordinate and direct the operations of the various departments and functions of municipal government and may exercise any authority, power, or duty lawfully delegated to him by the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall be excluded from the coverage of any ordinance or general law providing for a civil service system in the municipality. The position of chief administrative officer shall be a non-classified position and shall be excluded from coverage by the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 2-9.1; Ord. of 7-2-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 2-11. - City departments. 
(a)	The supervisory and administrations powers and duties of the city are hereby distributed among seven departments as follows: administration, public works, police, fire, office of the city clerk, wastewater treatment, and recycling. 
(b)	The department of administration shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction in the following areas of municipal government, to-wit: community development, including building inspections, code enforcement, floodplain management, licensing and permitting, and planning and zoning; and, human resources. This department shall be headed by the chief administrative officer and shall be directly under the supervision of the mayor. 
(c)	The department of public works shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the following areas of municipal government, to-wit: public works administration office, all employees of the public works shop division, street division, sanitation division (garbage and trash), parks and recreation division, and inventory control division and such other duties as assigned by the mayor. This department shall be headed by a director appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The head of the department shall have the title of public works director. 
(d)	The police department shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the following areas of municipal government, to-wit: all policemen and employees of the police department, municipal justice court, ex-officio deputy clerks appointed pursuant to section 2-72, police department representation on the civil service commission and disability and pension boards, school crossing guards, auxiliary policemen, animal control, city jail, and such other duties as assigned by the mayor. This department shall be headed by a director appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The head of this department shall have the title of chief of police. 
(e)	The fire department shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the following areas of municipal government, to-wit: all firefighters and employees of the fire department, fire department representation on the civil service commission and disability and pension boards, city fire inspection, fire department training facility, and such other duties as assigned by the mayor. This department shall be headed by a director appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The head of this department shall have the title of fire chief. 
(f)	The office of the city clerk shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the following areas of municipal government, to-wit: All deputy clerks and employees of the city clerk's office, accounting, voter registration, maintaining minutes and dockets, all data processing equipment, city budget, tax rolls, auditing, and all other duties placed upon the city or city clerk under the laws of the state. The city clerk shall also perform the duties of the clerk of the city council, if so appointed, in accordance with MCA 1972, § 21-8-11. The director of this department shall be the city clerk who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. 
(g)	The waste water treatment department shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the waste water treatment plant division and such other duties as assigned by the mayor. This division shall be headed by a director appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The head of the division shall have the title of wastewater treatment director. 
(h)	The recycling department, also known as Greenwood Leflore Recycling, shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for supervision, management, operation, and direction of the recycling department and such other duties as assigned by the mayor. The recycling department shall be headed by a director appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The head of the department shall have the title of recycling director. 
(Code 1977, § 2-10; Ord. of 3-2-1965, § 2; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 10-31-1989, § 1; Ord. of 6-30-1992, § 1; Res. of 4-7-2015) 
Sec. 2-12. - Divisions. 
(a)	The community development division includes the functions of building inspections, code enforcement, flood plain management, licensing and permitting, and planning and zoning. This division shall be headed by the director of community development and shall be directly under the supervision of the department of administration. 
(b)	The human resources division has standard personnel and human resources responsibilities. This division shall be headed by the director of human resources and shall be directly under the supervision of the department of administration. 
Sec. 2-13. - Official bonds. 
    The mayor, councilmembers, city clerk, chief administrative officer, deputy city clerk and chief of police are required to execute bonds to the city in the following amounts: 
(1)	The mayor shall execute a bond in the sum of $100,000.00. 
(2)	The members of the city council shall execute bonds in the amount required by section MCA 1972, § 21-17-5. 
(3)	The city clerk shall execute a bond in the sum of $50,000.00. 
(4)	The chief administrative officer shall execute a bond in the sum of $50,000.00. 
(5)	The chief of police shall execute a bond in the sum of $50,000.00. 
(6)	All deputy clerks shall execute a bond in the sum of $10,000.00. 
(Code 1977, § 2-11; Ord. of 1-16-2015, § 1; Ord. of 8-16-2005, § 1) 
State Law reference- Required of officers and employees handling money, MCA 1972, § 21-5-9; minimum bonds for city clerk, manager, or chief administrative officer, MCA 1972, § 21-15-38; bond of deputy city clerk, MCA 1972, § 21-15-23; bond of employees and officers handling public bonds, MCA 1972, § 21-3-5. 
Secs. 2-14-2-31. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COUNCIL AND MAYOR 

Sec. 2-32. - Council meetings-Time and place. 
    The regular meetings of the council shall be on the first and third Tuesday of each month at 4:00 p.m., in the council chamber in the city hall or any place that may be selected by special resolution. All meetings shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1977, § 2-29; Ord. of 3-14-2005, § 8; Ord. of 7-6-1953, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 7-2-1985, § 1; Ord. of 7-30-1985, § 1; Ord. of 9-3-1985, § 1; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1; Ord. of 4-17-1990, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-1990, § 1; Ord. of 8-25-1992, § 1; Ord. of 7-3-2001, § 1) 
Sec. 2-33. - Same-Consideration of claims. 
    All demands, claims and accounts against the city shall be processed and approved by the city council according to the procedures set forth in section 21, chapter 39, of the Mississippi Code. 
(Code 1977, § 2-30; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1; Ord. of 3-14-2005, §§ 11, 13; Ord. of 8-16-2005, § 1) 
State Law reference- Docket of claims, MCA 1972, § 21-39-7. 
Sec. 2-34. - Same-Minutes to be read and approved, and signed. 
    The minutes of the city council shall be adopted and approved by a majority of the council at the next regular meeting or within 30 days thereof, whichever occurs first. Upon such approval, the minutes shall have the legal effect of being valid from and after the date of the meeting. 
(Code 1977, § 2-31; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1; Ord. of 3-14-2005, § 15; Ord. of 8-16-2005, § 1) 
Sec. 2-35. - Councilmember's salaries. 
    The salary paid to councilmembers of the city shall be as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-5; Ord. of 1-8-1971, § 1; Ord. of 5-11-1977, § 1; Ord. of 7-2-1985, § 1; Ord. of 12-20-1988, § 2; Ord. of 10-15-1996, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 2-6-2001, §§ 1, 2; Res. of 2-19-2013) 
Sec. 2-36. - Mayor's salary. 
    The salary paid to the mayor of the city shall be as established from time to time pursuant to law, in addition to the use and maintenance of an automobile to be used for city business. 
(Code 1977, § 2-4; Ord. of 1-8-1971, § 1; Ord. of 5-11-1977, § 1; Ord. of 7-2-1985, § 1; Ord. of 11-15-1988, § 2; Ord. of 10-15-1996, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 2-6-2001, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference- Fixing of salaries of mayor and councilmembers, MCA 1972, § 21-5-15; compensation of mayor and councilmembers, MCA 1972, § 21-9-61. 
Sec. 2-37. - Office hours of mayor. 
    The mayor shall devote full time to the performance of the duties as mayor of the city. The official office hours of service of the mayor in the city hall shall be from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. of each business day of the week, except Saturday. 
(Code 1977, § 2-6; Ord. of 1-3-1939, § 1) 
Secs. 2-38-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CLERK OF THE COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-51. - Appointment, qualifications and term. 
    There shall be a clerk of the council who shall be nominated annually by a member of the city council, with confirmation vote of a majority of council at its first meeting in July. Qualifications for appointment shall include current employment as a deputy city clerk or as the clerk for the city or five years experience as a municipal/deputy clerk with Mississippi Municipal Clerks and Tax Collectors Association Municipal/Deputy Clerk Certification. The clerk of the council shall hold office for a term of one year. 
(Code 1977, § 2-7; Ord. of 10-19-1989, § 1; Ord. of 7-7-2009, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 2-52. - Duties and compensation. 
(a)	Duties. The clerk of the council shall compile the minutes and records of its proceedings, its ordinances and resolutions, perform such duties as may be required by law and perform such duties as may be assigned by the president of the city council. 
(b)	Salary. For services rendered, the clerk of the council shall be paid as is established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-8; Ord. of 10-19-1989, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-2009, § 1; Ord. of 9-18-2012(5), § 1) 
Secs. 2-53-2-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-60. - City attorney-Appointment, qualifications and term. 
    There shall be a city attorney who shall be appointed annually by the mayor, with confirmation vote of a majority of council at its first meeting in July. The attorney shall be a practicing attorney residing in and having an office in the city. The city attorney shall hold office for a term of one year. 
(Code 1977, § 2-12; Ord. of 1-3-2005, § 1; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 10-31-1989, § 1) 
State Law reference- See MCA 1972, § 21-15-25. 
Sec. 2-61. - Same-Duties, compensation, and reimbursement of out-of-pocket expenses. 
(a)	Retainer duties. Attorneys are to attend all council meetings, give oral legal advice when called upon, to the mayor, council, and councilmembers and stand available for prompt oral consultation by the mayor or council in order that the legal matters of the city may be expeditiously handled. For these services, the attorneys shall be paid a retainer as established from time to time by the council. 
(b)	Statutory duties. Attorneys shall handle all bonds issuance and notes' issuance and shall receive the statutory fee of one per cent therefor. 
(c)	Other duties. Attorneys are to represent the city in all civil litigation, as well as administrative matters as directed by the mayor, and the council, for which duties the attorneys shall be paid at the rate established from time to time by the council. Attorneys are to give written legal advice; to write letters and prepare correspondence, papers, written documents and instruments, and memoranda; to confer with the mayor and city employees; be available for and confer with the mayor and council in person and by telephone; and maintain files on all legal matters pertaining to the city; for which duties the attorneys shall be paid at the rate established from time to time by the council. Attorneys are also authorized to contract with the city at rates established from time to time to provide special legal services to the city as required or allowed by community development block grants or other federal or state grants or programs. 
(d)	Out-of-pocket expenses. Both the city attorney and the assistant city attorney shall be reimbursed for all reasonable and necessary out-of-pocket expenses. 
(Code 1977, § 2-13; Ord. of 1-3-2005, § 52; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 7-15-1986, § 1; Ord. of 4-23-1996; Ord. of 1-15-2002; Ord. of 9-18-2012(1)) 
Sec. 2-62. - City attorney pro tem-Office created. 
    The office of city attorney pro tem is hereby created. 
(Code 1977, § 2-15; Ord. of 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 2-63. - Same-Appointment by council; duties; term. 
    In the absence of the city attorney, an attorney pro tem may be appointed who shall take the place of the city attorney in his or her absence and shall fulfill their duties and receive the compensation allowed the city attorney for services for such time. Said city attorney pro tem shall serve only during the absence of the city attorney. 
(Code 1977, § 2-16; Ord. of 4-7-2003; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1) 
Secs. 2-64-2-68. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COURT, JUDGES, PROSECUTING ATTORNEYS AND PUBLIC DEFENDER 

Sec. 2-69. - Municipal judge-Office created; qualifications; duties. 
    There is hereby created the office of municipal judge of the city who shall preside over the police court of the city. The judge shall be a qualified elector of the municipality and an attorney at law. The judge may hold court in the municipal courtroom every day except Sunday and legal holidays if the business requires it. 
(Code 1977, § 2-17; Ord. of 1-5-1931, § 1; Ord. of 7-15-1986, § 1) 
State Law reference- See MCA 1972, § 21-23-3 et seq. 
Sec. 2-70. - Same-Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal judge shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine all violations of the municipal ordinances and to punish offenders therefor as may be prescribed and shall have the powers in addition hereto now given by the statutes of the state to municipal judges in cities. 
(Code 1977, § 2-18; Ord. of 1-5-1931, § 3; Ord. of 7-15-1986, § 1) 
Sec. 2-71. - Same-Salary. 
    The salary of the municipal court judge shall be as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-19; Ord. of 1-5-1931, § 2; Ord. of 9-18-1959, § 1; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 7-15-1986, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-1990, § 1; Ord. of 11-8-1995; Ord. of 9-17-2002; Ord. of 8-15-2006; Ord. of 9-18-2012(2)) 
Sec. 2-72. - Ex officio deputy clerks of the police court. 
(a)	Pursuant to section MCA 1972, § 21-23-11, the city council does hereby appoint certain police officers of the city as ex officio deputy clerks. 
(b)	Those certain officers so appointed as ex officio clerks are hereby authorized to take affidavits charging any claim against the municipality or state, as are now allowed by law to officers performing like service. 
(Code 1977, § 2-19.1; Ord. of 12-19-1983, § 1) 
Sec. 2-73. - Municipal judges pro tempore; office created; qualifications; duties. 
(a)	There is hereby created the office of municipal judge pro tempore. 
(b)	The municipal judge pro tempore shall be appointed annually by the mayor, with confirmation vote of the majority of the council at its first meeting in July each year. The municipal judge pro tempore shall be a qualified elector of the municipality and an attorney-at-law. 
(c)	The municipal judge pro tempore shall perform all duties of the municipal judge in the absence of such municipal judge or if such municipal judge is unable to serve for any reason. 
(Code 1977, § 2-19.2; Ord. of 8-21-2000; Ord. of 8-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-74. - Prosecuting attorney-Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of city prosecuting attorney. 
(Code 1977, § 2-20; Ord. of 1-7-1947, § 1) 
State Law reference- See MCA 1972, § 21-23-3. 
Sec. 2-75. - Same-Qualifications; salary. 
    The city prosecuting attorney shall be an attorney at law, a qualified elector of the city and duly licensed to practice law in all the courts of the state. The prosecuting attorney shall be appointed by the mayor with confirmation vote of the majority of council at its first meeting in July each year and shall receive a salary as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-21; Ord. of 1-7-1947, § 2; Ord. of 6-4-1952, § 1; Ord. of 9-18-1959, § 1; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 11-8-1995; Ord. of 9-17-2002; Ord. of 11-21-2006; Ord. of 9-18-2012(3)) 
Sec. 2-76. - Same-Duties. 
    The city prosecuting attorney shall attend the regular sessions of the municipal court and shall prosecute all persons charged with violating the ordinances of the city. The prosecuting attorney shall advise the police justice, the chief of police, and all members of the police department in respect to their duties and to do all things ordinarily and generally required of prosecuting attorneys for counties in this state. The prosecuting attorney shall, in addition thereto, prosecute all appeals from the municipal court to the county court and such appellate courts as may be necessary to protect the interest of the municipality and properly to discharge duties as prosecuting attorney. 
(Code 1977, § 2-22; Ord. of 1-7-1947, § 3) 
Sec. 2-77. - Special prosecutor for code violations-Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of special prosecutor for code violations. 
(Code 1977, § 2-23; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-78. - Same-Qualifications; salary. 
    The special prosecutor for code violations shall be an attorney at law, a qualified elector of the city and duly licensed to practice law in all the courts of the state. He shall be appointed annually by the mayor with confirmation vote of the majority of the council at its first meeting in July each year, and shall receive a salary as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-24; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1; Ord. of 11-8-1995; Ord. of 9-17-2002) 
Sec. 2-79. - Same-Duties. 
    The special prosecutor for code violations shall attend all meetings of the planning commission. The special prosecutor shall advise the community development division and all city inspectors regarding the enforcement and interpretation of the applicable technical and building codes and any other laws, rules or regulations falling under the jurisdiction of the community development division. The special prosecutor shall represent the community development division and all city inspectors in matters of either prosecution or defense before the planning commission and before all courts. The special prosecutor shall have the authority and standing to object to any request for a zoning variance which is unlawful, would unduly disrupt the growth pattern or character of the neighborhood or which is not in the best interest of the city or the affected neighborhood. If any variance objected to is granted, the special prosecutor shall have the authority and standing to prosecute appeals before the city council and any court or courts of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1977, § 2-25; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-80. - City public defender; office created; qualifications; salary; duties. 
(a)	There is hereby created the office of city public defender. 
(b)	The city public defender shall be appointed annually by the mayor, with confirmation vote of the majority of the council at its first meeting in July each year. The city public defender shall be a practicing attorney maintaining and having an office in the city and a member of the state bar association. 
(c)	The city public defender shall attend all sessions of the municipal court and shall provide representation and the assistance of counsel at all critical stages in the proceedings to all indigent defendants requesting same as required by the Constitution of the United States. 
(d)	The city public defender shall receive a salary as is established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-26; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-1990, § 1; Ord. of 11-8-1995; Ord. of 8-21-2000; Ord. of 9-17-2002; Ord. of 9-18-2012(4)) 
Secs. 2-81-2-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES AND AUTHORITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-100-2-111. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOSPITAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-112. - Terms of city members; powers and duties. 
    The term of office of all members of the hospital commission appointed by the city to serve jointly with commissioners appointed by the board of supervisors of the county, who constitute the governing body of the Greenwood Leflore Hospital shall expire on June 1 each year, said members having staggered terms of two years. The commissioners shall perform all the duties and exercise all powers mentioned in MCA 1972, ch. 41-7 under the provisions of which this section is adopted. 
(Code 1977, § 2-46; Ord. of 5-6-1941, §§ 1, 2) 
Secs. 2-113-2-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GREENWOOD TOURISM COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-120. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a Greenwood Tourism Commission for the promotion of conventions and tourism. This commission shall function in an advisory capacity as part of the executive branch of city government. It shall study and advise the executive branch in the areas of promoting conventions and tourism. The commission shall also be empowered to carry out such other tasks as the mayor shall by executive order assign to it from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2-201; Ord. of 2-7-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-121. - Membership. 
    The commission shall have 14 members chosen as follows: 
(1)	One member from each of the seven wards in the city, nominated by the mayor and subject to the advice and consent of the city council; 
(2)	A member of the executive committee of the Greenwood-Leflore County Chamber of Commerce, who shall serve as an ex officio, nonvoting advisory member; 
(3)	A member of the board of the Museum of the Mississippi Delta, to be selected by that board, who shall serve as an ex officio, nonvoting advisory member; 
(4)	The chairman or a representative of the Greenwood-Leflore Industrial Board as appointed by its chairman; 
(5)	The director of the Leflore County Civic Center; 
(6)	A representative of the Greenwood Motel/Hotel Association, to be selected by that association; 
(7)	A representative of the Greenwood Restaurant Association, to be selected by that association; and 
(8)	A representative of Mississippi Valley State University, to be selected by its president. 
(Code 1977, § 2-202; Ord. of 2-7-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-122. - Terms of office. 
    The seven appointed members of the commission who represent the seven city wards shall each serve a one-year term of office beginning on such dates as the city council establishes. The members from the chamber of commerce, industrial board, civic center board and Museum of the Mississippi Delta shall serve so long as they hold their respective positions with the organization they represent. 
(Code 1977, § 2-203; Ord. of 2-7-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-123. - Legal representation. 
    The city attorney shall be the attorney for the commission. 
(Code 1977, § 2-204; Ord. of 2-7-1989, § 1) 
Secs. 2-124-2-129. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TREE BOARD 

Sec. 2-130. - Creation and establishment of a tree board. 
    There is hereby created and established a tree board for the city, which shall consist of seven tree-interested members who shall be appointed by the mayor with the confirmation of the city council. Each council member shall recommend for the mayor's consideration one person who may live anywhere within the city. 
Sec. 2-131. - Term of office. 
(a)	There shall be seven members appointed by mayor, with city council confirmation. 
(b)	The terms of members shall be three years or until successors are appointed. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(c)	Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation. 
Sec. 2-132. - Meetings. 
    Meetings of the tree board shall take place at city hall on the first Wednesday of the first month in each quarter (January, April, July, and October) at 5:00 p.m. 
Sec. 2-133. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, counsel, investigate and develop a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets, and in other public areas. This plan shall consist of recommended trees for planting, along with spacing and maintenance requirements. Such plan, upon approval by the mayor, shall be presented to the city council for approval and shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan. The board, when requested by the mayor, shall update the plan as needed and shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and make recommendations upon any special matter or question within the scope of this work. 
Sec. 2-134. - Operation. 
    The tree board shall annually choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations, and keep a record of its proceedings. The majority of its members present shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business so long as a minimum of four members are present. The board shall keep minutes, which shall be reported to the mayor and city council. 
Secs. 2-135-2-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Sec. 2-140. - Library board membership. 
    Three qualified electors of the city shall be appointed to represent the city on the board of trustees of the Greenwood Leflore Public Library System to serve with two members to be appointed by the county. The city members shall serve for a term of five years each. Said board of trustees shall be vested with all the rights, duties, powers and responsibilities as provided by MCA 1972, §§ 33-3-15 through 33-3-21, and all amendments thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 12-4; Ord. of 10-7-1949, § 4) 
Secs. 2-141, 2-142. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PARKS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-143. - Parks commission; creation, membership, appointment of members, function, terms of office, and compensation. 
    The council does hereby elect to come under the provisions of MCA 1972, § 21-37-33, and does hereby create a parks commission that shall consist of seven members. One member shall be appointed from each ward of the city by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. Members of the commission shall be parks commissioners of the city. The commission shall serve as an advisory board to the mayor on all matters concerning the management and control of all parks, playgrounds, and swimming pools maintained and established in the city. Parks commissioners shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and without compensation. 
(Code 1977, § 14-1; Ord. of 11-19-1965, § 1; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1) 
Secs. 2-144-2-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC RECORDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Mississippi Public Records Act of 1983, MCA 1972, § 25-61-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-147. - Authority and purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish the procedures the city will follow in order to provide full access to public records. These rules provide information to persons wishing to request access to public records of the city and establish processes for both requestors and city staff that are designed to best assist members of the public in obtaining such access. The purpose of the Mississippi Public Records Act is to provide the public full access to public records concerning the conduct of government. These rules will be interpreted in favor of disclosure. In carrying out its responsibilities under the Act, the city will be guided by the provisions of the Public Records Act describing its purposes and interpretation. 
Sec. 2-148. - Requests for records to public records officer. 
(a)	Any person wishing to request access to public records of the city, or seeking assistance in making such a request should contact the designated public records officer of the city. 
(b)	The public records officer will oversee compliance with the Public Records Act but another city staff member may process the request. Therefore, these rules will refer to the public records officer or designee. The public records officer or designee and the city will provide the fullest assistance to requestors; ensure that public records are protected from damage or disorganization; and prevent fulfilling public records requests from causing excessive interference with essential functions of the city. 
Sec. 2-149. - Availability of public records. 
(a)	Hours for inspection of records. Public records are available for inspection and copying during normal business hours of the city, excluding legal holidays. Records must be inspected at the administrative offices of the city. The time, place and manner of inspection and copying of records will not be allowed to interfere with other essential duties of the city staff. 
(b)	Records index. An index of public records may be available for use by members of the public. The index may be accessed online at the city website. 
(c)	Organization of records. The city will maintain its records in a reasonably organized manner. The city will take reasonable actions to protect records from damage and disorganization. A requestor shall not take city records from city offices. A variety of records may be available on the city website. Requestors are encouraged to view the documents available on the website prior to submitting a records request. 
(d)	Making a request for public records. 
(1)	Any person wishing to inspect or copy public records of the city should make the request in writing on the city's request form, or by letter, fax, or e-mail addressed to the public records officer and including the following information: 
a.	Name of requestor; 
b.	Address of requestor; 
c.	Other contact information, including telephone number and any email address; 
d.	Identification of the public records adequate for the public records officer designee to locate the records; and 
e.	The date and time of day of the request. 
(2)	If the requestor wishes to have copies of the records made instead of simply inspecting them, the requestor should so indicate and make arrangements to pay for copies of the records or make a deposit towards such payment. 
(3)	A form is available for use by requestors at the office of the public records officer and online at the city government website. 
(e)	Acceptance of public records request. The public records officer or designee may accept requests for public records that contain the above information by telephone or in person. If the public records officer or designee accepts such a request, the officer or designee will confirm receipt of the information and the substance of the request in writing. 
Sec. 2-150. - General processing of public records requests. 
(a)	Providing access. The city acknowledges that providing access to public records is a duty and that any person shall have the right to inspect, copy or mechanically reproduce or obtain a reproduction of any public record in accordance with these policies. The public records officer or designee will process requests in the order allowing the most requests to be processed in the most efficient manner. 
(b)	Acknowledging receipt of request. Within seven business days of receipt of the request, the public records officer will do one or more of the following: 
(1)	Make the records available for inspection or copying; 
(2)	If copies are requested and payment of a deposit for the copies, if any, is made or terms of payment are agreed upon, send the copies to the requestor; 
(3)	Provide a reasonable estimate of when records will be available; 
(4)	If the request is unclear or does not sufficiently identify the requested records, request clarification from the requestor. Such clarification may be requested and provided by telephone. The public records officer or designee may revise the estimate of when records will be available; or 
(5)	Deny the request. 
(c)	Consequences of failure to respond. If the city does not respond in writing within seven business days of receipt of the request for disclosure, the requestor should consider contacting the public records officer to determine the reason for the failure to respond. 
(d)	Protecting rights of others. In the event that the requested records contain information that may affect rights of others and may be exempt from disclosure, the public records officer may, prior to providing the records, give notice to such others whose rights may be affected by the disclosure. Such notice should be given so as to make it possible for those other persons to contact the requestor and ask him to revise the request, or, if necessary, seek an order from a court to prevent or limit the disclosure. The notice to the affected persons will include a copy of the request. 
(e)	Records exempt from disclosure. Some records are exempt from disclosure, in whole or in part. If the city believes that a record is exempt from disclosure and should be withheld, the public records officer will state the specific exemption and provide a brief explanation of why the record or a portion of the record is being withheld. If only a portion of a record is exempt from disclosure, but the remainder is not exempt, the public records officer will redact the exempt portions, provide the nonexempt portions, and indicate to the requestor why portions of the record are redacted. 
(f)	Inspection of records. 
(1)	Consistent with other demands, the city shall promptly provide space to inspect public records. No member of the public may remove a document from the viewing area or disassemble or alter any document. The requestor shall indicate which documents the requestor wishes the public body to copy. 
(2)	The requestor must claim or review the assembled records within 30 days of the city's notification to him that the records are available for inspection or copying. The public body will notify the requestor in writing of this requirement and inform the requestor to contact the public body to make arrangements to claim or review the records. If the requestor or a representative of the requestor fails to claim or review the records within the 30-day period or make other arrangements, the city may close the request and re-file the assembled records. Other public records requests can be processed ahead of a subsequent request by the same person for the same or almost identical records, which can be processed as a new request. 
(g)	Providing copies of records. After inspection is complete, the public records officer or designee shall make the requested copies or arrange for copying. 
(h)	Providing records in installments. When the request is for a large number of records, the public records officer or designee will provide access for inspection and copying in installments, if the officer or designee reasonably determines that it would be practical to provide the records in that way. If, within 30 days, the requestor fails to inspect the entire set of records or one or more of the installments, the public records officer or designee may stop searching for the remaining records and close the request. 
(i)	Completion of inspection. When the inspection of the requested records is complete and all requested copies are provided, the public records officer or designee will indicate that the city has completed a diligent search for the requested records and made any located nonexempt records available for inspection. 
(j)	Closing withdrawn or abandoned request. When the requestor either withdraws the request or fails to fulfill obligations to inspect the records or pay the deposit or final payment for the requested copies, the public records officer will close the request and indicate to the requestor that the city has closed the request. 
(k)	Later discovered documents. If, after the city has informed the requestor that it has provided all available records, the city becomes aware of additional responsive documents existing at the time of the request, it will promptly inform the requestor of the additional documents and provide them on an expedited basis. 
Editor's note- Requestors should be aware of the following exemptions, outside the Public Records Act, that restrict the availability of some documents held by city for inspection and copying: Academic records exempt from public access, MCA 1972, § 37-11-51; appraisal records exempt from access, MCA 1972, § 31-1-27; archaeological records exempt from public access, MCA 1972, § 39-7-41; attorney work product, examination, exemption, MCA 1972, § 25-1-102; Birth Defects Registry, MCA 1972, § 41-21-205; bureau of vital statistics, access to records, MCA 1972, § 41-57-2; charitable organizations, registration information, exemption from public access, MCA 1972, § 79-11-527; concealed pistols or revolvers, licenses to carry, records, exemption, MCA 1972, § 45-9-101; confidentiality, ambulatory surgical facilities, MCA 1972, § 41-75-19; defendants likely to flee or physically harm themselves or others, MCA 1972, § 41-32-7; environmental self-evaluation reports, Public Records Act, exemption, MCA 1972, § 49-2-71; hospital records, Mississippi Public Records Act exemption, MCA 1972, § 41-9-68; individual tax records in possession of public body, exemption from public access requirements, MCA 1972, § 27-3-77; insurance and insurance companies, risk based capital level requirements, reports, MCA 1972, § 83-5-415; judicial records, public access, exemption, MCA 1972, § 9-1-38; jury records exempt from public records provisions, MCA 1972, § 13-5-97; licensure application and examination records, exemption from Public Records Act, MCA 1972, § 73-52-1; medical examiner, records and reports, MCA 1972, § 41-61-63; personnel files exempt from examination, see MCA 1972, § 25-1-100; Public records and trade secrets, proprietary commercial and financial information, exemption from public access, MCA 1972, § 79-23-1; workers' compensation, access to records, MCA 1972, § 71-3-66; records subject to privilege, such as attorney/client, physician/patient, etc. 
Sec. 2-151. - Processing of public records requests; electronic records. 
(a)	Requesting electronic records. The process for requesting electronic public records is the same as for requesting paper public records. 
(b)	Providing electronic records. When a requestor requests records in an electronic format, the public records officer will provide the nonexempt records or portions of such records that are reasonably locatable in an electronic format that is used by the public body and is generally commercially available, or in a format that is reasonably translatable from the format in which the public body keeps the record. Costs for providing electronic records are as established from time to time. 
(c)	Customized access to data bases. With the consent of the requestor, the city may provide customized access if the record is not reasonably locatable or not reasonably translatable into the format requested. The city may charge the actual cost for such customized access. 
Sec. 2-152. - Third party information. 
(a)	When any person files or submits documents with the city which the filer contends are exempt from disclosure under the Public Records Act, the filer shall provide a written statement at the time of filing which shall describe the documents filed and which shall fully explain why the documents are designated as exempt from disclosure and must specifically cite any statute or other legal authority in support of such designation. Such written statement shall itself be a public record subject to disclosure. 
(b)	Any document filed with the city which contains trade secrets or confidential commercial or financial information subject to the protection of any applicable law or court decision shall be clearly designated as such by the filer on its face and accompanying cover letter at the time of filing and shall be placed in an envelope other than white. Each page of each document shall be marked confidential. Upon request to inspect or copy any document so designated, the city shall notify the person who filed the document. Thirty days after such notice, the document will be made available for public inspection or copying unless the filer shall have obtained a court order protecting such records as confidential pursuant to MCA 1972, § 25-61-9. 
(c)	Any person filing documents with the city shall, prior to filing, redact from the documents any social security numbers, account numbers or dates of birth not required to be listed. The city shall determine on a case-by-case basis whether similar information may be redacted by the filer to prevent identity theft. In no event will the city bear any responsibility for a filer's failure to redact such information which leads to or may lead to identity theft or other crime or loss. 
Sec. 2-153. - Costs of providing public records. 
(a)	Costs for paper copies. A requestor may obtain standard black and white photocopies, or color copies, at rates to be established from time to time. Copy charges for some specific types of records are set by statute and may exceed the amount stated above. Before beginning to make the copies, the requestor must prepay all reasonably estimated costs of copying all the records selected by the requestor. The public records officer or designee may also require the payment of the remainder of the copying costs before providing all the records in an installment before providing that installment. The city will not charge sales tax when it makes copies of public records. 
(b)	Costs for electronic records. The cost of electronic copies of records shall be as established from time to time for information on a CD-ROM. There will be no charge for emailing electronic records to a requestor, unless another cost applies such as a scanning fee or system costs allowed under MCA 1972, § 25-61-7(2). 
(c)	Costs of mailing. The city may also charge actual costs of mailing, including the cost of the shipping container. 
(d)	Payment. Payment may be made by cash, check, or money order payable to the City of Greenwood. 
(e)	Charges for searching, reviewing and redacting. The actual cost of searching for and reviewing and, if necessary, redacting exempt information from public records shall be based upon the hourly rate of compensation for the lowest paid agency employee qualified to perform the task, which shall be multiplied by the actual time to complete the task. 
(f)	Possible advance payment required. The city may require payment in advance for all costs before providing copies or access to records. 
Sec. 2-154. - Review of denials of public records. 
(a)	Petition for internal administrative review of denial of access. Any person who objects to the initial denial or partial denial of a records request may petition in writing, including email, to the public records officer for a review of that decision. The petition must include a copy of or reasonably identify the written statement by the public records officer or designee denying the request.
