(b)	Consideration of petition for review. The public records officer must promptly provide the petition and any other relevant information to their supervisor or other public body official designated by the public body to conduct the review. That person will immediately consider the petition and either affirm or reverse the denial within two business days following the city council's receipt of the petition, or within such other time as the city and the requestor mutually agree to. 
(c)	Review by the ethics commission. Pursuant to MCA 1972, § 25-61-13, if the city denies a requestor access to public records, the requestor may ask the ethics commission to review the matter. 
(d)	Judicial review. Any person whose request for public records was denied may institute a suit in the chancery court of the county, seeking to reverse the denial, as set forth in MCA 1972, § 25-61-13. 
Secs. 2-155-2-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL SEPARATE SCHOOL DISTRICT 

Sec. 2-161. - Described. 
    The entire municipal separate school district of the city shall constitute and be composed of the entire territory within the corporate limits of the city, and in addition thereto, the following adjacent annexed territory: 
(1)	Lot 13, Section 2. 
(2)	That part of Lot 8, Section 10, which lies north and east of the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)	The west1/2 of the northwest1/4 and that part of the south1/2 of Section 11 lying north and east of the corporate limits of the city. 
(4)	The southwest1/4 of the northwest1/4 and that part of the west1/2 of the southwest1/4 of Section 12 lying north of the corporate limits of the city. 
(5)	That part of Lots 11 and 12, Section 8 lying west of the corporate limits of the city. 
(6)	That part of the northeast1/4, Section 17, lying north of the Columbus and Greenville Railway right-of-way and west of the corporate limits of the city. 
(7)	A tract of land located in sections 1 and 12 described by metes and bounds as follows, to wit: Begin at the northeast corner of the southwest1/4 of the northwest1/4 of Section 12, Township 19 North, Range 1 East, Leflore County, Mississippi, and run thence south to a point on the centerline of Old Pelucia Bayou; run thence in a northeasterly direction and along the centerline of Old Pelucia Bayou and along the centerline of Birch Bayou to a point on the northern boundary line of Section 1 of said Township 19 North, Range 1 East; run thence west and along the northern boundary line of said Section 1 to a point on the western boundary line of the right-of-way of Highway No. 7; run thence in a southwesterly direction and along said western boundary line of the right-of-way of Highway No. 7 to a point where said right-of-way boundary is intersected by the northern boundary line of the Woodhaven Subdivision Part One; run thence in a westwardly direction and along said northern boundary line of the Woodhaven Subdivision Part One to a point at the northwest corner of said Woodhaven Subdivision Part One; run thence southwardly and along the western boundary line of said Woodhaven Subdivision to a point at the southwest corner of said Woodhaven Subdivision; run thence west and along the northern boundary line of the Second Chapman Subdivision to a point at the northwest corner of said Second Chapman Subdivision; run thence south and along the western boundary line of said Second Chapman Subdivision and along the western boundary line of the Chapman Subdivision to a point on the northern boundary line of east1/2 of the southwest1/4 of said Section 1; run thence west and along said northern boundary line of the east1/2 of the southwest1/4 of Section 1 to a point at the northwest corner of said east1/2 of the southwest1/4 of Section 1; run thence south and along the western boundary line of said east1/2 of the southwest1/4 of Section 1 to a point on the southern boundary line of said Section 1; run thence east and along said southern boundary line of Section 1, being also along the northern boundary line of said Section 12, to a point on the eastern boundary line of the right-of-way of said Highway No. 7; run thence southwardly and along said eastern boundary line of the right-of-way of Highway No. 7 to a point on the northern boundary line of said southwest1/4 of the northwest1/4 of said Section 12; run thence east and along said northern boundary line of the southwest1/4 of the northwest1/4 of Section 12 to the point of beginning. 
All the above-described land is located in Township 19 North, Range 1 East, in Leflore County, Mississippi. 
(Code 1977, § 2-27; Ord. of 12-20-1932, § 1, as amended; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 2-162. - Same-Assessment for taxation. 
    All the territory constituting the Greenwood Municipal Separate School District shall be assessed for taxation for separate school district purposes except such property as is required by law to be assessed by the state railroad assessor; and said roll shall be made by the clerk or tax collector by copying from the county assessment rolls that portion thereof which embraces property or persons within the limits of such adjacent annexed territory as described in section 2-30, which copy shall be made as required by the Code of Mississippi. 
(Code 1977, § 2-28; Ord. of 12-20-1932, § 2; Ord. of 7-3-1989, § 1) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 4-1. - Drinking or possessing open containers of alcoholic beverages in public place. 
    It shall be unlawful within the city for any person to drink or have in possession in opened containers any beer, whiskey and other alcoholic beverages except inside a building or on the premises of private dwelling houses and except as permitted under the ordinance relating to the possession, during certain events, in municipal parks. 
(Code 1977, § 13-2; Ord. of 9-1-1967, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-1990, § 1) 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, MCA 1972, § 67-1-1 et seq.; intoxicating beverages offenses, MCA 1972, §§ 97-31-1 et seq., 99-27-1 et seq. 
Sec. 4-2. - Selling or delivering alcoholic beverages in public place; hours prescribed. 
    Even in instances where it is otherwise lawful to sell or deliver wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages, it shall be unlawful to do so in the city during the hours from 6:00 p.m. until 7:00 a.m., except inside a building occupied by the person selling or delivering the same. 
(Code 1977, § 13-3; Ord. of 6-12-1964, § 1) 
Sec. 4-3. - Sale of beer and wine by establishments in proximity to place of worship restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any cafe, restaurant, lounge, or other business located within 350 feet of a church or other place of public worship between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. to sell or offer to sell for on-premises consumption on a Sunday beer or light wine. 
(Code 1977, § 13-3.1; Ord. of 11-9-1978, § 1) 
Sec. 4-4. - Possession, consumption, transportation or handling of alcoholic beverages on municipal property or in municipal buildings. 
(a)	Prohibited; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume, transport or handle any alcoholic beverage of any kind, including, but not limited to, whiskey, beer or wine, in or on any municipal property except as permitted by the provisions of this section. 
(b)	Definition. A definition of municipal property as used in this section includes, but is not necessarily limited to, municipally owned buildings, parks, parking lots, municipal school buildings and grounds, and any property leased or occupied by the city or its agencies or commissions. 
(c)	Permits. Permits may be granted authorizing the possession, consumption, transportation or handling of alcoholic beverages on municipal property to persons under the following conditions: 
(1)	A written request shall be submitted to the chief of police of the city by any person, group, club, or association stating the date, time, location and approximate number of persons involved. The request shall be submitted at least 30 days in advance of the event. 
(2)	In the event the municipal property is under the control of and/or is being used by an agency or commission of the city, a copy of the request shall also be served on the director of said agency or commission and the director shall have ten days within which to notify the chief of police of any conflict with regard to use of the proposed site or to make known any objections to the issuance of the permit. 
(3)	The chief of police, after conducting an investigation, shall deny or grant the permit. 
(4)	Any person, group, club or association whose permit application is denied may appeal the denial to the city council of the city within ten days of the date of the denial by filing a written request for review with the city clerk of the city. 
(d)	Prohibited in all city parks; exception. Except for major events an object of which is at least in substantial part to promote tourism and which is open to the public generally, no permit shall be granted authorizing the possession, consumption, transportation or handling of alcoholic beverages in or on a municipal park. 
(e)	Penalty. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section or who fails to comply therewith shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(f)	Provisions deemed supplemental. The provisions of this section shall be deemed to be supplemental to any and all acts and laws of the state pertaining to the governance of sales and distribution of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1977, § 13-3.2; Ord. of 11-5-1982, §§ 1-5; Ord. of 6-17-1986, § 1; Ord. of 4-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 4-5. - Certain acts by permittees of beer and light wine permits prohibited. 
    In addition to any act declared to be unlawful by any other ordinance heretofore adopted by the city, it shall be unlawful for the holder of a permit authorizing the sale of beer and wine: 
(1)	To sell or give to be consumed in or upon any licensed premises any beer or light wine between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. each day; 
(2)	To sell, give or furnish any beer or wine to any person visibly or noticeably intoxicated, or to any insane person, or to any habitual drunkard, or to any person under the age of 21 years; 
(3)	To suffer or permit: 
a.	Any female person, while on the premises of said commercial establishment, to expose to the public view that area of the human female breast at or below the top of the areola thereof; 
b.	Any female person, while on the premises of said commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such portions of the human female breast as described in subsection (3)a of this section; 
c.	Any person, while on the premises of said commercial establishment, to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, anal cleft or cleavage; 
d.	Any person, while on the premises of said commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, anal cleft, or cleavage; 
(4)	To permit loud, boisterous or disorderly conduct of any kind upon the premises or to permit the use of loud musical instruments if either or any of the same may disturb the peace and quietude of the community wherein such business is located; 
(5)	To permit persons of ill repute, known criminals, prostitutes or minors to frequent the licensed premises, except minors accompanied by parents or guardians or under proper supervision; 
(6)	To permit or suffer gambling or the operation of games of chance upon the licensed premises; and/or 
(7)	To receive, possess or sell on licensed premises any beverage of any kind or character containing more than four percent alcohol by weight unless the licensee also possesses an on-premises permit under the local option alcoholic beverage control law. 
(Code 1977, § 13-3.3; Ord. of 6-14-1988, § 3; Ord. of 2-15-2000, § 1) 
Sec. 4-6. - Certain acts prohibited upon the premises of a commercial establishment which holds a permit authorizing the sale of beer and wine. 
    It shall be unlawful, while on the premises of a commercial establishment located within the boundaries of the city at which alcoholic beverages, beer or wine are offered for sale for consumption on the premises: 
(1)	For any female person to expose to public view that area of the human female breast at or below the top of the areola thereof, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance or simulate such areas of the female breast as described herein. 
(2)	For any person to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft or cleavage, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(Code 1977, § 13-3.4; Ord. of 2-15-2000, § 2) 
Sec. 4-7. - Establishment of closing time for the holder of a permit authorizing the sale of beer, light wine or other alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any night club, bar or similar business engaged in the sell of light wine or beer or other alcoholic beverages for the consumption upon its premises, to conduct business and otherwise remain open to the general public between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day of the week. 
(b)	Nothing in this provision shall be construed to infringe, restrict or deny the rights of the holder of a permit which has been approved as a qualified resort area by the division of alcohol beverage control of the state tax commission. 
(Code 1977, § 13-30.3; Ord. of 6-17-2008) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority, MCA 1972, § 21-19-9. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this chapter, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Feral dog or feral cat. Any dog or cat that has escaped from domestication and become wild, dangerous, or untamed. 
    Nuisance. A dog or cat shall be considered a nuisance if it: damages, soils, defiles, or defecates on private property other than the owner's or on public walks and recreation areas unless such waste is immediately removed and properly disposed of by the owner; causes unsanitary, dangerous, or offensive conditions; causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noise-making; or chases vehicles, or molests, prepares to attack, attempts to attack, or, in fact, attacks or interferes with persons or other domestic animals on public property and in the case of a person upon any private property where the person either owns the property or has been invited by the owner to be on the property. 
    Vicious animal. Any animal that constitutes a physical threat to humans or other domestic animals. 
    Wild animal. Any undomesticated animal including, but not limited to: lions, tigers, bears, wolves, apes, monkeys, (all nonhuman primates), foxes, coyotes, skunks, raccoons, opossums, or any other warm-blooded animal which can normally be found in a wild state and is not ordinarily domesticated by man, whether raised in captivity or in the wild. 
(Code 1977, § 4-31; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Bird sanctuary. 
(a)	The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, hunt, shoot, attempt to shoot, or to molest in any manner any bird or to rob bird nests or otherwise destroy the same; provided, however, that if starlings, blackbirds or similar birds or fowl are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property, then the same may be lawfully destroyed. The council or any other qualified authority designated by law to declare a public nuisance may, after being so informed, take appropriate action through duly constituted officials to abate such a nuisance. Any person desiring to destroy such birds may make application to the chief of police and trapping and killing of the same shall not be resorted to, if the nuisance can be abated in any more humane manner by methods approved by the Audubon Society, bird clubs, garden clubs or the humane society. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1; Ord. of 9-14-1956, § 2) 
Sec. 6-3. - Cruelty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to override, overdrive, overload, torture, torment, unjustifiably injure, deprive of necessary sustenance or drink, or cruelly beat or needlessly mutilate, or cause or procure to be overridden, overdriven, overloaded, tortured, unjustifiably injured, tormented or deprived of necessary sustenance or drink, or to be cruelly beaten or needlessly mutilated or killed, any living creature. 
(Code 1977, § 4-2; Ord. of 3-14-2005; Ord. of 4-11-2005) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCA 1972, § 97-41-1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-4. - Vaccination of dogs and cats required. 
(a)	Every person who owns or has in possession any dog or cat of the age of three months or over shall have the dog or cat inoculated (vaccinated) against rabies as required by the provisions of MCA 1972, § 41-53-1 et seq., as amended, and for all dogs to be tagged as required by the provisions of MCA 1972, § 41-53-7. 
(b)	The failure or refusal of any person to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this chapter and the offender shall, on conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 4-10; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
State Law reference- General requirement concerning rabies inoculations, MCA 1972, § 41-53-41 et seq. 
Sec. 6-5. - Dogs and cats running at large. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to cause or allow the same to run at large in the corporate limits of the city and no person shall own, harbor or keep any dog within the corporate limits of the city, except in compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)	Must be securely restrained at all times and tied to or be on a leash; 
(2)	Must be kept within a pen or suitable enclosure from which they are unable to escape; 
(3)	Must be kept within the confines of a structure or building from which they are unable to escape. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for the owner or possessor of any unneutered male cat or unspayed female cat to allow such cat to roam at large within the corporate limits of the city, and no person shall own, harbor or keep any unneutered or unspayed cat within the corporate limits of the city unless such animal is kept in a pen or suitable enclosure, structure or building from which they are unable to escape. 
(Code 1977, § 4-10.1; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to control animals running at large, MCA 1972, § 21-19-9. 
Sec. 6-6. - Impoundment of dogs running loose, animals causing a nuisance or vicious or feral animals. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of the animal control officer of the city, acting by and through the police department, to pick up any dog found running loose or any dog or cat reported by a resident to be causing a nuisance in that resident's yard, on school grounds, or in city parks, and to impound the same in an enclosure kept for that purpose by the city or its agent for five days, unless claimed sooner by the owner. If an animal thought to be a stray is determined by the city or its agent to be too sick or in too injured a condition whereby confinement for the five-day period would constitute cruel and inhumane treatment, humane euthanasia will be administered to the animal. 
(b)	When an animal is determined by the animal control officer or shelter manager to be vicious or feral, that animal may be humanely destroyed without the designated five-day holding period, provided the animal has been running at large with no vaccination tag around its neck. 
(c)	Within five days, the rightful owner of any dog or cat held at the animal shelter may obtain the animal upon payment of a charge to the city in the amount of the greater of $25.00 per day or the actual cost to the city of caring for the animal while impounded, plus a one-time administration fee of $75.00 per animal, provided the animal has been vaccinated and tagged as set forth in section 6-5 prior to said release. 
(d)	If an impounded animal is not claimed within the five-day period, such animal shall become the property of the city or its agent. 
(Code 1977, § 4-11; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 2; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 3; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-7. - Custody, care and control of animals. 
    The custody, care and control of an animal within the corporate limits of the city by a person shall be prima facie evidence that said person is the owner of the animal. 
(Code 1977, § 4-12; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 3; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 4; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-8. - Impoundment of animals running at large; declared nuisance. 
(a)	Animals found running at large are hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be taken by the animal control officer of the city and placed in the animal shelter and may be pursued and captured on any public or private property within the city limits of the city. 
(b)	The animal control authority is authorized to employ any equipment it deems necessary to enforce the provisions of this section, including, without limitation, humane wire box traps; and the animal control authority may, subject to conditions it may determine, lend such traps or other equipment to private persons for the purpose of preventing nuisances resulting from animals at large. 
(Code 1977, § 4-13; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 4; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 5; Ord. of 1-20-1986, § 1; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-9. - Impoundment of attacking animals. 
    In case of an attack by an animal resulting in injury to any person, such animal may be impounded by the animal control officer for observation for the period of ten days, costs for said impoundment to be paid by owner to the city in the amount of the greater of $25.00 per day or the actual cost to the city of caring for the animals while impounded, plus a one-time administrative fee of $75.00 per animal, or the owner thereof may, upon notification to the aforesaid animal control officer, have such animal impounded for ten days with a private veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine within the state. If, at the end of such period of time, it is determined that said animal has rabies, such animal shall be immediately destroyed. If, at the end of such period of time, the animal is determined to be free of rabies, it may be returned to its rightful owner upon payment of the aforesaid impoundment costs. If the animal is not claimed by its rightful owner at the end of the designated time, it then becomes the property of the city or its agent and may, at their discretion, be humanely euthanized or adopted by a new owner. 
(Code 1977, § 4-14; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 5; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 5; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1; Ord. of 5-16-2003) 
Sec. 6-10. - Sanitary condition of dog pens and premises; dogs creating nuisance. 
    The owners or harborers of all dogs within the city are hereby required to keep the same within suitable and adequate enclosures as protection from the elements, and are further required to keep said enclosures sanitary and clean so as to prevent disagreeable odors arising therefrom, or the presence of breeding of flies, mosquitoes, and other pests. It shall be unlawful for the owner or harborer of any dog or dogs to permit the same to create a disturbance in the neighborhood or annoy any person or family or become a nuisance in any manner, particularly by reason of noises, odors, filthy conditions or the breeding of flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(Code 1977, § 4-15; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 6; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 7) 
Sec. 6-11. - Cruelty to dogs, cats. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to torture, torment, unjustifiably injure, deprive of necessary sustenance, food, drink or adequate shelter; or cruelly beat or needlessly mutilate any dog or cat within the corporate limits of the city or to cause or permit the same to be done. 
(Code 1977, § 4-16; Ord. of 12-21-1977, § 7; Ord. of 12-20-1979, § 8) 
Sec. 6-12. - Keeping of vicious, ferocious, or dangerous animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain within the city, any vicious, ferocious, or dangerous animal or fowl. Any such animal or fowl may be impounded or destroyed by police or animal control personnel. 
(Code 1977, § 4-20; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-13. - Keeping of wild animals or reptiles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or permit to be kept on the person's premises any wild animal or reptile either as a pet or for display or exhibition purposes. This section shall not be construed to apply to zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, or circuses. The animal control officer shall have the power to release, order the release, or seize any wild animal being kept in violation of this section, federal law, or state statute. 
(Code 1977, § 4-21; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-14. - Abandonment of animals prohibited. 
    No owner of an animal shall abandon it. 
(Code 1977, § 4-22; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-15. - Giving away of animals as prizes prohibited. 
    No person shall give away any live animal, fish, reptile, or bird as a prize for, or as an inducement to enter, any contest, game, or other competition, or as an inducement to enter a place of amusement; or offer such vertebrate as an incentive to enter any business agreement whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade. 
(Code 1977, § 4-23; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-16. - Selling of chickens or ducklings in quantities of less than ten prohibited. 
    Chickens or ducklings younger than eight weeks of age may not be sold in quantities of less than ten to a single purchaser, nor shall any such animals be dyed. 
(Code 1977, § 4-24; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-17. - Exposing of poisonous substances liable to be eaten by animals prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same shall be liable to be eaten by any animal; provided that it shall not be unlawful for a person to expose on said person's own property common pest-control poison mixed with vegetable matter. 
(Code 1977, § 4-25; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-18. - Leaving an unattended animal inside a motor vehicle prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave an animal unattended inside a motor vehicle when such an action is reasonably potentially harmful to said animal. In the event the owner of said vehicle is not available and cannot be found or refuses to prevent said harm or reasonably potential harm from continuing, the animal control officer or any officer of the Greenwood Police Department shall be authorized to remove said animal from such vehicle and to utilize any reasonable method to effect such removal. 
(Code 1977, § 4-26; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-19. - Limits on the keeping of domesticated animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor more than four outdoor domesticated animals of the same species, over the age of three months, in any residential area within the corporate limits of the city. Exceptions: 
(1)	The limit shall be six cats if all six have been neutered; 
(2)	There shall be no limitation with regard to cats or rabbits kept in pens on the owner's property, provided that shelter and sanitation regulations are complied with. 
This restriction shall, likewise, not apply to cats or dogs kept exclusively within the residence of their owner. 
(Code 1977, § 4-27; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-20. - Use of steel-jaw leg-traps prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, set, or permit to be set on the property any steel-jaw leg-hold trap within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 4-28; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 6-21. - Keeping of certain animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep within the corporate limits of the city a cow, mule, horse, cattle, swine, sheep, goats, or fowl, such as chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese, pigeons, or guineas. 
(Code 1977, § 4-29; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-22. - Interference with animal control officer and others enforcing animal control laws prohibited. 
    No person shall interfere with, hinder, or molest any animal control officer in the performance of any duty as herein provided in this chapter. It shall likewise be unlawful to interfere with, hinder, or molest the animal control officer when the officer is engaged in the enforcement or attempted enforcement of any ordinance contained in this chapter or any state statute dealing with the same or a related subject matter as this chapter. It shall be likewise unlawful to interfere with, hinder, or molest any other person acting under color of law and enforcing or attempting to enforce the ordinances contained within this chapter or any state statute dealing with the same or a related subject matter as this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 4-30; Ord. of 1-20-1987, § 1; Ord. of 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-23. - Pit bull control. 
(a)	Findings. 
(1)	The city has experienced a series of incidents in which citizens and animals have been threatened or attacked and injured by pit bull dogs. 
(2)	The pit bull breed was developed for the purpose of producing fighting dogs. 
(3)	To increase its effectiveness as a fighter, certain pit bull traits have been selected and maximized by controlled breeding, including: 
a.	A set of powerful jaws with an exceptional ability to grip, lock and tear when dog bites; 
b.	A unique insensitivity to pain that causes pit bulls to be exceedingly tenacious in attack; 
c.	An unusually aggressive temperament toward human beings and animals; and 
d.	An extraordinary directness in their method of attack that does not include the common warning signs such as barking or growling as displayed by other breeds. 
(4)	For the reasons provided in this section, pit bull dogs present a present danger to the health and welfare of the citizens and animals in the city different in degree and kind from the dangers presented by other breeds of dogs. 
(b)	Regulations. 
(1)	Generally. This chapter is intended to utilize the authority and powers of the city in order to secure for the citizens of the city the protection of their health, safety and welfare. This chapter is intended to be applicable to dogs which are commonly referred to as "pit bulls" and which are defined herein. This chapter is designed to regulate these pit bull dogs and to ensure responsible handling by their owners through confinement and registration. The unique history, nature and characteristics of pit bull dogs have been determined to require the special regulations and provisions contained within this section which the city council hereby finds reasonable and necessary. 
(2)	Definition; identification of a pit bull dog. The term "pit bull" dog, as used within this chapter, shall refer to any dog which exhibits those distinguishing characteristics which substantially conform to the standards established by the American Kennel Club for American Staffordshire Terriers or Staffordshire Bull Terriers, or which substantially conform to the standards established by the United Kennel Club for American Pit Bull Terriers. Technical deficiencies in dog's conformance to the standards described herein shall not be considered to indicate that the subject dog is not a pit bull dog pursuant to this section. Testimony by a veterinarian or an animal behaviorist that a particular dog exhibits distinguishing physical characteristics of a pit bull establish a rebuttable presumption that the dog is a pit bull. 
(3)	Confinement of pit bull dogs. 
a.	Because of the pit bull dog's inbred propensity to attack other animals, and because of the danger posed to humans and animals alike by a pit bull dog when running loose or while running together in a pack, pit bull dogs must at all times be securely confined indoors, confined in a securely and totally enclosed and locked pen, constructed with cyclone type fencing material of at least nine gauge wire in thickness; with all four sides to be at least six feet in height; with concrete slab foundation at least four inches in thickness; and a secured cyclone fence top; such enclosure shall likewise have a conspicuous sign affixed thereto displaying the words "Dangerous Dog." 
b.	At any time that a pit bull dog is not confined as required in subsection (a) of this section, the dog shall be muzzled in such a manner as to prevent it from biting or injuring any person or animal, and kept on a leash with the owner or custodian in attendance; provided, however, that no pit bull dog may be walked within 50 feet of any public school ground, public park or church when in session nor enter onto such school ground, park or church when in session. 
c.	An exception to these confinement requirements is hereby provided for any pit bull dog in attendance at, and participating in, any lawful dog show, contest or exhibition sponsored by a dog club, association, society or similar organization. 
(4)	Registration of pit bull dogs. Every owner of a pit bull within the city shall register said dog with the Humane Society of Leflore County. The registration shall include the following: Name, address and telephone number of the dog's owner; the address where the dog is harbored, if different from that of the owner; a complete identification of the dog, including the dog's sex, color and other distinguishing physical characteristics; a color photograph of the dog, and a description of the method of compliance with the confinement requirements. The registration tag shall be worn on the dog's collar at all times. Certification of rabies vaccination shall be presented upon registration. 
(5)	Owner age requirement. Owners, keepers, or harborers of pit bulls dogs or the like must be 21 years of age. A person must be 21 years of age to walk a pit bull dog or the like on a leash. 
(6)	Limits of confinement. No more than three pit bull dogs or the like shall be confined at any single dwelling in the city. 
(7)	Altering of pit bull dogs. All pit bull dogs shall be neutered or spayed, and the appropriate certification shall be provided to the Humane Society of Leflore County upon registration. 
(8)	Liability insurance. Owners of pit bull dogs or the like shall maintain a liability insurance policy in an amount not less than $100,000.00, for bodily injury or property damages arising from events or occurrences associated with owning, keeping, or harboring pit bull dogs or the like. In lieu of a liability insurance policy, owners of pit bull dogs may post a cash bond in the amount of $100,000.00 with a reputable bonding company to be approved by the city and licensed to do business in the state. 
a.	Any liability insurance policy or cash bond purchased in compliance with this section must be placed on file with the city clerk's office. 
b.	No other form of insurance or personal surety is acceptable and is considered not to be in compliance with the provisions and requirements of this section. 
(9)	Enforcement. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the city animal control officer and the police department to enforce the provisions of this section. Owners, keepers, or harborers of pit bull dogs or the like, may be subjected to spot checks by local law enforcement and must be able to produce registration, proof of liability insurance, and show confinement to the satisfaction of this section. 
(10)	Schedule of penalties. Violation of this section shall be punished as follows: First offense: A fine of not less than $100.00; nor more than $299.00; Second offense: A fine of not less than $300.00 nor more than $500.00; Third and subsequent offenses: A fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $999.00, and permanent relinquishment of all pit bull dogs or the like by the owner, keeper, or harborer. Enforcement of penalties for violation of this section shall be within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(11)	Other regulations. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the city from providing more stringent regulation of pit bull dog owners, or of other types of animals deemed to be a threat to the safety and welfare of the community. 
(Code 1977, § 4-44; Ord. of 8-19-2008, §§ I, II) 
Secs. 6-24-6-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BEEKEEPING 

Sec. 6-70. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide standards for the keeping of bees. It is intended to enable persons to keep an appropriate number of bees while limiting the potential adverse impacts on the surrounding neighborhood. The city recognizes that adverse neighborhood impacts, including, but not limited to, swarming, stinging and the spread of disease, may result from the keeping of bees if appropriate and responsible beekeeping practices are not followed. This article is intended to create licensing standards and requirements that ensure that bees kept by persons do not adversely impact the use and enjoyment of neighborhood properties surrounding the property on which the bees are kept. 
Sec. 6-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apiary means a place where bee colonies are kept. 
    Bee means any stage of the common domestic honey bee, apis mellifera species. 
    Beekeeper means a person who owns or has charge of one or more colonies of bees. 
    Beekeeping equipment means anything used in the operation of an apiary, including, but not limited to, hive bodies, supers, frames, top and bottom boards, and extractors. 
    Colony means a hive and its equipment and appurtenances, including bees, comb, honey, pollen, and brood. 
    Hive means the structure intended for the housing of a bee colony. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, governmental entity, association, or public or private organization of any character. 
Sec. 6-72. - Certain conduct prohibited. 
    Notwithstanding compliance with the provisions of this article, it shall be a violation of this article for any beekeeper to keep a colony or colonies in a manner that threatens the public health, safety, and welfare of the community. 
Sec. 6-73. - Permit required. 
(a)	An annual permit is required for the keeping of bees in the city. 
(b)	Every applicant for a permit to keep an apiary shall: 
(1)	Complete and file an application on a form prescribed by the community development division. The application shall be accompanied by a plot plan that includes the size of the lot, the location and number of hives, the distance of the hives from the property boundary lines and, if required, the location of any flyway barriers. 
(2)	Deposit the prescribed permit fee with the city clerk at the time the application is filed. 
(c)	The code enforcement officer shall issue a permit if the applicant has shown right, title, or interest in the property where the apiary is proposed to be sited and has demonstrated compliance with the criteria and standards in this article. Written permission of the property owner to allow the applicant's maintenance of bee colonies on the property may serve as evidence of the applicant's right, title, or interest in the property. Any permit issued by the code enforcement officer only authorizes the keeping of bee colonies at the property and in the location on the property approved by the code enforcement officer. The relocation of any bee colonies to another property within the city or the change of colony locations within a property requires the prior approval of the code enforcement officer. 
Sec. 6-74. - Fees. 
    The fee for an annual permit to keep bees is, unless as otherwise established from time to time, $25.00 per beekeeper. 
Sec. 6-75. - Hives on residential lots. 
(a)	As provided in this article, an apiary may be maintained in a side yard or the rear yard of any single-family residential lot. The keeping of bees shall not be allowed on property zoned multifamily residential, commercial, industrial, or mixed use. 
(b)	A person shall not locate or allow a hive on property owned or occupied by another person without first obtaining written permission from the owner or occupant. 
Sec. 6-76. - Colony densities. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep more than following number of colonies on any tract within the city, based upon the size or configuration of the tract on which the apiary is situated: 
Size of tract Colonies permitted 1/4 acre or less 2 colonies More than 1/4 acre to 1/2 acre 4 colonies More than 1/2 acre to 1 acre 6 colonies More than 1 acre 8 colonies  
Sec. 6-77. - Hives. 
(a)	Honeybee colonies shall be kept in hives with removable frames which shall be kept in sound and usable condition. 
(b)	Hives shall be placed at least five feet from any property line and six inches above the ground, as measured from the ground to the lowest portion of the hive; provided, however, that this requirement may be waived in writing by the adjoining property owner. 
(c)	Each hive shall be conspicuously marked with the owner's name, address, and telephone number. 
Sec. 6-78. - Flyways. 
    If any colony is situated within 25 feet of a public or private property line of the tract upon which the apiary is situated, as measured from the nearest point on the hive to the property line, the beekeeper shall establish and maintain a flyway barrier at least six feet in height consisting of a solid wall, fence, dense vegetation or combination thereof that is parallel to the property line and extends ten feet beyond the colony in each direction so that all bees are forced to fly at an elevation of at least six feet above ground level over the property lines in the vicinity of the apiary. This barrier shall be in place prior to placing a colony within 25 feet of a public or private property line and prior to the approval of the annual permit to keep an apiary. It shall be a defense to enforcement under this article that the property abutting the apiary tract is undeveloped property. 
Sec. 6-79. - Water. 
    Each beekeeper shall ensure that a convenient source of water is available to the colony at all times during the year. The water shall be in a location that minimizes any nuisance created by bees seeking water on neighboring property. 
Sec. 6-80. - Beekeeping equipment. 
    Each beekeeper shall ensure that no bee comb or other beekeeping equipment is left upon the grounds of an apiary site. Upon removal from a hive, all such equipment shall promptly be disposed of in a sealed container or placed within a building or other bee-proof enclosure. 
Sec. 6-81. - Transportation of hives. 
    Beekeepers shall take appropriate care when transporting hives of bees. All loads of hives and supers of honey shall be properly secured. Bees being transported shall have entrance screens or be secured under netting. 
Sec. 6-82. - Right to inspect. 
(a)	The code enforcement officer, health inspector, health officer, animal control officer, and/or the state bee inspector shall have the right to inspect any apiary site. Where practicable, prior notice shall be given to the beekeeper. 
(b)	The code enforcement officer, health inspector, health officer, or animal control officer may seek the advice and assistance of any available master beekeeper in the administration and enforcement of this article. 
(c)	Permit holders will be responsible for all fees associated with any or all enforcement actions associated with non-compliance with this article. 
Sec. 6-83. - Denial, suspension, or revocation of permit. 
(a)	The code enforcement officer shall deny a permit if the applicant has not demonstrated compliance with all provisions of this article. 
(b)	A permit to keep bees may be suspended or revoked by the code enforcement officer where there is a risk to public health or safety or for any violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article or with the provisions of any other applicable ordinance or law. 
(c)	Any material misstatement or omission shall be grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of the permit. 
(d)	Any denial, revocation, or suspension of a permit shall be in writing and shall include notification of the right to and procedure for appeal. 
Sec. 6-84. - Appeal. 
    A person appealing the issuance, denial, suspension, or revocation of a permit by the code enforcement officer may appeal to the planning commission within 30 days of the decision being appealed. 
Sec. 6-85. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any other enforcement action which the city may take, violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4. Each day that a violation continues will be treated as a separate offense.

Sec. 8-1. - Fire limits.

(Code 1977, § 5-1)

ARTICLE II. - CODES AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 8-20. - Codes adopted by reference. 
(a)	The following codes are hereby adopted by reference as though they were fully copied herein in words and figures: 
International Building Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Residential Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Fuel/Gas Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Fire Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition. 
National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition. 
(b)	Modifications, additions, and deletions. The 2012 edition of the International Residential Code (IRC) shall be adopted in its entirety with the following modifications: 
(1)	Addition of the authorization of the 2009 IRC N1102.4.2.2 option for a visual inspection. 
(2)	Deletion of R313.2, which requires automatic residential fire sprinkler systems to be installed in one- and two-family dwellings. 
(Code 1977, § 5-6; Ord. of 6-9-1987, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-1996, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 10-1-1997, §§ 1, 2; Res. of 2-16-1999, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 7-18-2000, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 2-5-2002, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 1-18-2005, §§ 1, 2; Res. of 6-18-2013(2), § 5-6; Ord. of 5-20-2014, § 5-6) 
Sec. 8-21. - All revisions, amendments, recompilations or new editions automatically adopted. 
    With regard to all the technical codes, as well as the National Electrical Code, adopted by reference in section 8-20, all future revisions, amendments, recompilations or new editions shall be adopted by the city council, after review and recommendation by the building official. 
(Code 1977, § 5-7; Ord. of 6-9-1987, § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013(2), § 5-7) 
Sec. 8-22. - Housing code violations to be remedied within 30 days. 
    There shall be allowed 30 days for the remedying of all violations of the technical codes adopted in section 8-20, as revised or amended. 
(Res. of 6-18-2013(2), § 5-8) 
Sec. 8-23. - Codes; remedies and penalties cumulative. 
    In addition to any penalties set out in the codes adopted in section 8-20: 
(1)	Any violation of the technical codes by any person, firm, corporation or agent shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4. Each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of the standard codes is committed or continued shall be a separate offense. 
(2)	If the owner of the property has not remedied the violation or violations within the 30 days as provided in section 8-22, the city may, itself, remedy the violation or violations at the owner's expense. Such expense shall be the obligation of the owner to pay and shall also be a lien against the property. 
(3)	All remedies contained within the standard codes themselves or within this section shall be cumulative. Pursuit of any one remedy shall not prohibit the city from pursuing any other remedy or remedies provided for. 
(Code 1977, § 5-9; Ord. of 6-9-1987, § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013, § 5-9) 
Sec. 8-24. - Electrical inspection and approval after service disconnection. 
    Except in the case of a disconnection for nonpayment of bills where payment is made and reconnection occurs within 30 days after disconnection, an installation of electrical wiring on which service has been discontinued shall not be reconnected for service until after an inspection by the electrical inspector has been made, for which the inspection charges shall be made, and any of the following life or fire hazards that may be found therein have been eliminated: 
(1)	Wiring or appliances without proper automatic overload protection. 
(2)	Overloaded circuit, feeder or service wires. 
(3)	Single conductors not properly supported and separated. 
(4)	Wires in contact with wood or other foreign objects. 
(5)	Exposed current-carrying metal parts of wires or equipment exposed to accidental contact by persons or foreign objects. 
(6)	Flexible cords with deteriorated and defective insulation. 
(7)	Non-current-carrying metal equipment of electrical wiring exposed to contact by persons who in turn may be in contact with plumbing or heating equipment or other metal in contact with the earth, or while standing on the earth or on a conductive floor, unless such non-current-carrying metal equipment is effectively and properly grounded. 
(8)	Broken socket, receptacle, switch, fuse-holder or other device or appliance. 
The electrical inspector shall make inspections for reconnection promptly after application has been filed. 
(Code 1977, § 5-10; Ord. of 7-20-1948, § 14; Ord. of 6-9-1987, § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013(02), § 5-10) 
Sec. 8-25. - Moving buildings; payment of utility company expenses. 
    Any person desiring to remove or move any building within the city from one location to another shall, before the beginning of the moving of said building, pay the utility companies whose wires, lights, cables, etc., may interfere with said moving of said buildings, all expenses necessary in removing said wires, lights, cables, etc., which may be interfered with in such moving. The term "company" shall include this city. 
(Code 1977, § 5-11; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013(02), § 5-11) 
Sec. 8-26. - Authority of building official to determine stability of structures; requirements not covered by code. 
    Any requirement necessary for the strength or stability of an existing or proposed building or structure, or for the safety or health of the occupants thereof, not specifically covered by this Code, shall be determined by the building official or deputy building official. 
(Code 1977, § 5-12; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013(02), § 5-12) 
Sec. 8-27. - Building valuation and permit fees. 
(a)	Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory building means a subordinate building or structure on the same lot, or a portion of the main building, the use of which is clearly incidental to that of the main building. 
    Actual value means the total value of work, including materials and labor, for which the permit is being issued. If, in the opinion of the building official, the valuation is underestimated, the permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimates to meet the approval of the building official. 
    Addition means new construction that increases or adds to the square footage of an existing building or structure, including, but not limited to, the construction of carports, garages, and living areas. 
    Commercial use means the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, that benefits a commercial entity. Examples include offices, retail stores, places of business, restaurants, hospitals, churches, government buildings, hotels, motels, etc. 
    Enclosing means the construction of walls and/or roofs that increases or adds to the square footage of an existing building or structure, but does not require the construction of a new foundation, including, but not limited to, the construction of carports, garages, patios, decks, and porches. 
    Industrial use means the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for assembling, disassembling, distributing, fabricating, finishing, manufacturing, packaging, repair or processing operations. 
    Major renovations means construction on an existing building or structure that has an actual value of more than $10,000.00. 
    Minor renovations means construction on an existing building or structure that has an actual value of less than $10,000.00. 
    New construction means any construction that includes or requires the construction of a new foundation. 
    Residential use means the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for sleeping purposes, where the occupants are primarily permanent in nature. Examples include single-family dwellings, multifamily dwellings, apartment houses, convents, dormitories, boardinghouses, etc. 
(b)	Valuation. The value of buildings, structures, or alterations, for the purpose of determining the permit fee, shall be performed in accordance with the following schedule, subject to future revision as established from time to time: 
Type of construction Valuation Residential construction (gross square footage under roof) New construction $40.00 per sq. ft. Additions/enclosings/accessory buildings $30.00 per sq. ft. Major renovations and finishing expandable areas $20.00 per sq. ft. Minor renovations and other minor construction Actual value Commercial/industrial construction (gross square footage under roof) New construction $60.00 per sq. ft. Additions/enclosings/accessory buildings $50.00 per sq. ft. Major renovations and finishing expandable areas $40.00 per sq. ft. Minor renovations and other minor construction Actual value Temporary buildings or structures (gross square footage under roof) Offices/classrooms/etc. $50.00 per sq. ft. Tents (residential/commercial/industrial) $40.00 per sq. ft. Signs (gross square footage of the sign face) New single-sided sign $2.00 per sq. ft. New double-sided sign $1.50 per sq. ft. Renovations to existing sign $1.00 per sq. ft. Fences (flat fee per fence) Agricultural/residential (flat fee per fence) $35.00 fee Commercial/industrial (walls, subdivision fences, etc.) $50.00 fee Swimming pools (flat fee) Commercial or public (each) $300.00 fee Residential or private (each) $100.00 fee Pool heaters (each) $25.00 fee Gas piping (each outlet) $4.00 fee Brick tie inspection $25.00 fee Re-inspection fee (first inspection included in permit fee) $50.00 fee Second and each succeeding reinspection of the same type $50.00 fee Irrigation permit (landscape sprinklers) Actual value  
(c)	Permit fees. On all buildings, structures, or alterations requiring a building permit, a fee shall be paid as required at the time of filing application, in accordance with the following schedule, subject to future revision as established from time to time: 
Total valuation Fee $1,000.00 and less $15.00 plus an additional $15.00 for each inspection required after the initial inspection. $1,000.00 to $50,000.00 $15.00 for the first $1,000.00 plus $5.00 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and including $50,000.00. $50,000.00 to $100,000.00 $300.00 for the first $50,000.00 plus $4.00 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and including $100,000.00. $100,000.00 to $500,000.00 $500.00 for the first $100,000.00 plus $3.00 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and including $500,000.00. $500,000.00 and up $1,700.00 for the first $500,000.00 plus $2.00 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof.  
(d)	Moving of building or structure . For the moving of any building or structure, the fee shall be $100.00, subject to revision as established from time to time. 
(e)	Demolition of building or structure . For the demolition of a residential building or structure, the fee shall be $50.00. For the demolition of a commercial building or structure, the fee shall be $100.00. These fees are subject to revision, as established from time to time. 
(f)	Plan review . On new construction projects where plan review is required, a plan review fee of $100.00, said amount subject to revision as established from time to time, shall be paid at the time the plans and specifications are submitted; and, with regard to residential construction, such fee shall be paid if required by the building inspector. 
(g)	Work started before permit issued . Where work for which a permit is required is started or proceeded with prior to obtaining said permit, the fees herein specified shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed herein. 
(h)	Request for planning commission review . When any parcel of land requires review by the planning commission, including requests for rezoning, conditional uses, variances, plat approvals, and any and all other requests for review, the fee shall be $100.00, which includes the posting of signage, publishing of public notice, and other administrative fees associated with such review. 
(Code 1977, § 5-13; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1; Res. of 2-1-2011(2); Res. of 8-16-2011(2), § 1; Res. of 6-18-2013(02), § 5-13) 
Secs. 8-28-8-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 8-60. - Certification exam required. 
    No person shall be issued a certificate as a qualified electrician until said person has first made a passing grade on the electrical examination administered by the International Code Council Licensing Examination Program. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-1; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1; Ord. of 9-20-1994; Ord. of 3-2-1999, § (A)) 
Sec. 8-61. - License certificates; who may sign. 
    License certificates may be signed by a member of the electrical examining board, the secretary of the board or the inspector and the municipal seal affixed thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-2; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-62. - Electrical license fees. 
    There shall be a fee charged for each license which shall be effective for a period of one year and may be renewed annually on payment of a renewal fee, provided that said renewal is proper in the opinion of the electrical examining board. Fees shall be as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-3; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-63. - Installation of electrical wiring; annual surety bond required. 
    All persons (except public utility companies operating under a franchise) before installing any electrical wiring shall furnish the city a good surety bond annually in the sum of $5,000.00 as a guarantee that electrical wiring installed by them or by their employees shall be in accordance with the requirements of this article and the National Electrical Code, and it is further conditioned that such persons shall, without further cost to the person for whom the work was done, remedy any defective or faulty work and replace any inferior or unsafe material installed by them or by their employees and found by the electrical inspector as not conforming with the requirement of this section, and such bond as is furnished shall be liable for the correction of the faulty work or for the replacement of the inferior or unsafe material, and any additional cost arising from the abovementioned causes. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-4; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-64. - Inspection of electrical wiring; permit charges or fees. 
    There shall be the permit charges or fees that are hereby established from time to time for the inspection of electrical wiring before a permit or a certificate of approval is issued or the wiring connected for electric current. All charges in this section are cumulative in making up the total charge to be made for the permit and inspection of electrical wiring installed under any one permit. Provided, however, a maximum charge shall prevail for the permit and inspection of electrical wiring in any one building and installed under a single permit. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-5; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-65. - Installation of electrical wiring; written permit required. 
    Any person desiring to install electrical wiring shall, after the licensing provisions of this article have been complied with, file a written notice with the electrical inspector's office stating fully the nature of the work to be done and the owner and location of the property where the same is to be carried out and obtain a written permit to install the electrical wiring. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-6; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-66. - Inspection of wiring before turning on current. 
    Electrical wiring, or an addition to such wiring, shall not be connected for service of electric current until after it has been inspected and approved by the electrical inspector as complying with the provisions of this article. Permission may be granted by the electrical inspector for temporary service for a period not exceeding 30 days, and at the expiration of the time specified the electrical inspector shall order the service of electric current to be disconnected, unless a certificate of approval has been issued. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-7; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-67. - Concealment of electrical wiring prior to inspection unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal or cause to be concealed, in such manner that the electrical inspector cannot easily observe or satisfy himself that the provisions of this article have been complied with, any electrical wiring before the same has been inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-8; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Sec. 8-68. - Tampering with fuses or other automatic overload protective devices unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with fuses or other automatic overload protective devices for electrical wiring or equipment in such manner that, by so doing, the electrical wiring or equipment will be supplied with electric current without the protection of a fuse or other automatic overload protective device as required by the minimum standard for electrical wiring. The occupant of the building where a condition outlined in this section is found to exist will be held liable and will be prosecuted for the violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 6.5-9; Ord. of 3-20-1990, § 1) 
Secs. 8-69-8-94. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - DEALERS IN ANTIQUES AND VARIOUS PRECIOUS METALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Business of purchasing precious items for resale, MCA 1972, § 75-95-1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-25. - Permit required. 
    Any person, firm or corporation acquiring, purchasing or otherwise dealing in antique, used or scrap jewelry, flatware, silverware, silver, gold or other precious metals in whatever form, where the said purchase is for resale in its original form or as changed by remounting, melting, reforming, remolding or recasting or for resale as scrap or in bulk, shall be required to obtain a permit from the chief of police prior to engaging in such business, which permit shall be valid for not more than six months. 
(Code 1977, § 6-21; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 1) 
Sec. 10-26. - Information required of applicant; fee; false information. 
(a)	To obtain a permit, applicants shall supply to the chief of police the following information: Name, social security number, and date of birth of applicant, and if a corporation, the names, social security numbers and dates of birth of all officers and directors who shall be designated as to their office; address of applicant, and, in addition, if a corporation, the address of all officers and directors; names of employees, social security numbers and dates of birth and their addresses; criminal convictions, other than traffic offenses of applicant, officers, directors and employees; street address of the place from which business is to be conducted, and the location where items described in section 10-25 shall be kept during the time period set forth in section 10-27; a recent photograph of applicant, officers, directors, and employees; the days of the week and hours of the day during which business will be conducted. 
(b)	The fee for said permit shall be in an amount as established from time to time, for each six-month period or portion thereof. 
(c)	A willful providing of false information shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 6-22; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 2) 
Sec. 10-27. - Waiting period required before selling, exchanging, melting, etc., items. 
    It shall be unlawful for any such person, firm or corporation engaging in the activity described in section 10-25 for a period of five days from the date of said purchase or other acquisition, to sell, exchange, barter or remove from the place in which said business is conducted, or in case the place of business is located in a motel or hotel, the room or rooms in which the business is conducted, or such other place as may be approved by the chief of police, or to change the form of any of said items by remounting, melting, cutting up, or otherwise to change the form of any of said items described in section 10-25. 
(Code 1977, § 6-23; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 3) 
Sec. 10-28. - Items to be kept separated. 
    During the five-day period set forth and provided for in section 10-27, all items described in section 10-25 thereof shall be kept physically separated according to the date of purchase or other acquisition and shall not be commingled with any other personality. 
(Code 1977, § 6-24; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 4) 
Sec. 10-29. - Records to be kept; delivery of copy to chief of police. 
    Every person, firm or corporation dealing in the items described in section 10-25 shall maintain a log in duplicate and shall enter on said log a clear and accurate description of any items described in section 10-25 which are purchased or otherwise acquired and the date and amount of money or other thing of value paid for said items and the name, race, sex, driver's license or state identification number (state and number), residence and address of the seller. The seller and the purchaser shall each sign the log acknowledging the accuracy of the description of said items sold and the consideration paid for said items. The seller shall, following the signing of his or her name, list race, sex, residence and address and a driver's license number or state identification number. For each day the person, firm or corporation described in section 10-25 shall designate in the application as a day on which shall be open for business of the type described herein, such person, firm or corporation shall deliver to the chief of police in a manner designated by the chief a copy of the log concerning that day's business, whether transactions are consummated or not, said copy of said log to be delivered by noon of the day following. The original log shall be carefully preserved without alteration and shall at all times be open and available for inspection by the chief of police or the chief's designee. Failure to log each purchase or other acquisition of any item described in section 10-25 shall constitute a separate violation of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 6-25; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 5) 
Sec. 10-30. - Exemption. 
    This article shall have no application to duly licensed pawn shops and jewelry stores domiciled and having established places of business and who have complied with all privilege tax laws of the state and the city. 
(Code 1977, § 6-26; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 7) 
Sec. 10-31. - Presumption of resale purposes in criminal proceedings. 
    In any criminal proceeding hereunder, the holder of a permit issued pursuant to the terms of this article shall be presumed to have acquired, purchased or otherwise come into the possession of the items described in section 10-25 hereof for purposes of resale. 
(Code 1977, § 6-27; Ord. of 12-24-1980, § 9) 
Sec. 10-32. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)	Generally. Each day a person, firm or corporation engaging in the activities defined in section 10-25 shall fail to obtain a permit from the chief of police or maintain a log as required, or shall fail to deliver to the chief of police a copy of the log for which provision is herein made or other violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	Fine and/or imprisonment. Every person, firm, or corporation, their agents or employees who shall violate any of the provisions hereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(c)	Revocation of permit. Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of this article or upon the failure to comply with its terms, the chief of police shall revoke any permit issued pursuant to the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1977, § 6-28; Ord. of 12-24-1980, §§ 6, 8, 10) 
Secs. 10-33-10-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BED AND BREAKFAST FACILITIES 

Sec. 10-77. - Statement of purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to provide standards for the establishment and operation of bed and breakfast facilities. The "Bed and Breakfast Ordinance" is intended to allow for a more efficient use of large houses in the city and to systematically manage anticipated growth in tourism. This article defines the standards and requirements for establishing a bed and breakfast facility in a residential neighborhood, for continuing to operate an existing bed and breakfast facility, and for conducting commercial meetings in a bed and breakfast facility. These regulations enable a homeowner to maintain residential structures in a manner which keeps them primarily in residential use. The homeowner can take advantage of the scale and the architectural and historical significance of a residence by introducing bed and breakfast services to, what would otherwise be, a private home. In addition, the neighborhood benefits because the property is preserved, well maintained, and remains occupied. It is intended that the operation of bed and breakfast facilities shall be compatible with the surrounding area by averting adverse impacts, such as the commercialization of residential areas and demand for on street parking. The regulations are also designed to consider the support and/or opposition from adjacent property owners and the immediate neighborhood. 
(Code 1977, § 6-51; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 1) 
Sec. 10-78. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bed and breakfast residence facility means an owner-occupied or resident manager run bed and breakfast establishment wherein units are rented to transient guests on an overnight basis, and wherein breakfast is the only meal served to these guests. 
    Bed and breakfast residence facility with commercial meeting privileges means a bed and breakfast residence where commercial meetings such as weddings, banquets, luncheons, meetings, parties, fund raisings, or other gatherings for compensation are permitted on site. 
(Code 1977, § 6-52; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 2) 
Sec. 10-79. - Conditional use procedures. 
(a)	The operation of a bed and breakfast facility, with or without commercial meeting privileges, in an area previously zoned residential requires the approval by the planning commission of a conditional use to the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(b)	Each application for a conditional use to the zoning ordinances in order to operate a bed and breakfast facility, either with or without commercial meeting privileges, in a residential zone must be accompanied by clear and convincing evidence that there will be no substantial interference with the health, safety and welfare of the general public, as well as the character and integrity of a residential area. In addition, a bed and breakfast facility shall not promote the commercialization of residential neighborhoods. All decisions for the granting of a conditional use for the operation of a bed and breakfast facility within a residential zone will be made on a case-by-case basis. The planning commission will work with each applicant to accommodate both individual interests and the interests of the city, particularly those residents of the area in question. 
(Code 1977, § 6-53; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 3) 
Sec. 10-80. - Conditional use permit. 
(a)	In addition to obtaining a conditional use to the zoning ordinances, the operation of a bed and breakfast facility, either with or without commercial meeting privileges, requires a conditional use permit. The permit procedure is the same as for all applications for conditional uses or amendments to the zoning ordinances. Each application for conditional use must be accompanied by clear and convincing evidence that there will be no substantial interference with the health, safety and welfare of the general public, as well as the character and integrity of a residential area. In addition, a bed and breakfast facility shall not promote the commercialization of residential neighborhoods. All decisions for the granting of a conditional use permit for the operation of a bed and breakfast facility will be made on a case-by-case basis. The planning commission will work with each applicant to accommodate both individual interests and the interests of the city, and particularly those residents of the area in question. 
(b)	The conditional use permit for the operation of a bed and breakfast facility either with or without commercial meeting privileges within a residential zone is not automatically transferrable to a subsequent owner. The new owner or perspective purchaser must submit a new application for a conditional use permit to the planning commission. A public hearing on the application must take place to inform the public of changes happening in their neighborhood and to provide an opportunity for public input on the change. Special consideration will be given to properties previously operated as a bed and breakfast facility; however, all new applications must meet the provisions set forth in this article. 
(c)	In addition to the standards of this article, conditions of approval may be added to the conditional use permit consistent with the intent and purposes of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 6-54; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 4) 
Sec. 10-81. - Operation. 
    All facilities authorized hereunder shall be owner-occupied or have a resident manager. 
(Code 1977, § 6-55; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 5) 
Sec. 10-82. - Use-related regulations. 
(a)	Commercial meetings. Under existing zoning regulations, commercial meetings are prohibited in all residential areas. Under this article, commercial meeting privileges will be granted in the following manner: 
(1)	By the approval of an application for a bed and breakfast facility with commercial meeting privileges. A bed and breakfast facility with commercial meeting privileges grants permission to the applicant to host commercial meetings on a case-by-case basis if the applicant can prove that all other requirements are met and that the proposed use will have little or no negative impact on the surrounding neighborhood. 
(2)	By the approval of a separate application for commercial meeting privileges in a pre-established bed and breakfast facility, owners of pre-established bed and breakfast facilities may apply for commercial meeting privileges which grants permission to the applicant to host commercial meetings on a case-by-case basis if the applicant can prove that all other requirements are met and that the proposed use will have little or no negative impact on the surrounding neighborhood. 
(b)	Reports. Once commercial meeting privileges are granted to a bed and breakfast facility, the owner/operator must submit annual reports to the planning commission. These reports shall reflect type of event, dates and number of people and other such information as deemed necessary by the planning commission. 
(c)	Renewal. Conditional use permits for the operation of a bed and breakfast facility, with or without commercial meeting privileges, must be renewed annually. All renewed applications must be presented to the planning commission for its review and approval. 
(d)	Service to guests: 
(1)	Food services may only be provided to overnight guests of a bed and breakfast facility or to the guests at a commercial meeting. The proprietor must meet all the requirements and seek approval by the county board of health. 
(2)	Serving alcohol to overnight guests is allowed. The proprietor must meet all requirements of the state alcohol beverage control commission in order to serve alcohol at a bed and breakfast facility. 
(Code 1977, § 6-56; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 6) 
Sec. 10-83. - Monitoring. 
    All bed and breakfast facilities are encouraged to maintain a guest book for overnight guests and for commercial meetings. It should include dates of stay, origin of visitors, and the dates of commercial meetings. The guest book may serve as evidence in the event the bed and breakfast or commercial meeting privileges are in question or under review by the planning commission. 
(Code 1977, § 6-57; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 7) 
Sec. 10-84. - Pre-established bed and breakfast facilities. 
    All bed and breakfast facilities operating as of the date of the ordinance from which this article is derived must meet all of the requirements and criteria contained herein. 
(Code 1977, § 6-58; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 8) 
Sec. 10-85. - Application fees. 
    Application fees and relevant criteria shall be as established from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 6-59; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 9) 
Sec. 10-86. - Insurance. 
    Each person having a permit under this article shall carry general liability insurance covering such operation in the minimum amount of $100,000.00. 
(Code 1977, § 6-60; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 10) 
Sec. 10-87. - Citizen complaint. 
    Any private citizen can voice concern or otherwise appear before the planning commission or the city council in regard to noncompliance with the provisions of this article and such complaint, if well taken, shall be considered by the planning commission and the city council in considering the permitting or renewal of any bed and breakfast facility, including the granting or renewal of commercial meeting privileges. 
(Code 1977, § 6-61; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 11) 
Sec. 10-88. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. The owner of any bed and breakfast facility where anything in violation of this article shall be placed or shall exist, and any person who may having knowingly assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 6-62; Ord. of 4-1-1997, § 12) 
Sec. 10-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNK DEALERS, PAWNBROKERS, TRANSIENT VENDORS 

Sec. 10-90. - Purchase of junk, etc.-From minors; consent required.
