    It shall be unlawful for any person to buy, purchase, barter or receive or take, directly or indirectly, from any person under 21 years of age, any old iron, sacks, secondhand watches, jewelry, bicycles, machinery or parts of machinery, tools, plumbing supplies, water pipes, fixtures or fittings, guns, pistols, electric wire or electrical fittings or fixtures, or any kind of the following articles, whether new or old, or secondhand: Lead, brass, copper or iron of any kind or description, or automobile accessories of every kind and description, unless at the time such articles are purchased, bought, bartered for, taken or received, the minor selling such articles shall deliver to the person buying, bartering for or receiving them, a certificate of the parent of such minor, or guardian, or the mayor, or the chief of police of the city, authorizing such sale. Such certificate shall accurately describe the articles to be sold, bartered or delivered, and shall be taken and preserved by the purchaser of said articles, for one year after the purchase or receiving of the articles and shall be subject at all times to inspection by the chief of police or any police officer of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-8; Ord. of 8-21-1917, § 1) 
Sec. 10-91. - Same-Record. 
    Any person who shall purchase, buy, barter or in any manner directly or indirectly receive any of the material or articles mentioned in section 10-90, from any person whether a minor or not, shall keep a record thereof, which record shall show the name of the person selling or delivering the material or article, the address of the person, the date of the purchase thereof, and a description of the material or article purchased and the price paid therefor, which said record shall be kept for one year and be subject at all times to the inspection of the chief of police and police officers of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-9; Ord. of 8-21-1917, § 2) 
Sec. 10-92. - Regulation of the business and other transactions of transient vendors. 
(a)	Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means an individual, corporation, association, partnership or other entity. 
    Transient business means any business conducted for the sale of merchandise or services that is carried on at a particular location for a period of less than six months in each year, even though the owner of such business may conduct the business at another location for more than six months in each year. 
    Transient vendor means any person who transacts transient business in this state either in one locality or by traveling from place to place in this state. The term includes a vendor who for the purposes of carrying on such business hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, railroad car or real property. 
(b)	A transient vendor may not transact business in the city unless the vendor, and the owner of the merchandise or provider of the services to be offered if the merchandise is not owned or the services are not provided by the vendor, has secured a license in accordance with this section and otherwise complied with this section. 
(c)	A transient vendor who desires to transact business in the city shall apply for and obtain a license in the city. The vendor must obtain such license in each municipality in which the vendor desires to transact business. The license application shall be filed with the municipal tax collector, and must include: 
(1)	The name and permanent address of the transient vendor making the application; 
(2)	A statement describing the kind of business to be conducted, the length of time for which the applicant desires to transact the business, and the proposed location of the business; 
(3)	The name and permanent address of the applicant's registered agent or office; and 
(4)	Proof that the applicant has acquired all other required city, county and state permits and licenses. Such proof shall include a state sales tax number and, if the transient vendor desires to transact business in the city, such number shall include such municipality's sales tax diversion code. 
(d)	If the applicant is an association or a corporation, the applicant must also include the names and addresses of the members of the association or the officers of the corporation. If the applicant is a corporation, the application must state the date of incorporation and the state in which it was incorporated. If the applicant is a corporation organized under the laws of another state, the applicant must state the date on which the corporation qualified to transact business as a foreign corporation in this state. 
(e)	Each applicant for a transient vendor license shall designate a registered agent on the license application. The registered agent must be a resident of the city and shall be the agent on whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law to be served on the licensee may be served. The registered agent must agree in writing to act as the agent. The license applicant shall file a copy of the agreement with the license application. 
(f)	The municipal tax collector shall maintain an alphabetical list of all transient vendors in the city, and the names and addresses of their registered agents. 
(g)	If a transient vendor who does business in the city fails to have or to maintain a registered agent in the city, or if the designated registered agent cannot be found at the stated permanent address, the municipal tax collector is the agent of the transient vendor for service of process, notices or demands. Service on the tax collector is made by delivering to the collector's office duplicate copies of the process, notice or demand. If such a process, notice or demand is served on the tax collector, the collector shall immediately forward one copy by registered or certified mail to the permanent address of the transient vendor. 
(h)	Each applicant for a transient vendor license shall include a license fee, as established from time to time, with the application, which fee shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. The applicant shall also execute a cash bond or a surety bond issued by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state in an amount that is the lesser of either $2,000.00 or five percent of the wholesale value of any merchandise or service to be offered for sale by the applicant. The surety bond shall be issued in favor of the state and conditioned upon payment of: 
(1)	All taxes due from the applicant to the state or to a political subdivision of the state. 
(2)	Any fines assessed against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees for a violation of this section. 
(3)	Any judgment rendered against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees in a cause of action commenced by a purchaser of merchandise or services not later than one year after the date the merchandise or services were sold by the applicant. 
(i)	The municipal tax collector shall issue a transient vendor license under this section only if all requirements of this section may been met. The license is not transferable and is valid only within the territorial limits of the city. A license expires 90 days after the day of issuance. 
(j)	The transient vendor shall maintain the bond during the period that the vendor conducts business in the city and for a period of one year after the termination of the business. After the transient vendor furnishes satisfactory proof to the municipal tax collector that the vendor has satisfied all claims of purchasers of merchandise from or services offered by the vendor and that all sales taxes and other applicable taxes have been paid, the bond shall be released. 
(k)	The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)	Civic and nonprofit organizations or wholesale sales to retail merchants by commercial travelers. 
(2)	Wholesale trade shows or conventions. 
(3)	Sales of goods, wares, services or merchandise by sample, catalog or brochure for future delivery. 
(4)	Fairs and convention center activities conducted primarily for amusement or entertainment. 
(5)	Any general sale, fair, circus, auction or bazaar sponsored by a church or religious organization. 
(6)	Garage sales held on premises devoted to residential use. 
(7)	Sales or repairs of crafts or sales or repairs of items made by hand by the person making the crafts or items. 
(8)	Duly licensed flea markets operating from a fixed location. 
(9)	Sales of agricultural, dairy, poultry, seafood or forest management products or services related to forest management or silvicultural activities, nursery products, foliage plants or ornamental trees, except such products or services sold at retail and not grown or produced within the state. 
(10)	Sales of agricultural services. 
(l)	A transient vendor not otherwise exempted from this section is not exempted from this section because of a temporary association with a local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant, or by conducting the transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant. 
(m)	A license may be renewed on payment of a renewal fee as established from time to time, and filing for renewal with the municipal tax collector before the expiration of the current license. A license may be renewed only one time, after which a licensee must again purchase a new license. 
(n)	While transacting business, a transient vendor shall post in a prominent place, so that they may clearly be seen by purchasers of the merchandise or services which the vendor is offering, state sales tax number, transient vendor license number, and a statement that the vendor is required to give purchasers, at the time of payment, receipts for purchases that include sales tax. The postings required in this section shall be written in bold, legible letters and numbers not less than one inch in height. The transient vendor shall keep a running total of sales. 
(o)	Any person who knowingly or intentionally operates a transient business without a valid license as provided by this section or who knowingly or intentionally advertises, offers for sale, or sells any merchandise or services in violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4. Such person may also be proceeded against by suit, and the tax collector may seize and sell any property of the person liable for the tax and penalty in the same manner as property of taxpayers delinquent for the payment of ad valorem taxes due on personal property may be distrained and sold. 
(Code 1977, § 13-20; Ord. of 4-15-1986, § 1; Ord. of 7-18-1995) 
Sec. 10-93. - Regulation of pawnbrokers, junk dealers, etc. 
(a)	Definition. As used in this section, the term "secondhand dealer" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind which, to any degree, buys and sells secondhand articles. It shall not apply to a private citizen who has a garage or yard sale, a nonprofit organization, or an antique dealer. 
(b)	Requirements. Every junk dealer, pawnbroker and secondhand dealer in the city is hereby required to maintain a log in duplicate in which shall be entered a clear and accurate description of any items which are purchased or otherwise acquired and the date and amount of money or other thing of value paid for said items and the name, race, sex, driver's license (state and number), residence and address of the person selling, pledging, or pawning the item. All parties to the transaction shall sign the log acknowledging the accuracy of all of the information placed in the log entry and the junk dealer, pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall obtain the thumbprint of each person selling, pawning, or pledging the item. For each day the junk dealer, pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall be open for business, such person, firm or corporation shall deliver to the chief of police in a manner designated by him, a copy of the log concerning that day's business (whether transactions are consummated or not), said copy of the log to be delivered by noon of the day following. The original log shall be carefully preserved without alteration and shall be at all times open and available for inspection by the chief of police or the chief's designee. Failure to log each transaction shall constitute a separate violation of this section. 
(c)	Penalty for violation. Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 13-21; Ord. of 4-15-1986, § 1) 
State Law reference- Junk dealers to keep records of certain transactions, MCA 1972, § 97-17-71. 
Secs. 10-94-10-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - JUNKYARDS 

Sec. 10-110. - Regulation of junkyards. 
(a)	Junkyards prohibited. 
(1)	All junkyards as defined in this section are hereby prohibited in each and every zoning district in the city. 
(2)	Junkyards as nonconforming uses may be allowed subject to compliance with all other statutes, regulations, and ordinances. 
(3)	All junkyards, which were legally and properly in operation as of the date of adoption of this Code, will be considered preexisting, nonconforming uses. All other junkyards shall be prohibited. All such preexisting, nonconforming junkyards must comply with each and every statute, regulation and ordinance in effect, including, but not limited to, all provisions of the zoning ordinances of the city within 60 days of passage of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(b)	Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile graveyard means any establishment or place of business which is maintained, used or operated for storing, keeping, buying or selling wrecked, scrapped, ruined or dismantled motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts. 
    Junk means old or scrap copper, brass, rope, batteries, paper, trash, tires, rubber debris, waste or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles or parts thereof, iron, steel and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous material and used tires. 
    Junkyard means any establishment or place of business which is maintained, operated, or used for storing, keeping, buying, or selling junk. The term "junkyard" includes the term "automobile graveyard." A junkyard and an automobile graveyard, specifically, will not be permitted to sell new or used vehicles of any nature intended to be used for operation and/or transport. 
    Operator means the person who is actually responsible for the operation and management of a junkyard. 
    Owner means the person who is the actual owner, pursuant to a deed of record, of the land where a junkyard is situated. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other entity or business entity of any nature. 
(c)	License and application requirements. 
(1)	The owner of every junkyard operating within the city must receive an annual license for the same. The owner of said junkyard must comply with any and all application requirements as well as be in compliance with all statutes, regulations, and ordinances of the United States government, the state, county, and city. 
(2)	Every applicant for a junkyard license shall file with the community development division a written application signed by the owner and the operator, if not the same person or entity. Said application shall contain the following: 
a.	The name and address of the owner and operator and if either of these entities are a firm, partnership, cooperation, limited liability company, or other business entity, the names and addresses of the officers, all shareholders owning in excess of ten percent of corporate stock, any partners, members, and the registered agency thereof. 
b.	The length of time that the applicant or owner has used the premises outlined below as a junkyard. 
c.	The legal description of the premises to be used as a junkyard, including a metes and bounds description of the lands constituting the premises, together with a description of any buildings or other improvements thereon. 
d.	A description of the type and size of any and all buildings to be located at the junkyard. 
e.	A description of all materials to be purchased, sold or stored in the junkyard. 
f.	A sketch or diagram of the junkyard premises showing existing and proposed entrances or entranceways to the junkyard, and the location of all buildings and structures used in the junkyard operation. 
g.	A list of the names and addresses of all owners of real estate within a radius of 500 feet of the outermost boundaries of said junkyard. 
h.	A fire control plan, which must be approved by the local fire official. 
i.	All receipts from the previous year documenting the number of tires transferred to an end-market, recycling center approved by the state, or a tire facility exempted from the requirement. 
j.	A copy of the certification submitted to the state department of environmental protection. 
k.	The number of employees to be employed at the junkyard and proof of workers' compensation insurance covering said employees. 
(3)	The applicant shall submit at the time of filing of the application a certified check for the license fee as established from time to time by the city council. 
(4)	Any license granted by the community development division pursuant to this section shall expire on December 31 of the year in which the license was granted. Thereafter, the license may be renewed for a one-year period commencing January 1 by submitting the application therefor to the community development division no later than December 1 of the previous year and depositing with the city clerk a certified check in the amount of $100.00 as payment of the annual license fee. 
(5)	Each license holder shall post the holder's license in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(6)	The failure or refusal of any applicant to submit a complete application with all documentation and fees required by this section shall be cause for denial of the license of the year submitted. 
No junkyard application will be considered and no license issued unless proof of payment of any and all taxes which are due as of the time of the submission of said license has been submitted with said application. 
(d)	Regulations. All junkyards which are lawfully in the city shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)	It shall be unlawful to stack, pile or place motor vehicles, parts of motor vehicles or any other junk or materials upon such premises in such a manner as to create a place for the harboring or breeding of mice, rats or other vermin or to stack, pile or place junk above the height of the boundary fence surrounding the premises. 
(2)	All junkyards shall be completely obstructed from the view of each and every adjoining landowner and from any and every public street. Unless a junkyard is so located whereby there is such natural environmental obstruction that obstructs the view of said junkyard from all and every adjoining landowner and every and all public streets, every junkyard and places where junk is stored shall be enclosed completely on all sides by a fence at least eight feet high and of a type and construction as shall be approved by the building official. Building permits for new construction shall be applied for/paid for before construction begins. There shall be no advertisement allowed or any description nor writing on said fence, except the name of the business, if any, and said writing shall not exceed the area of 25 square feet. 
(3)	All burning is hereby prohibited. 
(4)	No junk, rubbish or salvage of any type shall be maintained outside the enclosure surrounding any junkyard, nor outside of any junkshop. 
(5)	It shall be unlawful to hammer or pound any metal or other materials on said premises between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. from Mondays to Saturdays, inclusive, or at any time on Sundays. 
(6)	No license issued pursuant to the terms of this section shall entitle any licensee or anyone else to operate under said license at, in or on any lot, building, dwelling or location or any part thereof other than that specified in the license. No license shall be assignable or transferable to any other person or party whatsoever or to any other lands or premises other than those previously approved as junkyards and existing as such by valid licensing previously. The only transfer allowed shall be a person-to-person transfer, upon application made to the city council of the city of an existing validly licensed junkyard. The application shall contain the names and addresses of all parties to the transfer applied for, in accordance with all terms of this section, and shall be accompanied by a certified check payable to the city in the amount of $100.00. Any license permitted to be transferred by the city council shall expire on December 31 of the year in which the transfer is made. Thereafter, the license may be renewed for a one-year period. 
(7)	No materials of any explosive nature shall be maintained or demolished on any premises. 
(8)	No materials shall be kept or maintained on any said premises, lands, or locations which shall be of such odorous nature as to be offensive to adjoining landowners and property owners or other inhabitants in the area of the licensed premises. 
(9)	The licensee shall maintain sufficient fire extinguishers on the licensed premises at all times and shall also establish fire protection according to standards recommended by the International Fire Code for such premises. Each junkyard shall be subject to an annual inspection by an appropriate member or members of the fire department and/or community development division and must comply with any conditions, recommendations, or orders issued thereby. 
(10)	No part of any junkyard or junkshop shall be located within 200 feet from any private residence not owned by the applicant or from any church or school. 
(11)	All junkyards must operate in compliance with all relevant county, state, and federal environmental regulations. 
(12)	All junkyards shall take all steps to ensure that no mosquito colony formation or development is allowed to occur and must comply with all applicable state and local regulations. The configuration of junk at any junkyard shall be arranged so as to prevent the collecting and/or the retaining and/or the stagnation of water of any kind, including rainwater. 
(13)	All cars being dismantled or stacked must have the gasoline tanks removed. 
(14)	There shall be a limit of tires, whether rimless or otherwise, which are stored at any junkyard, and said limit shall not exceed five tires per vehicle which is stored at said junkyard, with said tires being located on or in said vehicle. In addition to the five tires contained on or in any vehicle, each junkyard shall be permitted to have an additional 50 tires not located on or in any vehicle. 
(15)	There shall be at least eight feet of open accessible space between any rows of vehicles which are stacked at any junkyard. 
(e)	Right of refusal to renew licenses. 
(1)	The city, by issuing said license, reserves unto itself the right to refuse the renewal of any existing license upon a finding by the code enforcement officer that the operation of said junkyard at the premises used for said purpose is detrimental to the health, safety, and general welfare of the public. The granting of a license under this section shall not be construed for any purpose as permission to the licensee to maintain any condition which would constitute a public or private nuisance or maintain any condition which would violate the regulations propounded in this section. Should the city determine on the hearing of the application for renewal of the existing license that there is a probable cause for refusing to renew said license, the community development division is to immediately notify the applicant that the city will hold a hearing on whether or not said license should be renewed. Such notification should inform the applicant of the time and date and the place of the hearing, which hearing shall be held within not less than ten nor more than 20 days from the date of service of said notice. The applicant shall then have an opportunity to be heard on the issue of whether or not said license should be renewed. The community development division shall also notify all property owners within 500 feet of the subject junkyard of the time and send by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(2)	The community development division may authorize a temporary permit for such licensee until the hearing has been completed and a determination made so that the business of a licensee may not be suspended or interfered with unreasonably by filing of any written objections. 
(f)	Suspension and revocation of license; inspection. 
(1)	The community development division may revoke any license granted at any time during the period for which the license was issued upon any violation of the provisions of this section, after a hearing provided to the licensee following complaint in writing and at least ten days' notice to the licensee setting forth the grounds of complaint. 
(2)	The licensed premises shall be open to inspection by the community development division and the county board of health at any reasonable time of day or night. 
(3)	In the event that any license shall be revoked for good cause shown or terminated voluntarily by the licensee, there shall be no refund of any portion of the license fee. 
(4)	In the event that any license shall be revoked, surrendered, or otherwise terminated, the same shall be evidence of the abandonment of a junkyard use and no further license shall be issued for said junkyard premises without proper zoning variances and other approvals being acquired for the same. 
(g)	Violations and penalties. 
(1)	Any person or corporation violating or refusing or neglecting to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(2)	A continuance of a violation or a noncompliance with the provisions of this section shall be deemed a nuisance, and the city council shall have the right to apply to the courts of this state for injunctive relief or other relief in addition to the penalties prescribed herein. 
(h)	Rules and regulations; inspections; administration. All licensed premises shall be at all times subject to such rules and regulations as may hereafter be made by the city council and shall be subject to inspection by the fire department and/or community development division, or any of their agents. The community development division shall have the responsibility of administering this section and making all complaints under said section. 
(i)	Refunds. There shall be no refund to a licensee of any of the license fees upon either the surrender or the revocation of a license granted hereunder. 
(j)	Prosecution of violations; sanctions. All penalties imposed under this section for violations thereof shall be independent of one another, and the city shall have the option of whether to prosecute a violation in the city court or whether to move for revocation of the licensee's license if the violator has such, or both. The invoking of sanctions or criminal penalties shall not be a bar to a subsequent proceeding under either section. 
State Law reference- Junkyard Control Law, MCA 1972, § 49-25-1 et seq. 
Chapter 12 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Mississippi Emergency Management Law, MCA 1972, § 33-15-1 et seq.; local organization of emergency management, MCA 1972, § 33-15-17; emergency use of personnel authorized, MCA 1972, § 33-15-49. 

Sec. 12-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the Emergency Management Ordinance of Greenwood, Mississippi. 
(Code 1977, § 7-1; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-2. - Intent and purpose. 
(a)	It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to establish an office that will ensure the complete and efficient utilization of all of the city facilities to prepare for and combat disaster resulting from enemy actions and other disasters defined herein. 
(b)	The emergency management office will be the coordinating agency for all activity in connection with disaster planning and operations; it will be the instrument through which the city officials may exercise the authority and discharge the responsibilities vested in them by the Mississippi Emergency Management Act, chapter 15 of title 33, Mississippi Code of 1972, Annotated, and this chapter. 
(c)	The chapter will not relieve any city department of the moral responsibilities or deprive it of any authority given to it by the state statutes, city resolutions, local ordinances, nor will it adversely affect the work by any volunteer agency organized for relief in disaster emergencies. 
(Code 1977, § 7-2; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Attack means a direct or indirect assault against the city, the state, its government, its environs or the nation, by the forces of a hostile nation or the agents thereof, including assault by bombing, radiological, chemical or biological warfare, or sabotage. 
    City means the incorporated areas of the city that lie inside the city limits geographically located within the county. The term "city" may include other political jurisdictions where there exists an agreement that they be included under this chapter. The term "city" shall also be defined to include the Greenwood-Leflore Airport. 
    Director means the executive head of the emergency management office under the direction and control of the mayor of the city or the mayor's designee who must be a member of the emergency management council. 
    Disaster includes, but is not limited to, actual or threatened enemy attack, sabotage, extraordinary fire, flood, storm, civil disorders, epidemic or other impending or actual calamity endangering health, life or property of constituted government. 
    Disaster volunteer means any person duly registered in writing, identified and appointed by the director of the emergency management office and assigned to participate in the disaster preparedness or operational activity. 
    Emergency forces means the employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and personnel, equipment and facilities distributed by, or obtained from, volunteer persons or agencies. 
    Emergency management means to carry out governmental functions of maintaining the public peace, health and safety during an emergency. The term "emergency management" includes plans and preparations for mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery from, the effects of an attack on the city by the forces of any enemy nation or the agents thereof, and it shall also include such activity in connection with other disasters as defined herein. It shall not, however, include any activity that is the primary responsibility of the military forces of the United States. 
    Emergency management council means the executive group which shall make all policy, vote on all matters pertaining to the security and well being of the city and the county in the event of an emergency, disaster or any other event that would require the assembling of said council. The emergency management council shall consist of the mayor, members of the city council and other elected officials of the county that have been specified in an emergency management resolution by the county board of supervisors. Each member of said council will have one vote on specified matters and must be present at council meetings to cast that vote. 
    Regulations includes plans, programs, and other emergency procedures deemed essential to disaster preparedness and operations. 
    Volunteer means contributing a service, equipment or facilities to the emergency preparedness organization without remuneration. 
(Code 1977, § 7-3; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-4. - Organization and appointment. 
(a)	The mayor is hereby authorized to create an organization for emergency management utilizing to the fullest extent the existing agencies within the city. The mayor shall be responsible for the organization, administration, and operations of the emergency preparedness and operational forces of the city. The mayor will designate a line of succession for those bodies to ensure that the necessary responsibility for direction and control can be exercised in the event of absence or inability of a quorum to act. 
(b)	The organization shall consist of the following: 
(1)	The employees, equipment and facilities of the city departments, board and commissions, who will participate in the emergency preparedness activities. Duties assigned to a department shall be the same or similar to the normal duties of the department. 
(2)	Volunteer persons and agencies offering service to, and accepted by the city. 
(c)	The mayor, in accordance with agreements with participating political subdivisions, will appoint a director of emergency management who shall be a person well versed and trained in planning and operations involving the many different agencies which will operate to protect the public health, safety and welfare in the event of danger enemy attack or disaster as defined in this chapter. The director will act as an advisor to the mayor during emergencies. 
(Code 1977, § 7-4; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-5. - Emergency powers and duties. 
(a)	The mayor may exercise the emergency power and authority necessary to fulfill and exercise general powers and duties under this chapter and the mayor's judgment shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke emergency powers provided in this chapter and those invested by state statutes listed in MCA 1972, § 33-15-17, as amended. The city council may convene to perform its powers as the situation demands, and receive reports relative to disaster preparedness activities. 
(b)	The city council may promulgate such regulations, during any period when disaster threatens or when a disaster has struck, as is deemed necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources. Examples of those regulations include, but are not necessarily limited to, the following: 
(1)	Regulations prohibiting or restricting the movement of vehicles in order to facilitate the work of disaster forces, or to facilitate the mass movement of persons from critical areas within the political subdivision's jurisdiction. 
(2)	Regulations pertaining to the movement of persons from areas deemed to be hazardous or vulnerable to disaster. 
(3)	Such other regulations necessary to preserve public peace, health and safety. Regulations promulgated in accordance with law will be given widespread circulation by proclamation published and uttered by newspaper and radio. Any person violating the law during a proclaimed civil emergency shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(c)	The mayor shall order disaster forces to the aid of other communities when required in accordance with state statutes, and may request the state, or a political subdivision of the state, to send aid to the city in case of disaster where conditions in the city are beyond the control of the local disaster forces. 
(d)	The mayor, subject to applicable state laws on procurement, may obtain vital supplies, equipment and other properties found lacking and needed for the protection of health, life and property of the people, and bind the city for the fair value thereof. 
(e)	The mayor may require emergency services of any city officer or employee. If regular forces are determined to be inadequate, the mayor may require the services of such other personnel as can be obtained that are available, including volunteer citizens. All duly authorized persons rendering disaster emergency services shall be entitled to the privileges and immunities as are provided for regular city employees and other registered and identified disaster workers. Claims for appropriate compensation will be processed when conditions so warrant consideration. 
(f)	An office of emergency management under the direction of the emergency management council shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson. The mayor of the city and the president of the county board of supervisors shall be the only candidates for these posts. However, the mayor and the president of the board of supervisors may by special order designate any other councilmember to fill these posts on their behalf. There shall be an executive head who shall be known as the director, and such assistants and other employees as deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the organization. 
(g)	Under the supervision of the emergency management council, the director shall be responsible for, but not necessarily limited to, the following duties: 
(1)	The director shall be responsible for the planning, coordination and operation of the emergency preparedness and operations activity of the political subdivision. Under the direction of the emergency management council, the director shall maintain liaison with the state and federal authorities and the authorities of other nearby political subdivisions to ensure the most effective implementation of the local disaster plan. 
(2)	The recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment those of the political subdivision. 
(3)	Subject to approval by the emergency management council, negotiating and concluding agreements with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such buildings for sheltering the public during disaster conditions and to designate these buildings as public shelters. 
(4)	Establish a public information program which will inform the people of the actions required for the protection of their persons and property in case of a disaster. 
(5)	Conducting public practice alerts and tests to ensure the efficient operations of the disaster forces and to familiarize residents with disaster regulations, procedures and operations. 
(6)	Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any disaster preparedness or operation activity. 
(7)	Assuming such authority and conducting such activity as the emergency management council may direct to promote and execute the local disaster plan. 
(8)	Establishing a reporting system to keep the emergency management council informed on the emergency preparedness level in the political subdivision at all times. To inventory and keep records on all property and equipment belonging to or issued to the emergency management council and to see that said equipment and property is maintained and in a state of readiness for any emergency situation. 
(9)	Some of the duties ascribed to the emergency management council may, at its discretion, be handled by the director, but the responsibility and authority stems from and remains with the emergency management council. 
(10)	The director shall be an ex officio member of the emergency management council but will not vote in matters before the emergency management council except in case of a tie vote. 
(11)	The director may, at the direction of the emergency management council, enter into mutual aid agreements with surrounding counties in cases of emergency or disasters. 
(12)	The director may enter into statements of understanding with private business and volunteer agencies. 
(Code 1977, § 7-5; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-6. - Emergency operations plan. 
(a)	A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be adopted by the emergency management council subsequent to recommendations by the emergency management director. In the preparation of this plan as it pertains to the emergency management organization, it is the intent that the services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments, agencies, city boards and city commissions shall be used to the fullest extent possible. When approved, it shall be the duty of all concerned departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. This basic plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter, and have the effect of law whenever a disaster, as defined by this chapter, has been proclaimed. All plans developed must be in accord with existing federal, state and local statutes and ordinances. 
(b)	There shall be prescribed in the local disaster plan those positions for which lines of succession are necessary. In each department and agency, the responsible person will designate and keep on file with the director a current list of three persons as successors to this position. The list will be in order of succession and will as nearly as possible, designate persons best capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions. 
(c)	Each department and agency head assigned responsibility in the basic plan shall be responsible for carrying out all duties and functions assigned therein. Duties will include the organization and of training of assigned employees and volunteers. Each department and agency head shall formulate the operational plan for the respective head's service which, when approved by the emergency management council, shall be annexed to and become part of the basic plan. 
(d)	Amendments to the basic local disaster plan will be submitted to the emergency management council for its approval. The emergency management director will make recommendations to the council relative to proposed amendments. Such amendments shall take effect on the date of approval unless stated otherwise. 
(e)	When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the city government, the mayor, subject to applicable state procurement laws, is authorized to direct the director to seek paid or unpaid assistance from persons outside of government. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall also grant authority for the persons so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during and after the occurrence of a disaster. Such citizens shall be enrolled as disaster assistance volunteers or employees, as the case might be, in cooperation with the heads of the department affected. 
(Code 1977, § 7-6; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-7. - Organization and private liability. 
(a)	Neither the city, nor its agents and representatives, while acting in good faith and without willful misconduct, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule or regulation, shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as a result of said activity. 
(b)	Neither any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants the city the right to license, inspect, designate or use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or during an actual, impending or practice occurrence or natural or manmade disasters, shall be civilly liable for the death or injury to any person on or about such real estate or premises by virtue of its use for civil defense purposes, or loss of or damage to, the property of such person, except in the case of willful misconduct. 
(Code 1977, § 7-7; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-8. - Violation of regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter or of the regulations or plans issued pursuant to the authority contained herein, or to willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the disaster forces as herein defined in the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter or any regulation or plan issued thereunder. 
(Code 1977, § 7-8; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-9. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 7-9; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-10. - Funding. 
    For the purpose of funding the emergency management council's functions, funds will be provided as authorized under the Mississippi Emergency Management Act in MCA 1972, §§ 33-15-23, 33-15-25(b) and 33-15-27. 
(Code 1977, § 7-11; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 12-11. - Conflicting ordinances, rules and regulations suspended. 
    At all times when the orders, rules and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede all existing ordinances, resolutions, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent herewith. 
(Code 1977, § 7-12; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 1) 
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority generally, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-1, 21-19-3, 21-19-15. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Privies and cesspools prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, construct or maintain any privy or cesspool within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-1; Ord. of 11-3-2003) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit, MCA 1972, § 21-19-1. 
Sec. 14-2. - Depositing slops, etc., on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or pour any slops, sewage or wastewater from any premises upon or into any street, alley, sidewalk, ditch or drain in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-2; Ord. of 3-5-2001; Ord. of 11-3-2003) 
Sec. 14-3. - Spitting in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit upon a sidewalk or on the floor of any public building in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-3; Ord. of 3-2-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 14-4. - Mosquito control definition. 
    Any collection of water considered in sections 14-5 through 14-9 shall be held to be that contained in ditches, pools, ponds, streams, excavations, holes, depressions, open cesspools, privy vaults, fountains, cisterns, tanks, shallow wells, barrels, troughs, urns, cans, boxes, bottles, tubs, buckets, roof gutters, tanks of flush closets, reservoirs, vessels, tires, receptacles of any kind, or other containers or devices which may hold water. 
(Code 1977, § 11-4; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 2) 
State Law reference- Mosquito control commissions, MCA 1972, § 41-27-1. 
Sec. 14-5. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit, within the city, any collection of standing or flowing water in which mosquitoes breed, or are likely to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so as effectually to prevent such breeding. 
(Code 1977, § 11-5; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 3; Ord. of 5-7-2007, §§ 1, 3) 
Sec. 14-6. - Prevention. 
    The methods used or treatment directed toward the prevention of breeding of mosquitoes in collections of water shall be of a type approved by the code enforcement officer. The code enforcement officer shall, from time to time, issue mosquito control regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 11-6; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 4) 
Sec. 14-7. - Evidence and violation. 
    The presence of mosquito larvae in collections of water shall be evidence that mosquitoes are breeding there, and failure to prevent such breeding within three days after notice by the code enforcement officer, authorized representative, or the mayor or authorized representative, be it police officer, housing inspector, or street supervisor, shall be deemed a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 11-7; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 5) 
Sec. 14-8. - Corrective action. 
    Should the person responsible for conditions giving rise to the breeding of mosquitoes fail or refuse to take necessary measures to prevent the same, within three days after due notice has been given to him, the code enforcement officer or the officer's representative, or the mayor or mayor's representative, is hereby authorized to do so, and all necessary cost incurred by him for this purpose shall be a charge against the property owner or other person offending, as the case may be. 
(Code 1977, § 11-8; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 6; Ord. of 5-7-2007, § 2) 
Sec. 14-9. - Inspection of premises. 
    For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of sections 14-4 through 14-8, the code enforcement officer or the officer's representative, or the mayor or mayor's representative, acting under their respective authorities, may, at all reasonable times, enter in and upon any premises within their jurisdiction; and any person charged with any of the duties imposed by said sections as stated in the notice of the code enforcement officer or the mayor, as the case may be, who fails to perform such duties or to carry out the necessary measures to the satisfaction of the code enforcement officer or the mayor, shall be deemed guilty of a separate violation of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 11-9; Ord. of 9-3-1975, § 7) 
Secs. 14-10-14-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTERING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Cleaning private property by city and imposing lien for cost, MCA 1972, § 21-19-11; abatement of nuisances, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-1, 95-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-37. - Depositing in public place; removal required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, sweep or place, or cause to be thrown, dropped, swept or placed in any public street, public or private alley, gutter, sidewalk or other public place in the city, dirt, brick, glass, gravel, coal, leaves, brush, trash, rubbish, paper, cotton samples, boxes or waste material of any kind or description without forthwith removing same. 
(Code 1977, § 11-20; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCA 1972, § 97-15-29. 
Sec. 14-38. - Sweeping sidewalks adjacent to business establishments. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons operating or occupying business establishments in the city to clean daily by sweeping or otherwise, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., the sidewalks in front of or along the side of the buildings occupied or controlled by such person. 
(Code 1977, § 11-21; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 2) 
Sec. 14-39. - Cleanliness of private property. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of all persons in both the business districts and residential districts of the city to keep and maintain their premises in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. Any person failing to comply with this section within 48 hours of written notice of violation shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. Each 24-hour period shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	If upon ten days' written notice, the owner and/or occupant of the property fails to comply with this section, then the city may do all things necessary to bring the property into compliance and the owner and/or occupant shall be civilly liable for all costs and expenses incurred by the city in bringing the property into compliance. 
(c)	A property owner and/or occupant may be held liable under either or both subsections (a) and (b) of this section. Liability of owners and/or occupiers under subsection (b) of this section shall be joint and several. 
(Code 1977, § 11-22; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 3; Ord. of 7-23-1985, § 1) 
Sec. 14-40. - Spillage from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person hauling gravel, cinders, brick, coal, sand, dirt, debris, garbage or waste material other than tree limbs and shrubbery, along the public streets or alleys of the city to do so in a vehicle or conveyance not equipped with sufficient flooring and sides, and covered by tarpaulin or similar material, so as to prevent any spillage, waste, or fall of such material from the conveyance transporting same into the streets or alleys of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-23; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 5; Ord. of 11-17-1992) 
Sec. 14-41. - Draining waste oil into streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or drain, or suffer or permit to be changed or drained, oil from the motors of motor vehicles on or into the streets, alleys, gutters, sidewalks or other public places of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-24; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 6) 
Sec. 14-42. - Enforcement. 
    The code enforcement officer of the city and the police officers of the city are hereby charged with the duty of carrying out and enforcing the provisions of this article and are hereby empowered to make arrests for violation thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 11-25; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 8) 
Secs. 14-43-14-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREE PRESERVATION 

Sec. 14-59. - Intent and purpose. 
    The intent of this article is to aid in the stabilization of soil by the prevention of erosion and sedimentation; to reduce storm water and the runoff and the cost associated therewith and replenish ground water supplies; to aid in the removal of carbon dioxide and generation of oxygen in the atmosphere; to provide a buffer and screen against noise pollution; to provide protection against severe weather; to aid in the control of drainage and restoration of denuded soil subsequent to construction or grading; to provide a haven for wildlife; to protect and increase property values; to conserve and enhance the physical environment and aesthetics; and promote the general welfare and enhance the quality of life of the citizens for present and future generations by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs, and other plants within the city. 
Sec. 14-60. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Person means any public or private individual, group, company, firm, corporation, partnership, association, society or any other combination of human being whether legal or natural. 
    Shrub means any woody plant in a public place that remains low and produces shoots or trunks from the base. 
    Street trees means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
    Tree means any tree or shrub pruned tree form in a public place. 
Sec. 14-61. - Tree and shrub species to be planted. 
    The following list constitutes the recommended tree and shrub species for the city: 
(1)	Small trees. 
Crape Myrtle. 
Deciduous Holly. 
Eastern Redbud. 
Grancy Graybeard. 
Japanese Magnolia. 
Little Gem Magnolia. 
Ornamental Magnolias. 
Smoketree. 
Southern Crabapple. 
Two-wing Silverbell. 
Wax Myrtle. 
Winged Sumac. 
(2)	Medium trees. 
American Holly. 
Cherry Laurel. 
Chinese Elm. 
Eastern Red Cedar. 
Flowering Dogwood. 
River Birch. 
Sweet bay Magnolia. 
(3)	Large trees. 
American Sycamore. 
Bald Cypress. 
Cedar Elm. 
Red Maple. 
Silver Maple. 
Southern Magnolia. 
Tulip Tree. 
Black Gum. 
Cherrybark Oak. 
Live Oak. 
Nuttall Oak. 
Overcup Oak. 
Pin Oak. 
Swamp Chestnut Oak. 
Water Oak. 
Willow Oak. 
(4)	Shrubs and grasses. 
Abelia. 
Aucuba. 
Azalea. 
Boxwood. 
Camellia. 
Cleyera. 
Fatsia. 
Forsythia. 
Gardenia. 
Holly. 
Indian Hawthorne. 
Itea. 
Juniper. 
Liriope. 
Lorapetulum. 
Mahonia. 
Muhly Grass. 
Nandina. 
Oakleaf Hydrangea. 
Oleander. 
Pittosporum. 
Rose. 
Rosemary. 
Spiraea. 
Tea Olive. 
Viburnum. 
Sec. 14-62. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 14-61 and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, 30 feet; medium trees, 40 feet; and large trees, 50 feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
Sec. 14-63. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 14-61, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; and large trees, four feet. 
Sec. 14-64. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet of any fireplug. 
Sec. 14-65. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 14-61 may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
Sec. 14-66. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, parks, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with sections 14-61 through 14-65. 
Sec. 14-67. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this ordinance at the determination of the tree board. 
Sec. 14-68. - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased, or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
Sec. 14-69. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The tree board will notify, in writing, the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners, at their own expense, within 60 days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the owners' property tax notice. 
Sec. 14-70. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
Sec. 14-71. - Interference with tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this article. 
Sec. 14-72. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of planting, cutting, trimming, pruning, removing, spraying, or otherwise treating trees or shrubs within the city without first producing evidence of a license from the state department of agriculture and commerce's bureau of plant industry. No license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. 
Sec. 14-73. - Appeal. 
    Any person may appeal any ruling or order of the tree board to the city council, who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
Sec. 14-74. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, shall be punished as provided for in section 1-4. 
Chapter 16 - FIRE PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority, MCA 1972, § 21-19-21; enacting fire regulations, MCA 1972, § 21-19-21; adoption of technical codes, MCA 1972, § 21-19-25; fire departments and fire districts, MCA 1972, § 21-25-1 et seq.; Mississippi Fire Prevention Code, MCA 1972, § 45-1-101 et seq.; municipal authority to establish fire limits and certain fire-related regulations, MCA 1972, § 21-19-21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fireworks. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, possess for the purpose of sale, or to use by shooting or exploding any fire crackers, Roman candles, torpedoes, sky rockets or any explosives commonly known and referred to as fireworks, except and not including toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices in which paper caps manufactured in accordance with United States Interstate Commerce Commission regulations for packing and shipping of toy paper caps are used and toy pistol paper caps manufactured as provided herein by state statute within the city. 
(b)	The provisions of this section shall not prohibit the public shooting of fireworks or any fireworks display that may be exhibited under controlled supervision which may be a part of any public entertainment sponsored by the chamber of commerce or any other public civic organization or in connection with any trade carnival, winter carnival or other public spectacle first approved by the chief of police that may be held within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8-1; Ord. of 11-2-1956, §§ 1, 3) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, MCA 1972, § 21-19-15; state regulations, MCA 1972, § 45-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 16-2. - False alarm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to turn in a false fire alarm. 
(Code 1977, § 8-2; Ord. of 1-13-2014, § 1) 
Sec. 16-3. - Fire calls outside the city; determination of fees and conditions. 
(a)	There will be a charge, in an amount established from time to time, payable to the city for answering a fire call involving the dispatching of a fire truck to any location within the county. 
(b)	There will be a charge, in an amount established from time to time, payable to the city for answering a fire call involving the dispatching of a fire truck to any location outside the county. 
(c)	There will be no charge made for answering calls and dispatching firefighters and equipment to churches, schools, nursing homes and publicly owned properties within the county. 
(d)	There will be no dispatching of firefighters or equipment to locations outside the city limits if the situation exists that such action would endanger the fire protection within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8-3; Ord. of 10-27-1978, § 5; Ord. of 9-15-1987, § 1) 
Secs. 16-4-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Rules and regulations for Mississippi Fire Prevention Code, 19 Miss. Admin. Code, Pt. 7, R. 7.01-7.14. 

Sec. 16-26. - Fire code enforced. 
    The city shall enforce the fire code noted and adopted in chapter 8. The chief of the fire department shall recommend any amendments to the fire code, which, in the chief's judgment, shall be desirable. 
Sec. 16-27. - Establishment and duties of fire marshal. 
(a)	The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the fire marshal of the city. 
(b)	The chief of the fire department may appoint such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall be from time to time necessary. 
(c)	A report of the fire marshal shall be made annually and transmitted to the mayor containing all proceedings under the code, with such statistics as the fire marshal may wish to include therein. 
(Code 1977, § 8-21; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 2; Ord. of 2-15-1982, § 1) 
Sec. 16-28. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Corporation council, when used in the fire prevention code, means the attorney for the city. 
    Municipality, when used in the fire prevention code, means this city. 
(Code 1977, § 8-22; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 3) 
Sec. 16-29. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is to be prohibited. 
(a)	The limits referred to in the fire prevention code, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: The entire city. 
(b)	Exceptions to this section may be obtained only for bulk storage of special industrial explosives by companies conducting manufacturing operations in the Greenwood-Leflore Industrial Park. Permits for such storage of explosives shall be issued by the community development division on a case-by-case basis only in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)	The requesting company shall submit plans for construction of a special storage facility to the community development division. 
(2)	The construction and installation of said storage facilities shall be in accordance with the adopted fire code. 
(3)	Upon approval of the completed storage facilities by the community development division as complying with the above-referenced code, and adequate to prevent theft of the explosives, a permit be shall issued. 
(Code 1977, § 8-23; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 4; Ord. of 3-16-1993) 
Sec. 16-30. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is to be prohibited. 
(a)	The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: The entire city; provided, however, this prohibition shall not apply to such storage in outside aboveground tanks that were used for such purposes as of the adoption of a prior ordinance on February 2, 1962. 
(b)	The limits referred to in the fire prevention code, in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited, are hereby established as follows: The city limits, except, however, that new bulk plants may be allowed on a case-by-case basis; provided that such plants be underground installations only located in areas zoned for light industry; installed in accordance with NFPA 30, Flammable and Combustible Liquids Code and all state and federal environmental laws concerning underground fuel storage tanks; and that complete plans for construction be submitted to the city inspector division for consideration of the building permit. 
(c)	Within that area known as the Greenwood-Leflore Industrial Park, above ground fuel storage tanks and new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids may be permitted upon a case by case basis. 
(Code 1977, § 8-24; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 5; Ord. of 12-19-1989, § 1; Ord. of 2-15-1994; Ord. of 12-16-1997; Res. of 8-17-1999, § (A)) 
Sec. 16-31. - Establishment of limits in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases is to be restricted. 
    The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as follows: The entire city; provided, however, such restrictions shall not apply to bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases in locations in existence on February 2, 1962. 
(Code 1977, § 8-25; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 6) 
Sec. 16-32. - Establishment of motor vehicle routes for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents. 
    The routes referred to in the fire prevention code for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are hereby established as follows: Designated, marked truck routes. 
(Code 1977, § 8-26; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 7) 
Sec. 16-33. - Establishment of motor vehicle routes for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals or other dangerous articles. 
    The routes referred to in the fire prevention code for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows: Designated, marked truck routes. 
(Code 1977, § 8-27; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 8) 
Sec. 16-34. - Fire lanes on private property. 
(a)	The marking of fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use, shall be approved by the fire chief and the chief of police and they shall have the power to modify fire lanes to meet the needs of a particular structure. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department and the chief of police to establish fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use, where the parking of motor vehicles or other obstructions may interfere with the ingress and egress of fire department vehicles for the protection of persons and property, such as at shopping centers, bowling lanes, theaters, hospitals, churches and similar locations. 
(c)	Parking of motor vehicles or otherwise obstructing fire lanes is prohibited at all times. 
(d)	The following locations have designated fire lanes in effect and are hereby designated by the chief of police and the fire chief in accordance with best practices for the marking and designation of fire lanes: 
(1)	Fire Station No. 1 on Main Street. 
(2)	Fire Station No. 2 on Carrollton Avenue. 
(3)	Fire Station No. 3 on Tallahatchie Street. 
(4)	Fire Station No. 4 on Highway 7 North. 
(5)	Highland Park Shopping Center on Park Avenue. 
(6)	Greenwood Mall Shopping Center on Park Avenue. 
(7)	Greenwood Marketplace on Park Avenue. 
(8)	Village Shopping Center on Highway 82. 
(9)	Leflore Lanes on Highway 82. 
(10)	Eastgate Shopping Center on Highway 82. 
(11)	Greenwood West Shopping Center on Highway 82. 
(12)	Walmart Supercenter on Highway 82. 
(e)	Violations of this section will be enforced by the police department and such violations will be considered as other unauthorized parking violations of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8-28; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 9; Ord. of 5-8-1974; Res. of 1-19-1999) 
Sec. 16-35. - Modifications. 
    The fire marshal shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the fire marshal thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1977, § 8-30; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 11) 
Sec. 16-36. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the fire marshal shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire marshal to the council within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1977, § 8-31; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 12) 
Sec. 16-37. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
    The mayor, the chief of the fire department and the fire marshal shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in said code. The fire marshal shall post such list in a conspicuous place in fire marshal's office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1977, § 8-32; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 13) 
Sec. 16-38. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the council, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each such violation and noncompliance respectively, be punished as provided in section 1-4. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	The application of the penalty described in subsection (a) of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1977, § 8-33; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 14) 
Sec. 16-39. - Repeal of conflicting ordinances. 
    All former ordinances or parts thereof conflicting or inconsistent with the provisions of the code hereby adopted are hereby repealed. 
(Code 1977, § 8-34; Ord. of 6-9-1971, § 15) 
Chapter 18 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Statutory authorization. 
    The state legislature has, in title 17, chapter 1, Mississippi Code of 1972 Annotated delegated the responsibility to local government units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the council of the city does hereby adopt the following floodplain management regulations. 
(Res. of 5-15-2012, exh. A(art. 1, § A)) 
Sec. 18-2. - Findings of fact. 
(a)	The city is subject to periodic inundation, which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)	These flood losses are caused by the cumulative effect of obstructions, both inside and outside the identified special flood hazard areas, causing increases in flood heights and velocities and by the occupancy in flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods or hazardous to other lands which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages. 
(Res. of 5-15-2012, exh. A(art. 1, § B)) 
Sec. 18-3. - Statement of purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)	Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety, and property due to water or erosion hazards, which result in damaging increases in erosion or in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)	Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(3)	Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters; 
(4)	Control filling, grading, dredging, and other development which may increase erosion or flood damage; and 
(5)	Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
(Res. of 5-15-2012, exh. A(art. 1, § C)) 
Sec. 18-4. - Objectives. 
    The objectives of this chapter are: 
(1)	To protect human life and health; 
(2)	To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(3)	To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(4)	To minimize prolonged business interruptions; 
(5)	To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(6)	To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of floodprone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; and 
(7)	To ensure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a floodprone area. 
(Res. of 5-15-2012, exh. A(art. 1, § D)) 
Sec. 18-5. - Methods of reducing flood losses. 
    In order to accomplish its purposes, this chapter includes methods and provisions for: 
(1)	Restricting or prohibiting uses which are dangerous to health, safety, and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which result in damaging increases in erosion or in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)	Requiring that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(3)	Controlling the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which help accommodate or channel floodwaters; 
(4)	Controlling filling, grading, dredging, and other development which may increase flood damage; and 
(5)	Preventing or regulating the construction of flood barriers that will unnaturally divert floodwaters or may increase flood hazards in other areas. 
(Res. of 5-15-2012, exh. A(art. 1, § E)) 
Sec. 18-6. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A Zone is the area of special flood hazard without base flood elevations determined. 
    A99 Zone is that part of the SFHA inundated by the one percent chance flood to be protected from the one percent chance flood by a federal flood protection system or levee under construction, no base flood elevations are determined.
