(2)	No person, other than employees of the city or employees of Greenwood Utilities who are engaged in their official duties, shall go upon any park, playground, or other facility managed, owned or operated by the city except between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. without the written authority and approval of the city. 
(3)	Notwithstanding the above, the mayor may limit, change, modify and set different hours of openings and closings for the operation of any swimming pool, playground, pavilion, or youth center operated or managed by the city. 
(4)	No glass or ceramic object of any kind or nature shall be taken into or possessed in any park, playground, swimming pool or any other public recreational facility without prior express written permission of the public works director. 
(b)	Regulation of vehicles. 
(1)	No person, except employees of the city or Greenwood Utilities engaged in official business or as authorized below, shall drive, park or operate any motor vehicle of any kind, including, but not limited to, motorcycles, go-carts, all-terrain vehicles, scooters, automobiles, or trucks on any part of the grounds, walks, pathways, or drives of any park, playground, or other facility managed, owned or operated by the city. 
(2)	The mayor is authorized to establish rules and regulations regarding the parking and operation of vehicles within parks and playgrounds, which regulations may include the designation of certain areas as public parking areas and the issuing of permits to drive vehicles within said parks and playgrounds. 
(c)	Permits. 
(1)	Area or facility permit. No person or group shall have the exclusive use of any specified area or facility located in any park, playground or other facility managed, owned or operated by the city, without first having obtained an area or facility permit issued by the public works department. The issuance by the public works department of an area or facility permit allows the group to which the permit is issued to have the exclusive use and control, subject to the rules of the department, of the area or facility designated in the permit. Permit fees shall be as established from time to time. 
(2)	Concessions permit. 
a.	Except as set forth herein, all concessions permits shall authorize the exclusive right to offer for sale to the general public food, beverages, and other items and may be issued by the public works department either separately or in conjunction with an area or facility permit. No person shall offer for sale to the general public food, beverages, or other items without first having obtained a concessions permit issued by the department. 
b.	Nonexclusive concessions permits may be issued by the department when consented to and approved by the sponsors of the league, team, or persons in charge of coordinating the program or activity permitted by the area or facility permit. 
(d)	Violation; penalty. 
(1)	Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section, or who fails to comply therewith, shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(2)	Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section, or who fails to comply therewith, may also be temporarily suspended or permanently prohibited, by order of the director, from thereafter using any and/or all public recreational facilities. A violation of any such order shall also be a violation of this section and may be punishable as such. 
(Code 1977, § 14-3; Ord. of 6-12-1980, §§ 1-4; Ord. of 11-19-1985, § 1; Ord. of 6-17-1986, § 1; Ord. of 3-16-1999) 
Chapter 28 - SOLID WASTE AND RECYCLING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate removal, MCA 1972, § 21-19-1; disposal systems, MCA 1972, § 21-27-11 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-4. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 28-5. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building debris means any debris, including scrap lumber, plaster, roofing concrete, brickbats, sand, and spoil, resulting from site preparation, construction, repair, remodeling, or demolition of any building or appurtenances on private property. 
    Bulky wastes means items of solid waste that due to their large size or weight are not or cannot be handled by the general collection service. 
    Collection service fee means a monthly charge or fee for all solid waste collection services rendered a particular residential, commercial, industrial, or institutional location. 
    Collector, professional private means a private business engaged in the collection and disposal of refuse for a profit. 
    Construction and demolition waste means all types of rejected, damaged, or discarded building materials, surplus earth spoil, vegetation, or other solid waste matter resulting from site preparation, construction, repair, remodeling, or demolition of any building or structure. 
    Containers means locally-approved metal or plastic receptacles used for the temporary storage of solid waste awaiting collection. 
    Director means the director of the public works department for the city. 
    Garbage or food wastes means rejected vegetable, fruit, and animal matter resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and serving of foods. 
    Hazardous waste means rejected chemical compounds, mixtures, substances, or articles which may constitute a hazard to health or may cause damage to property by reason of being explosive, flammable, poisonous, corrosive, unstable, irritating, radioactive, or otherwise harmful. The term "hazardous waste" specifically includes pathological wastes, herbicides and pesticides. 
    Incinerator means any device used for the burning of solid wastes where the factors of combustion, such as temperature, retention time, turbulence, and combustion air can be controlled. 
    Industrial solid waste means all solid waste created by or resulting from manufacturing operations or machinery, heavy equipment, vehicle repair or modification, or other industrial operations. 
    Litter means any quantity of uncontainerized paper, metal, plastic, glass or miscellaneous solid waste which may be classed as trash, debris, rubbish, refuse, garbage, or junk. 
    Office of pollution control means the office of pollution control of the state department of environmental quality. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Putrescible matter means wastes capable of being decomposed by micro-organisms with sufficient rapidity as to cause nuisances from odors, gases, and other objectionable conditions. Food wastes, offal, and dead animals are examples of putrescible components of solid waste. 
    Refuse or solid waste means all useless, unwanted or discarded materials of the community and includes semi-liquid or wet wastes with insufficient liquid content to be free-flowing. 
    Rubbish means solid waste from residences, commercial establishments, and institutions that does not contain food waste or ashes. 
    Yard rubbish means the grass clippings, hedge cuttings, limbs, leaves and other discarded materials from yards and gardens. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-1) 
Sec. 28-6. - Exclusive collection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the city to engage in the business of collecting, removing and disposing of garbage and rubbish in the city, for others, except those private collectors specifically authorized by a permit issued by the city, with the following exception: Any person may collect and transport any or all solid waste exclusive of hazardous waste originating on his or her own property or resulting from the operation of the business or the service provided to an approved disposal site without securing a private collectors permit. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-2) 
Sec. 28-7. - Jurisdiction of director of public works department. 
    The removal, disposition, and management of all solid waste disposals in the city shall be under the jurisdiction of the director of the public works department. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-3) 
Sec. 28-8. - Rules and regulations to implement articles. 
    The director of the public works department, subject to the approval of the mayor, may make such rules and regulations as are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter as may be necessary or desirable to aid in the administration of and obtaining compliance with the provisions of the chapter which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-4) 
Sec. 28-9. - Collection and disposal of hazardous wastes, pathogenic wastes, and biohazardous wastes. 
(a)	Hazardous wastes. All hazardous wastes shall be disposed of by the industry, manufacturer, processing plant, laboratory, or institution generating such wastes under such methods and conditions as shall been approved by the bureau of pollution control. 
(b)	Pathogenic, radioactive, and infectious medical wastes. All pathogenic, radioactive, and infectious medical wastes shall be disposed of by the hospital or institution generating such wastes under such conditions as shall be approved by the office of pollution control. 
(c)	Biohazardous and medical wastes. All biohazardous and medical wastes shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the office of pollution control. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-5) 
Sec. 28-10. - Solid waste storage containers. 
(a)	Low density residential. The city will provide municipally owned solid waste storage containers to low density residential households, including single-family dwellings and two-family dwellings. Containers will be designed to be emptied mechanically by specially designed and constructed vehicles and will be available in either a 95-gallon or 65-gallon capacity. Users of municipally owned solid waste storage containers shall be responsible for placing all bagged solid waste in the containers and removal of all litter from the vicinity of the container. Lids shall remain closed and secured at all times, except while the container is being emptied. Any container furnished by the city shall remain the property of the city and may be removed from any premises when its use in that location is no longer considered advantageous to the city. Users of municipally owned solid waste storage containers shall pay a replacement fee equal to the actual cost of the container if it is lost or stolen from the user's property. 
(b)	High density residential. The city may, at its own option, elect to furnish a container or containers for the storage of solid waste at apartment houses, tenements, trailer parks, or other high density residential developments. Any container furnished by the city shall remain the property of the city and may be removed from any premises when its use in that location is no longer considered advantageous to the city. Users of municipally owned bulk containers shall reduce all solid waste placed in bulk containers to the smallest volume readily attainable by hand (i.e., all cartons, boxes, or other containers shall be dismantled, cut apart, or otherwise broken down and flattened). All food waste and other putrescible matter deposited for collection in bulk containers must be placed in wet proof paper or plastic bags or containers. 
(c)	Commercial, industrial, institutional. The city will provide municipally owned solid waste storage containers to commercial, industrial, and institutional establishments when requested to do so. Containers will be designed to be emptied mechanically by specially designed and constructed vehicles. Users of mechanically emptied solid waste storage containers shall be responsible for placing all solid waste in the containers and removal of all litter from the vicinity of the container. Commercial, industrial, and institutional establishments may choose to provide their own containers. Any such containers shall conform to the requirements for commercial or residential solid waste storage containers, and be compatible with the equipment in use by the city. 
(d)	Assignment and use of municipally owned solid waste storage containers. The director of the public works department is authorized and responsible for the assignment of municipally owned solid waste storage containers for the exclusive use of residential, commercial, industrial, and institutional entities. The use of such containers by any person or corporate entity other than the designated user is prohibited and is a violation of this chapter and subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-6) 
Sec. 28-11. - Location of storage containers. 
(a)	Front of residence. Where collection of solid waste is made from the front of residence or place of business, solid waste storage containers shall be placed within five feet of the curbline in front of the residence or place of business, but not in the street or gutter. All solid waste storage containers shall be removed from the front of residence or place of business within 24 hours of the time of collection. 
(b)	Alley. Where collection is made from the alley, solid waste containers shall be placed within five feet of, but not within, the traveled portion of the alley, unless otherwise directed by the director of the public works department. Solid waste containers placed along or adjacent to an alley shall be located so as not to interfere with maintenance or drainage of the alley or roadway. 
(c)	Time of placement, protection from animals. Solid waste containers shall be placed for collection on mornings when collection are scheduled or on the night preceding a scheduled collection. Lids must remain closed and secured, and suitable protection must be provided to deter scavenging by animals. 
(d)	Back or side of residence. Where collection of solid waste is made from the back or side yard of a residence or place of business further than five feet from the property line in front of the residence or place of business, solid waste containers shall be placed in such a manner as to not require the opening of any door or gate. Such location shall be at a higher fee than normal residential collection. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-7) 
Sec. 28-12. - Preparation of household solid waste for collection. 
    Garbage and other household refuse shall be drained of excess fluids and placed within refuse storage bags, or other containers, and these bags or containers shall be securely tied or fastened so as to prevent spillage, entry by animals or the seepage of water into them. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-8) 
Sec. 28-13. - Yard rubbish. 
    Grass cuttings, hedge cuttings, leaves and other yard rubbish shall be placed within refuse storage bags or other containers and securely tied or fastened to prevent spillage or other entrance of water into the containers. Heavy or bulky items such as discarded furniture or appliances, tree trimmings, large accumulations of hedge cuttings, or other yard debris shall be cut, where appropriate, into lengths not to exceed four feet and placed within five feet of the traveled portion of a street or alley in a uniform and even manner in a single pile so that the same may be conveniently collected with a boom mounted mechanical grapple. It shall be unlawful for such waste matter to be placed in side drain ditches, gutters, or on the traveled portion of a street or alley. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-9) 
Sec. 28-14. - Schedule of collections. 
    Household solid waste, including garbage and yard rubbish, will be collected in residential areas on designated collection days. Additional collections may be made where considered necessary by the director of the public works department. Collection of solid waste from commercial, industrial, and institutional locations shall be made at such frequency as is determined to be appropriate by the director of the public works department according to the needs of each individual business, industry, or institution. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-10) 
Sec. 28-15. - Sanitary landfills and other places of disposal. 
(a)	The city may establish public sanitary landfills and or other disposal sites as may be necessary, and no person shall use or be permitted to use any sanitary landfill or other disposal site except with the approval of the director of the public works department in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated under this chapter. 
(b)	The director of the public works department shall be authorized to promulgate reasonable rules, regulations, and fees for the collection at landfills, incinerators, or other disposal sites. The director of the public works department shall also make reasonable rules and regulations that shall be necessary to carry out the inspection, supervision, and enforcement of use fees. 
(c)	Dirt, gravel, broken bricks, concrete, rock, asphalt, and similar material deemed by the director of the public works department to be suitable materials for landfill use may be exempted from the use fee by the director of the public works department. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-11) 
Sec. 28-16. - Solid waste collection fee schedule. 
(a)	The solid waste collection fee schedule is adopted from time to time by the city council for the collection of solid waste in the city. 
(b)	If there is an increase in the frequency, volume, or time required for the collection of solid waste, there shall be a surcharge calculated by the public works director as an appropriate percentage of the base fee set forth in the schedule of fees. In such cases, individual residents and businesses shall be notified of the surcharge by the public works director. 
(Ord. of 9-6-2016, § 10-12) 
Sec. 28-17. - Billing of service fee. 
(a)	The service fee for the removal of residential solid waste by the director of the public works department is mandatory for residential utility customers and shall be included as a separate item each month on the bills rendered by Greenwood Utilities. Where said fees are payable, said charges shall be rendered on the first bill of the division sent on and after the first day of the month following the adoption of this chapter, and for each month thereafter. 
(b)	All persons receiving solid waste disposal service by the city who are not customers of Greenwood Utilities shall be billed separately by the city. The service fee for removal of commercial, industrial, and institutional solid waste shall be billed monthly. Checks should be made payable to the city. The service fee for commercial, industrial, or institutional solid waste may be included in Greenwood Utilities' bills. Failure to pay the service fee within 30 days after the due date of the utility statement or service fee bills shall be grounds for suspension of solid waste disposal services or the city may proceed to recover the amount of any such delinquency, with interest, in a civil action, or both. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-13) 
Sec. 28-18. - Responsibility for collection charges. 
    In the case of premises containing more than one dwelling unit or place of business, and each is billed separately for utilities by Greenwood Utilities, such fees shall be billed to the person in possession, charge, or control who is the customer of Greenwood Utilities. In the case of premises containing more than one dwelling unit or place of business which are served by a single utility bill, so that the occupants or tenants cannot be billed separately by Greenwood Utilities, such fees as are prescribed by this chapter shall be billed by Greenwood Utilities to the customer of the single utility bill who shall be liable for the service fee for said premises. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-14) 
Sec. 28-19. - Lawn service provider; duty to remove yard rubbish. 
    Every person who cuts trees, trims shrubs, cuts grass, or collects leaves as an independent contractor shall remove or cause to be removed all such rubbish from the premises serviced by him. An independent contractor is considered to be any person who performs a service for a fixed price or fee. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-15) 
Sec. 28-20. - Building debris, industrial solid waste; responsibility for removal. 
    Building debris and industrial solid waste shall not be removed by the public works department, and the owner shall cause such materials and waste to be privately removed. In the event the public works department is required to remove such building debris or industrial solid waste, the cost of such removal shall be charged back to the individual property owner. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-16) 
Sec. 28-21. - Transportation of solid waste. 
    Any vehicle used for the transportation of solid waste matter on the streets of the city or to any municipal disposal site shall be enclosed at the sides and back or equipped with a tarpaulin or other methods established by the director of the public works department so as to reasonably avoid spilling garbage or waste, disseminating odors, and attracting insects. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-17) 
Sec. 28-22. - Private collection permits. 
(a)	Generally. When private collection services are considered to be in the public interest, upon application by prospective collectors, the director of the public works department may recommend to the mayor that such service be provided by a private collector in accordance with rules and regulations established by the mayor for private collection permit holders. There shall be a charge of $500.00 per year for a permit. Applicants for private collection permits shall apply to the city clerk's office. 
(b)	Payment bond. The city shall require of each private collector a bond to secure the payment fees, inspection fees, and sanitary fill or use fees. Said bond shall be in an amount determined by the director of the public works department. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-18) 
Sec. 28-23. - Nuisances prohibited, compliance with chapter required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in possession, charge of, or control of any premises to keep, cause to be kept, or allow the keeping on any premises within the corporate limits of the city of any solid waste, in such a manner that will become offensive or deleterious to health or likely to cause disease or injury and the same is hereby declared a public nuisance. The depositing or causing to be deposited of any manner of solid waste or litter upon the paved portion of the city streets and the travelled way of alleys or on other public areas is likewise declared a public nuisance. The office of pollution control, police department, community development division, and supervisory employees of the public works department are hereby authorized to inspect any premises in the city and its police jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing the requirements of this chapter. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-19) 
Sec. 28-24. - Employees and vehicles of the public works department not to be impeded in their duties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to impede or interfere with any of the employees or vehicles of the public works department engaged in the performance of services and duties of that department under the provisions of this chapter. Vehicles or other objects which block access of the public works department employees or equipment to solid waste containers or to free passage along collection routes shall be removed at the request of the public works department employees at the expense of the property owner. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-20) 
Sec. 28-25. - Place or disposal of waste materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of or cause to be disposed of any garbage, rubbish or other waste materials upon any property other than a sanitary landfill or other disposal site so designated by the city, except that special permits may be issued by the public works department for the depositing of waste materials at other approved locations. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-21) 
Sec. 28-26. - Littering prohibited. 
    It shall be a violation for any person to place any garbage, straw, dirt, chips, shells, nails, iron, glass, vegetable materials, paper, or other rubbish or noxious substance on any street, sidewalk, alley, public park, or other public place in the city or on the property of another person, or to violate any of the requirements of this chapter which relate to littering. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-22) 
Sec. 28-27. - Dead animals. 
    Dead animals, such as cats, dogs, or other of similar size will be picked up once daily on regular weekdays in response to calls made to the animal control officer. Dead animals must be placed adjacent to a street or alley for collection. Animals weighing in excess of 70 pounds shall be removed to the city disposal site by the owner. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-23) 
Sec. 28-28. - Fish and poultry houses. 
    The city sanitation department will not collect refuse from fish and poultry handling and vending establishments or from egg or poultry hatcheries. Operators of these establishments shall transport such refuse to the sanitary landfill or other disposal site during hours of operation of the disposal site and effect disposal of it as directed. Such refuse may be otherwise disposed of by the owner in a manner so as not to create a nuisance upon written approval of the director of the public works department. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-24) 
Sec. 28-29. - Occupant's responsibility for cleanliness, sanitation and fire prevention. 
    All occupants of residences and business places shall be held responsible for the cleanliness of their premises and of sidewalks and alleys immediately adjacent to the premises. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to burn any solid waste matter within the corporate limits of the city, except in incinerators that have been first approved for such purposes by the director of the public works department of the city and after a permit for use of same has been issued by the director of the public works department. Such incinerators must also receive approval of the bureau of pollution control or its successor. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-25) 
Sec. 28-30. - Hazardous waste. 
    Any hazardous waste, as defined herein, approved for disposal in a disposal site operated by the city, shall be transported by its owner or agents of its owner to the city sanitary landfill or other authorized city disposal site and disposed of in the manner specified by the city employee in charge. Some hazardous wastes may be excluded from the city's sanitary landfill. Disposal of such waste shall be in accordance with section 28-29. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-26) 
Sec. 28-31. - Sanitation services subject to office of pollution control regulations. 
    The handling, collection and disposal of all solid wastes shall be subject to the regulations of the office of pollution control which is charged with the duty of insuring that the public health shall not be endangered in the handling, storage, or disposal of such refuse matter. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-27) 
Sec. 28-32. - Penalties. 
    Any person who fails, neglects, or refuses to comply with the terms and provisions of any section, subsection, or part of this chapter or who in any way violates any of the terms or provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. Each 24-hour period after receiving notification such person shall fail to comply with any terms or provision of any section, subsection, or part of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-29) 
Sec. 28-33. - Non-typical sewer rates. 
    The following rate structure for liquid wastes hauled to and disposed of at the city waste water treatment plant or other approved location in the sanitary sewer system is established. A volumetric charge for all non-typical liquid waste disposed of at the city sewage treatment plant or other approved location shall be established as follows: 
(1)	For all liquid waste permitted by the state department of environmental quality, tested prior to discharge, from a single source, hauled to and discharged at the sewage treatment plant or a location in the sanitary sewer system known approved by the public works director, and a sewage treatment plant manifest completed for each load, a rate of $0.05 per gallon. 
(2)	For all liquid was not permitted by the state department of environmental quality, tested prior to discharge and determined by sewage treatment plant personnel to be nonhazardous to the operation of the sewage treatment plant, from a single source, hauled to and discharged at a location known and approved by the public works director, and a sewer treatment plant manifest completed for each load, a rate of $0.05 per gallon. 
(Res. of 3-17-2015(02), § 10-31) 
Sec. 28-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECYCLING 

Sec. 28-35. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means the director of the recycling department for the city. 
    Materials recovery facility means any specialized plant that receives, separates, and prepares recyclable materials for marketing to end-user manufacturers. 
    Office of pollution control means the office of pollution control of the state department of environmental quality. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Recyclable materials or recyclables means any material that is able to be recycled, including, but not limited to aluminum, steel, paper, cardboard, and certain types of plastic. 
    Recycle means to treat or process used or waste materials so as to make them suitable for reuse. 
    Recycling containers means locally-approved metal or plastic receptacles used for the temporary storage of recyclables awaiting collection. 
Sec. 28-36. - Exclusive collection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the city to engage in the business of collecting, removing and disposing of recyclables in the city, for others, except those private collectors specifically authorized by a permit issued by the city, with the following exception: Any person may collect and transport any or all recyclables originating on his or her own property or resulting from the operation of his or her business or the service he or she renders to an approved materials recovery facility without securing a private collectors permit. 
Sec. 28-37. - Jurisdiction of director of recycling department. 
    The collection, removal, disposition, and management of all recyclable materials in the city shall be under the jurisdiction of the director of the recycling department. 
Sec. 28-38. - Rules and regulations. 
    The director of the recycling department, subject to the approval of the mayor, may make such rules and regulations as are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter as may be necessary or desirable to aid in the administration of and obtaining compliance with the provisions of the chapter which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 28-39. - Recycling containers. 
(a)	Low density residential. The city will provide municipally owned recycling containers to low density residential households, including single family dwellings and two-family dwellings. Users of municipally owned recycling containers shall be responsible for placing all recyclables in the containers. Any container furnished by the city shall remain the property of the city and may be removed from any premises when its use in that location is no longer considered advantageous to the city. Users of municipally owned recycling containers shall pay a replacement fee equal to the actual cost of the container if it is lost or stolen from the user's property. 
(b)	High density residential. The city may, at its own option, elect to furnish a container or containers for the storage of recyclables at apartment houses, tenements, trailer parks, or other high density residential developments. Any container furnished by the city shall remain the property of the city and may be removed from any premises when its use in that location is no longer considered advantageous to the city. Users of municipally owned recycling containers shall reduce all recyclables to the smallest volume readily attainable by hand (i.e., all cartons, boxes, or other containers shall be dismantled, cut apart, or otherwise broken down and flattened). 
(c)	Assignment and use of municipally owned solid waste storage containers. The director of the recycling department is authorized and responsible for the assignment of municipally owned recycling containers for the exclusive use of residential, commercial, industrial, and institutional entities. The use of such containers by any person or corporate entity other than the designated user or users is prohibited and is a violation of this chapter and subject to the penalties provided herein. 
Sec. 28-40. - Location of recycling containers. 
(a)	Front of residence. Where collection of recyclables is made from the front of residence or place of business, recycling containers shall be placed within five feet of the curb line in front of the residence or place of business, but not in the street or gutter. All recycling containers shall be removed from the front of residence or place of business within 24 hours of the time of collection. 
(b)	Alley. Where collection is made from the alley, recycling containers shall be placed within five feet of, but not within, the traveled portion of the alley, unless otherwise directed by the director of the recycling department. Recycling containers placed along or adjacent to an alley shall be located so as not to interfere with maintenance or drainage of the alley or roadway. 
(c)	Time of placement, protection from animals. Recycling containers shall be placed for collection on mornings when collection is scheduled or on the night preceding a scheduled collection. 
(d)	Back or side of residence. Where collection of recyclables is made from the back or side yard of a residence or place of business further than five feet from the property line in front of the residence or place of business, recycling containers shall be placed in such a manner as to not require the opening of any door or gate. 
Sec. 28-41. - Schedule of collections. 
    Recyclables will be collected in residential areas on designated collection days. Additional collections may be made where considered necessary by the director of the recycling department. Collection of recyclables from commercial, industrial, and institutional locations shall be made at such frequency as is determined to be appropriate by the director of the recycling department according to the needs of each individual business, industry, or institution. 
Sec. 28-42. - Recycling collection fee schedule. 
    A fee schedule may be adopted from time to time by the city for the collection of recyclables. 
Sec. 28-43. - Unlawful interference with department employees and vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to impede or interfere with any of the employees or vehicles of the recycling department engaged in the performance of services and duties of that department under the provisions of this chapter. Vehicles or other objects which block access of the recycling department employees or equipment to recycling containers or to free passage along collection routes shall be removed at the request of the recycling department employees at the expense of the property owner. 
Sec. 28-44. - Recycling services subject to office of pollution control regulations. 
    The handling, collection, and disposal of all recyclables shall be subject to the regulations of the office of pollution control which is charged with the duty of insuring that the public health shall not be endangered in the handling, storage, or disposal of such matter. 
Sec. 28-45. - Penalties. 
    Any person who fails, neglects, or refuses to comply with the terms and provisions of any section, subsection, or part of this chapter or who in any way violates any of the terms or provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-4. Each 24-hour period after receiving notification such person shall fail to comply with any terms or provision of any section, subsection, or part of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation. 
Chapter 30 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PROPERTY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority, MCA 1972, § 21-37-3 et seq.; authority of governing authority to regulate streets, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-1, 21-19-31, use of streets for utilities' purposes, MCA 1972, §§ 21-27-3, 21-27-5, 21-27-7; power to exercise full jurisdiction over streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-3; power to construct and maintain sidewalks, MCA 1972, § 21-37-5; closing streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-7; power to provide street lighting, MCA 1972, § 21-37-11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Building numbering. 
    All persons owning any building in the city are required to have the same numbered, in accordance with the regulation U.S. postal numbers as required by law, in order to secure free mail delivery. 
(Code 1977, § 18-1; Ord. of 7-5-2004) 
Sec. 30-2. - Removal of weeds and grass. 
(a)	Each real estate owner in the city is required to cut down and remove all weeds and grass with a height of more than ten inches that may be growing in front of the owner's property, to the middle of the streets, on receiving notice from the code enforcement officer to do so. 
(b)	Any person failing to cut down and remove said weeds and grass within three days after notice from the code enforcement officer shall, on conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 18-2; Ord. of 9-5-1900; Ord. of 9-16-2014, § 18-2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Sidewalk construction. 
    Those contemplating building sidewalks along the city streets must notify the city clerk and public works director or other designated person and before beginning the construction of same, pay to the city clerk the inspection fees prescribed by the city. All sidewalks are to be constructed according to the specifications prescribed or approved by the public works department. 
(Code 1977, § 18-3; Ord. of 2-20-2017) 
Sec. 30-4. - Building and construction on public property without written permission prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to build, construct, or place anything on public property or to exercise any dominion or control thereover without first having obtained the written permission of the municipal official in charge of that property. If no specific official is in charge, then written permission must be obtained from the mayor. Any violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4. Each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation is committed or continued shall be a separate offense. At the city's election, any violation may be treated as a nuisance and remedied accordingly. All remedies contained within this section shall be cumulative. Pursuit of any one remedy shall not prohibit the city from pursuing any other remedy or remedies provided for. 
(Code 1977, § 18-7; Ord. of 6-16-1987, § 1) 
Sec. 30-5. - Spillage from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person hauling gravel, cinders, brick, coal, sand, dirt, debris, garbage or waste material other than tree limbs and shrubbery, along the public streets or alleys of the city to do so in a vehicle or conveyance not equipped with sufficient flooring and sides, and covered by tarpaulin or similar material, so as to prevent any spillage, waste, or fall of such material, from the conveyance transporting same into the streets or alleys of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-23; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 5; Ord. of 11-17-1992) 
Sec. 30-6. - Draining waste oil into streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or drain, or suffer or permit to be changed or drained oil from the motors of vehicles on or into the streets, alleys, gutters, sidewalks or other public places of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-24; Ord. of 3-4-1930, § 6) 
Sec. 30-7. - Banners, etc., over streets or on electric system poles-Prohibited. 
    Except as provided in section 30-8, it shall be unlawful for any person to place, suspend or maintain, or cause to be placed, suspended or maintained, any sign, banner, picture or other device of any kind above or over any public street of the city, or on or attached to any part of the electric transmission or distribution system of the city, including the wires and poles forming a part thereof. The term "street" as used in this section does not include sidewalks, but shall include the street proper and the ground between any sidewalk and the curb of any street. 
(Code 1977, § 13-11; Ord. of 1-9-1959, §§ 1, 3) 
Sec. 30-8. - Same-Exceptions to prohibition. 
    Nothing contained in section 30-7 shall be construed as prohibiting any holder of a valid franchise from the city from performing any act authorized by such franchise or as prohibiting the city and its employees from suspending Christmas decorations and such other devices as the city desires above and over said public streets and on and attached to said electric transmission or distribution system of said city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-12; Ord. of 1-9-1959, § 2) 
Sec. 30-9. - Distributing advertising matter on streets-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed on any street of the city any printed commercial advertising matter, including what is commonly called "advertising circulars." 
(Code 1977, § 13-13; Ord. of 5-5-1936, § 1) 
Sec. 30-10. - Same-Placing on or in motor vehicles. 
    The placing of advertising circulars or any printed commercial advertising matter on or in vehicles on the streets of the city without first having obtained the consent of the owners thereof, shall be deemed to be a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 13-14; Ord. of 5-5-1936, § 2) 
Sec. 30-11. - Signs, etc., prohibited on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or exhibit any sign, signboard, display board, or any boards of whatever kind on which advertising is done, on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-15; Ord. of 5-1-1928, § 1) 
Secs. 30-12-30-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 30-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person who makes application for a permit. 
    Construction means, but shall not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing or removing signs or facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening, boring and/or cutting into the surface of any part of the right-of-way. 
    Director means the city's community development division. 
    Emergency means any unforeseen circumstance or occurrence, the existent of which constitutes a clear and immediate danger to persons or property. 
    Facility or facilities means the plant and equipment of a public utility and includes property owned, operated, leased, licensed, used, controlled, or supplied for, or in connection with, the business of the public utility. 
    Facilities representative(s ) means the specifically identified agent(s)/employees of a utility who are authorized to direct field activities of that utility and serve as official notice agent(s) for facilities related information. The utility shall be required to make sure at least one of its facilities representatives is available at all times to receive notice of, and immediately direct response to, facilities related Emergencies or situations. 
    Permittee means any person who has been issued a permit and has agreed to fulfill all the terms of this article. 
    Public necessity means the works or improvements required for the protection of the health, welfare, and safety of the public, for which no other reasonable alternative exists. 
    Public utility or utility or user means a person that provides or intends or wishes to provide utility services, and includes but is not limited to any electric utility, gas utility, telecommunications utility, cable company, water utility, or sewer utility. 
    Registration means an authorization which grants permission to conduct specific regulated activities on, in, over, under, or within any rights-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in a written service agreement with the city or in a related provision of this Code of Ordinances. 
    Right-of-way or rights-of-way means real property located within and adjoining the streets, roads and highways within the city, which is owned by the city, county or state or is otherwise maintained by the city, county or state. 
    Service agreement means a valid license agreement, franchise agreement, or operating agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law and accepted by a utility, which allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city. 
    Street is a public street, public easement, public right-of-way, public highway, public alley, public way, or public road accepted or maintained by the city. 
Sec. 30-28. - Exemptions. 
    All street openings required by utilities owned and/or operated by the city shall be made and restored under the direction and supervision of the community development division or under terms of an agreement with the community development division. The permit, fee, deposit, insurance, and bond requirements of this article shall not be applicable to any openings made by such municipally owned or operated utilities. All street openings required by the provisions of this article shall not be applicable in those instances where the highway is maintained by the state or by the county. 
Sec. 30-29. - Utility registration. 
(a)	Registration required . Unless specifically exempted by state or federal law or this Code, each utility that occupies, uses or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived, including by lease, sublease or assignment, must, to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, register by filing a statement ("registration") with the director within 90 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(b)	Registration procedure . The registration filed with the city shall be on a form approved by the city and shall include all of the following, as well as any other information required by the city: 
(1)	The name, legal status (i.e., partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, email address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the utility filing the registration (the "registrant"); 
(2)	If the registrant is not the owner of the facility in the right-of-way, the registration shall include the name, street address, email address if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the facility's owner; 
(3)	The name, street address, email address if applicable and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representative(s). Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representative(s) in an emergency shall be provided at the time of filing a registration and shall be updated as necessary to assure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times; 
(4)	A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Mississippi Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and 
(5)	A copy, if requested, of the legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. 
(c)	Completeness of registration . If a registration is incomplete, the director shall notify the registrant and shall provide a reasonable period of time in which to complete the registration. If a registration is complete, the director shall notify the utility in writing. 
(d)	Acceptance of registration . The city's acceptance of a registration shall indicate the registration is complete. Acceptance of the registration shall not convey title in the rights-of-way. Acceptance of the registration merely provides the registrant with a nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way for the limited purposes stated in the acceptance. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining any permit(s) required by city ordinances nor from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction as required in this article. 
(e)	Facilities in place without registration . Beginning one year after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, any facilities or facility or part of a facility found in a right-of-way for which a registration is required but has not been obtained, unless specifically exempted by law, and for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights provided by city ordinance or otherwise available at law or in equity, including but not limited to abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities, evicting the utility from the right-of-way; and/or prosecuting the violator. 
Sec. 30-30. - Permits for use of the city's rights-of-way. 
(a)	Except as provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to install, construct, move or relocate pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires and other equipment, facilities or appliances upon, under, along, and over the public roads and highways and rights-of-way located within the municipality without first obtaining a right-of-way permit. 
(b)	A request for a right-of-way permit, complete with all information required under this section, must be submitted at least ten working days before the commencement of work proposed in the request, unless waived by the director. The request will be approved or disapproved by the director promptly after receiving all necessary information. 
(c)	The person requesting a permit ("applicant") will provide the director with documentation in the format specified by the director, describing: 
(1)	The proposed, approximate location and route of all facilities to be constructed or installed and the applicant's plan for right-of-way construction; 
(2)	Three sets of engineering plans for the proposed facilities, drawn at a scale not to exceed one inch equals 100 feet unless otherwise approved by the director; 
(3)	Details of the location of all rights-of-way and utility easements that the applicant plans to use; 
(4)	Details of all existing city utilities in relationship to the applicant's proposed route; 
(5)	Details of what the applicant proposes to install, such as pipe size, number of interducts, valves, etc.; 
(6)	Details of plans to remove and replace asphalt or concrete in streets, driveways, alleys and sidewalks; 
(7)	Drawings of any bores, trenches, handholes, manholes, switchgear, transformers, pedestals, etc., including depth; 
(8)	Complete legend of drawings submitted by the applicant; 
(9)	The name, address and phone numbers of the contractor or subcontractor who will perform the actual construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with the contractor who will be available at all times during construction. Such information shall be required prior to the commencement of any work; 
(10)	The construction and installation methods and materials to be employed for the protection of existing structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the right-of-way, and the dates and times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject to approval of the director; 
(11)	A statement that proof of insurance, bond or other required financial information is current and on file; 
(12)	A traffic control plan; 
(13)	Detailed emergency procedures and a list of "on-call" contacts; and 
(14)	A copy of the applicant's order granting a certificate of authority from the Mississippi Public Service Commission or other applicable state or federal agency, where the person is lawfully required to have such certificate from said commission or other state or federal agency. 
(d)	A permit issued under this article shall state to whom it is issued, location of work, location of facilities, dates and times of work that is to take place and any other conditions set out by the director. The permit will be in the name of the person who owns or will own the facilities to be constructed, maintained, repaired, or upgraded or by a representative of the owner of the facilities to be constructed. Permits are not transferable from one person to another. In granting any permit, the director may attach such other conditions thereto as may be reasonably necessary to prevent damage to public or private property or to prevent the operation from being conducted in a manner hazardous to life or property or in a manner likely to create a nuisance. 
(e)	The director may require a pre-construction meeting with the right-of-way applicant and applicant's construction contractor. 
(f)	All construction and installation in the right-of-way shall be in accordance with the right-of-way permit. The director shall be provided access to the work and to such further information as he or she may reasonably require to ensure compliance with the permit. 
(g)	All construction or installation work authorized by permit must be completed in the time specified in the right-of-way permit. If the work cannot be completed in the specified time, the right-of-way applicant may request an extension from the director. The work shall not be made in any place other than the location specifically designated in the permit. 
(h)	A copy of the right-of-way permit and approved engineering plans shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the director at all times when construction or installation is occurring. 
(i)	Emergency responses related to existing facilities installed prior to adoption of this article, may be undertaken without first obtaining a permit; however, the director shall be notified in writing, on a form approved by the director, within two business days of any construction related to an emergency response. The written notice shall include a reasonably detailed description of the emergency work performed in the right-of-way and an updated map of any facilities that were moved or repaired. 
(j)	Right-of-way permit fees shall be established from time to time by the city. 
Sec. 30-31. - Notices to property owners, tenants, police, and fire authorities. 
(a)	If the work to be undertaken by the permittee is such that it will affect the use of properties abutting or adjoining the project, the director shall require the permittee to submit a list of the names and addresses of the owners and tenants of such properties. Upon receipt of such list, the director shall notify the affected property owners and tenants of the proposed work to be done. 
(b)	If the work to be undertaken by a permittee will affect other subsurface installations in the vicinity of the proposed opening, the director shall notify the owners of such facilities of the proposed work. 
(c)	The director shall notify the city police and fire authorities of all street opening permits granted. Such notification shall state the nature of the work to be done, proposed beginning and completion dates, and the location of such project. 
Sec. 30-32. - Construction standards. 
(a)	No person shall construct or install, or cause to be constructed or installed, facilities within a right-of-way that constitute a threat or hazard to public safety, either for vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(b)	Unless otherwise specifically allowed in writing by the director, all excavations within the right-of-way shall be filled and compacted within 24 hours of excavation and pavements of streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be completely restored within 14 days of excavation. 
(c)	The user or the user's contractor or representative shall notify the director 24 hours in advance that construction is ready to proceed. Notification shall include the reference number assigned to excavation by the one-call system. 
(d)	All construction shall be in conformance with all city codes and applicable local, state, and federal laws. 
(e)	Three feet by three feet information signs, stating the identity of the person doing the work on the facilities, telephone number and user's identity and telephone number, shall be posted in the right-of-way on each approach to the location where construction is to occur. The signs must be posted 24 hours prior to the beginning of work in the right-of-way and shall continue to be posted at the location during the entire time the work is occurring. 
(f)	Erosion control measures and advance warning signs, markers, cones, and barricades must be in place before work begins. 
(g)	Reflective barricades and flashing lights must be restored at the end of each day. 
(h)	Without affecting any contractual relationship between the user and its contractors, the user shall be responsible for the workmanship and any damages by their contractors and subcontractors. A responsible representative of the user will be available to the director at all times during construction. 
(i)	The user shall be responsible for storm water management and erosion control that complies with city, state and federal guidelines. Requirements shall include, but not be limited to, silt fencing in erosion areas until vegetation is restored, barricade fencing around open holes, and wire-backed silt fencing in high erosion areas. When any earth, gravel or other excavated material is caused to roll, flow, or wash upon any street, the permittee shall cause the same to be removed from the street within eight hours after deposit. In the event the earth, gravel or other excavated material is so deposited is not removed, the director shall cause such removal and the cost incurred shall be paid by the permittee or deducted from permittee's bond. 
(j)	The user or the user's contractor or subcontractor shall notify the director immediately of any damage to other utilities, whether owned by the city or privately owned. 
(k)	When a street, alley, or sidewalk cut is required, prior approval must be obtained from the director and all of the director's requirements shall be followed. Repair of all street, alley and sidewalk removals must be made promptly to avoid safety hazards to vehicle and pedestrian traffic. Excavated materials shall be laid compactly along the side of the trench and kept trimmed up so as to cause little inconvenience as possible to public travel. In order to expedite the flow of traffic or to abate a dirt or dust nuisance, the director may require the permittee to provide toe boards or bind: and if the excavated area is muddy and causes inconvenience to pedestrians, temporary wooden plank walks shall be installed by the permittee as directed by the director. If the street is not wide enough to hold the excavated material without using part of the adjacent sidewalk, the permittee shall keep a passageway at least one-half the sidewalk width along such sidewalk line. 
(l)	Cutting or excavation of street, alley, or sidewalk surfaces that are less than five years old is prohibited, unless approved by the director. 
(m)	All directional boring shall have locator place bore marks and depths while the bore is in progress. 
(n)	Lane closures in school zones or on streets other than residential streets shall be limited to the time period between 8:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless prior approval is obtained from the director. All barricades, warning flags and danger signs and reflector cones shall be placed in accordance with specifications established by city ordinance or as specified by the director. 
(o)	All work, including any directional boring, must be performed between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, except as otherwise provided by this subsection. Any work to be performed outside these work hours must be approved 24 hours in advance by the director or his or her designee. No work may be done on city holidays, except in case of emergency. 
(p)	Users are responsible for obtaining line locations from all affected utilities at least 48 hours prior to any excavation. 
(q)	Placement of all handholes, manholes, or other access facilities must be approved in advance by the director. 
Sec. 30-33. - Plans of record. 
(a)	Users shall provide the director with "plans of record" within 30 days of completion of work in the right-of-way. 
(b)	Users with existing facilities in the rights-of-way as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall submit within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, a plan to provide complete plans of record in not more than 300 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(c)	The plans of record shall be provided to the city in the format specified by the director and contain as much detail and accuracy as required by the director. All the criteria specified for plans submitted for the initial permit will be required for the plans of record. 
(d)	Submittal of plans shall be in digital format as well as written. 
(e)	Users shall, not later than January 31 of each year, submit updated plans of record which incorporate all changes, additions, abandonments, and relocations of Facilities completed in the previous calendar year; provided, however, if no additions have been made to its installation during the previous year, a utility may file with the director a written statement to that effect, within the time period specified above. The annual update of the plans of record shall be in the format prescribed by the director. 
Sec. 30-34. - Abandoned facilities. 
(a)	Whenever any infrastructure located under the surface of any street, or the use thereof, is abandoned, the person owning, using, controlling or having an interest therein shall, within 30 days after such abandonment, file with the community development division, a statement in writing giving in detail the location of the structure so abandoned. Each map, or set of maps, filed pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall show in detail the location of all such structures abandoned subsequent to the filing of the last preceding map or set of maps. 
(b)	When the city plans to pave or improve streets in which there are abandoned facilities, the owner of such facilities shall be notified to remove them if in the opinion of the city council their removal is in the interest of the city. If the owner shall refuse to remove such facilities within 60 days of the city's request, the city shall remove the abandoned facilities and the owner shall reimburse the city for such removal. 
Sec. 30-35. - Improperly installed, repaired, or maintained facilities. 
(a)	A user of the city rights-of-way shall properly install, repair, upgrade, and maintain its facilities. 
(b)	Facilities shall be considered to be improperly installed, repaired, upgraded, or maintained if: 
(1)	The installation, repair, upgrade or maintenance endangers public health, safety or welfare; 
(2)	The facilities encroach upon private property or extend outside the right-of-way location assigned by the director; 
(3)	The facilities do not meet applicable state, federal or local laws; 
(4)	The facilities are not capable of being located or maintained using standard practices; or 
(5)	The facilities are placed in an area that interferes with another user's facilities. Nothing in this section shall diminish the authority of the director to require specific placement of lines. 
Sec. 30-36. - Restoration of property. 
(a)	A user of the city rights-of-way shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of-way and adjoining property or other facilities which the user or its facilities damage. 
(b)	A user shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace, restore or repair any street, facilities or property or structure thereon, thereunder, thereover or adjacent thereto that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of the construction or installation, operation, upgrade, repair or removal of facilities to a condition as good as or better than its condition before the work performed by the user that caused such disturbance or damage. If a user does not commence such replacement or repair within 20 working days following written notice from the city, the city or the owner of the affected structure or property may make such replacement or repair and the user shall pay the reasonable and actual cost of the same. 
(c)	All locate flags shall be removed during the clean-up process by the user at the completion of the work. 
(d)	Restoration of all streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, and related infrastructure must be done in accordance with federal, state, and local requirements, including, but not limited to the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(e)	Restoration must be made in a timely manner and to the satisfaction of the director. If restoration is not satisfactory or not performed in a timely manner, then all of the user's work in progress, except for that work related to the problem, will be halted and no other permit will be approved until all restoration work is complete. The hold on the user's work will include work previously permitted but not complete. 
Sec. 30-37. - Revocation or denial of permit. 
    If any provisions of this article are not followed by a user of the rights-of-way, a permit may be revoked by the director. If a user has not followed the terms and conditions of this article in work done pursuant to a prior permit, new permits may be denied or additional terms required. All appeals of administrative decisions of the director shall be in writing and shall be sent via certified mail to the chief administrative officer within 30 days from the date the administrative decision was issued. All appeals will be heard by the planning commission within 45 days from the date a written appeal is received by the community development division. 
Sec. 30-38. - Authority to require relocation. 
    The director or his or her designee shall be authorized to require a holder of a right-of-way permit to relocate their pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, and other equipment, facilities, or appliances if such relocation is a public necessity as determined by the director or his or her designee. The director or his or her designee may also require an overhead wire or cable to be relocated underground if the street involved should convert from an overhead telephone system to an underground telephone system. 
Sec. 30-39. - Liability of permit holder. 
    The holder of a right-of-way permit shall at all times be responsible to the public and hold the city harmless for any property damage or personal injury caused or occasioned by the installation, maintenance or occupancy of any wire, cable or conduit under, upon, along, or over the public roads and highways and rights-of-way as provided for in this article. 
Sec. 30-40. - Insurance and bonding requirements. 
(a)	Any person seeking to obtain a right-of-way permit shall provide to the director proof of liability insurance or self-insurance in the amount of $2,000,000.00 primary plus $3,000,000.00 umbrella, or other securities as acceptable to the director. Such insurance shall cover all work done by such person upon, under, along, and over the public roads and highways and rights-of-way located within the municipality and shall be maintained during all periods such work is being done. 
(b)	Any person applying for a right-of-way permit shall be required to submit a performance bond or other security acceptable to the director in the amount of $5.00 per linear foot of right-of-way to be occupied, with a minimum of $25,000.00, which shall be held for a period of one year from the date of final inspection, to ensure that all infrastructure is replaced satisfactorily, and that no complications arise as a result of the right-of-way disturbance. Such bond shall cover all work done by such person upon, under, along, and over the public roads and highways and rights-of-way located within the municipality. 
(c)	A performance or surety bond shall guarantee completion to the satisfaction of the city of all excavation and street restoration work required by this article and by the conditions of the permit within the time limits set on the permit. Said bond shall further guarantee that all excavation and street restoration work shall be free from settling and defects in workmanship or materials for a period of two years after the date said work is completed and accepted by the city. The bond shall be conditioned to protect and save harmless the city and the city council from all claims and damages for cleaning or repairing any damage by the person and will be used to reimburse the city for any cost incurred to clean or repair city roads or rights-of-way, to re-ditch or repair existing ditch structure or for other damage caused as a result of the actions of the person after the issuance of the right-of-way permit. The performance bond or surety bond shall be in a form approved by the city's attorney. 
(d)	Such bond shall protect the city against any damage caused by such person or firm tendering the bond, or any agent, employee or contractor of said person or firm and will be used to reimburse the city for any cost incurred to clean or repair city roads or rights-of-way, to re-ditch or repair existing ditch structure or for other damage caused as a result of the actions of the person after the issuance of the right-of-way permit. The person responsible for operations under the right-of-way permit will be given notice of the damage and allowed 72 hours to restore the road and right-of-way to a safe and operable condition as determined by the director. All repairs, material used and final releasing conditions shall be approved and accepted by the director. 
(e)	A surety bond shall be issued by a surety acceptable to the city, and shall contain the following endorsement: "This bond may not be canceled or allowed to lapse until one year after receipt by the city, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a written notice from the issuer of the bond of intent to cancel or not to renew." 
(f)	The city may require verification of continuing coverage as needed. 
Sec. 30-41. - Violations. 
(a)	Violation of the requirements of this article shall be prosecuted as provided in section 1-4. 
(b)	Each day of operation without sufficient and legal notice or without a bond, insurance, letter of credit, shall constitute a new and separate violation of this article. 
(c)	Prior to initiation of enforcement litigation, the violator shall be given the opportunity to correct the violation within the timeframe specified by the director. 
(d)	In addition, the city may order specific performance of any actions required by this article or required by a franchise, license, or permit, including the permit authorizing work to be performed in the right-of-way, or any other agreement or authorization. 
Secs. 30-42-30-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES AND VENDING ON PUBLIC THOROUGHFARES 

Sec. 30-128. - Sales, etc., on streets-Prohibited; exceptions as to ice cream vendors and farm products vendors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, sell, give away to induce trade, or vend at retail to the public any goods, wares, merchandise, produce, farm products, fruit, poultry or vegetables on any of the streets in the city; except that this section shall not be applicable to any person engaged in the sale and distribution of ice cream products intended for immediate consumption, if said person shall obtain the proper municipal vending licenses, shall comply with all regulations of the county health department applicable thereto, shall maintain the permanent situs of all vehicles used in such distribution and sales within the city, and shall maintain liability insurance coverage of $100,000.00 or more on each of said vehicles. 
(Code 1977, § 13-16; Ord. of 7-21-1961, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 30-129. - Same-Statement of intent. 
    The intent and purpose of section 30-128 is to prohibit the sale of merchandise described in said section, subject to the exception as to ice cream products contained therein, from trucks and other vehicles or stands parked or located within or on any of the streets in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-17; Ord. of 7-21-1961, § 3) 
Sec. 30-130. - Same-Definition. 
    The term "street" used in sections 30-104 and 30-105 shall be construed to include sidewalks and the ground between the sidewalk and the curb as well as the street. 
(Code 1977, § 13-18; Ord. of 7-21-1961, § 4) 
Sec. 30-131. - Display of merchandise on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any merchant or other person doing business in the city to expose goods, wares or merchandise in such manner as to rest upon, or project over the sidewalks of the city or in any manner obstruct the free use of said sidewalks and passage thereon by the public. 
(Code 1977, § 13-19; Ord. of 5-25-2005) 
Secs. 30-132-30-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMPLETE STREETS 

Sec. 30-150. - Statement of intent. 
    The city seeks to plan for, design, and construct all new city transportation improvement projects to provide appropriate accommodation for pedestrians, bicyclists, motorists, and persons of all ages and abilities, while promoting safe operation for all users. Complete streets may be achieved through single projects or incrementally through a series of smaller improvements or maintenance activities over time. It is the mayor and city council's intent that all potential sources of transportation funding be considered to implement complete streets principles. The city believes that maximum financial flexibility is important to implement complete streets principles and that implementation should complement the context of the community. 
Sec. 30-151. - Incorporation of complete streets principles. 
    The city recognizes the importance of a well-connected network of streets, sidewalks, and bicycle paths and will incorporate the complete streets principles as follows: 
(1)	Planning, design, and construction of new streets and roadways shall encourage connectivity with existing streets and roadways in an effort to create a comprehensive, integrated, and connected transportation network for all users and modes of transportation. 
(2)	A four-foot wide paved shoulder shall be included with construction of all new roadways or with the resurfacing or reconstruction of existing roadways when roadway traffic is greater than 1,000 vehicles per day. Paved shoulders have safety and operational advantages for all road users in addition to providing a place for bicyclists and pedestrians. 
(3)	Sidewalks, shared use paths, street crossings (including over and under passes), pedestrian signals, signs, street furniture, transit stops, and other facilities, shall be designed, constructed, operated, and maintained so that all pedestrians, including people with disabilities, can travel safely and independently. 
(4)	Bicycle and pedestrian ways shall be established in new construction and reconstruction projects undertaken by the city in keeping with the proposals of the city's comprehensive plan unless one or more of these conditions exist: 
a.	Bicyclists or pedestrians are prohibited by law from using the roadway. In this instance, a greater effort may be necessary to accommodate bicyclists and pedestrians elsewhere within the right-of-way or within the same transportation corridor. 
b.	The cost of establishing bikeways or walkways would be excessively disproportionate to the total cost of the transportation project. 
c.	Severe topographic or natural resource constraints exist that preclude expanding roadway paving without incurring excessive costs. 
d.	There is very low population density and scarcity of residents or other factors indicate an absence of present and future need. 
Sec. 30-152. - Complete streets principles not applicable. 
    Complete streets principles will not apply where extraordinary circumstances exist, such as: 
(1)	During ordinary maintenance activities designed to keep assets in serviceable condition (e.g., mowing, cleaning, sweeping, spot repair and surface treatments such as chip seal, or interim measures on detour or haul routes); 
(2)	Where the city council issues a documented exception concluding that application of complete streets principles is inappropriate because it would be contrary to public benefits or safety; 
(3)	Where other parallel accommodation exists; or 
(4)	Where there is a demonstrated absence of present and future need. 
Chapter 32 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 32-1-32-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT TAX ABATEMENT 

Sec. 32-21. - Title. 
    This article shall hereby be entitled the "Historic Preservation District Tax Abatement Ordinance" and shall hereafter be referred to and known under such title. 
(Ord. of 2-18-2014, § I) 
Sec. 32-22. - Purpose. 
    There is hereby established a tax abatement program within the area of the city designated by the city council as the Main Street Greenwood, Inc. District, including any property designated as a state or national historic landmark that is situated outside said district, the application of which shall be pursuant to the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-18-2014, § II) 
Sec. 32-23. - Exemption authority. 
    The city council may, in its discretion, exempt from any or all municipal ad valorem taxes, excluding ad valorem taxes for school district purposes, for a period of not more than seven years, any certain new renovations of, and improvements to, existing structures and for certain new structures lying within the areas designated by the city council as the Main Street Greenwood, Inc. District, including any property designated as a state or national historic landmark that is situated outside said district, but only in the event that such structures shall have been constructed, renovated or improved pursuant to the requirements as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. of 2-18-2014, § III) 
Sec. 32-24. - Pre-construction application procedures.
